name: Insurgency
description: Take to the streets for intense close quarters combat, where a team's survival depends upon securing crucial strongholds and destroying enemy supply in this multiplayer and cooperative Source Engine based experience.
minimum_requirements: Minimum OS: Windows® 7 Processor: Intel® Core™ 2 Duo E6600 or AMD Phenom™ X3 8750 processor or better Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: Video card must be 512 MB or more and should be a DirectX 9-compatible with support for Pixel Shader 3.0 Hard Drive: 10 GB HD space DirectX: 9.0c
recommended_requirements: Recommended Memory: 8 GB RAM Graphics: Video card 2048 MB or more Hard Drive: 10 GB HD space on a SSD

reviews.review_text: I decided to hold off on writing a review until there were a few more updates and for me to have at least 500+ hours invested into the game. I am going to keep this straight up what i think about it as a whole with no fluff. Short and sweet.  Should you get it? It depends on what type of fps's you like. Many CS players have fell in love with it because they like the realism and they've grown tired of the arcade feel that most other shooters have. Don't doubt it for a second, this game is hard to pick up on but once you do, you realize how well reflexes really help if you're rushing but don't expect to be 360 no-scoping people because there is almost no chance in hell that that will happen. Those with good aim that are looking down sight as you turn a corner will get you every time so this is a game best played instinctively and safe (just don't be one of those snipers that sit at spawn and let the enemy capture everything). There are few grenade, C4, or launcher spots that few people know of and use at the start of some maps which can be frustrating, so that is why I'm really hoping that much larger maps will be released in the future that are more open and don't feel as constrained/guided (Heights and Buhriz are like that but i still love them). Maps that were easy to spawn camp have been updated heavily to prevent that which is great. The devs are absolutely brilliant at balancing and opening new areas of maps, always on top of it so kudos to them.   Community engagement is stronger than i've ever seen it, there was a public playtest of player submitted maps that were voted on in hopes of them being added to the game and the rise of The Digital Gaming League is starting their first official Insurgency competitive season with a multitude of teams signed up.   The Nightfall update just added so much more to the game, it feels totally different than it used to in every good way possible. Noises are made when crossing though brush and leaning, leaning mechanic feels more 'stiff' (meaning not fluidly unnatural), the night vision is spot on and well-balanced, flares look awesome in the night sky, but my only complaint is that the running animations with weapons look kinda wonky now, i preffered it the way it was before but i won't nit-pick things for the sake of the length of this review. Also the new co-op survival is an amazing idea, i could see myself spending hours on that alone with friends.   I could write a list of 10,000 reasons to get this game but none of that could possibly describe the feeling that it would give you if you were playing it yourself. It needs to be experienced, the feelings it gives never dies and that in itself says something. Kills are rewarding, objectives are highly valued, teamwork is vital. You need this game in your life if you are looking for a realistic shooter!  *12/20/14 edited formatting*  NEW UPDATE! 5/3/16  1,290 hours logged, i just can't seem to get enough. New maps, improvements, feautures, etc. OH and a new Insurgency game is coming out soon hell yea! Community is growing steadily, a lot more Pick Up Games (PUG's) than there used to be when i wrote this review for those interested in competitive. My only wish is for ranked competitive matchmaking to exist instead of the typical unranked. The future of Insurgency is looking very healthy!

TL;DR: Rainbow Six + Red Orchestra + a bit of Counter-Strike and a sprinkle of attachments like Battlefield but without dumb unlocks. A solid tactical shooter with a slow pace and punishing time-to-kill where a few bullets will take you down.   Insurgency is Rainbow Six in Iraq with lots of sudden death and PTSD and jumping because you're shot out of nowhere. It's a game of hide-and-seek with laser sights betraying their owner's position and footsteps betraying your own position. Imagine if Red Orchestra had a baby with Rainbow Six. It's got a lot of that in its blood. In fact, one of the original devs for RO is the guy behind Insurgency. Now, the hypothetical RainbowOrchestra child was raised by Counter-Strike. Some round-based game modes and not all of them have respawns without some major coordination.   It's a tense package where you might go with no kills or a lot, depending on how well you can plan ahead with your teammates because if you don't get the drop on your enemies, you're dead before the bullets leave the chamber. If you liked the mod, you'll like this. If you like Red Orch but in the scale of the older Rainbow Six games, you'll like this.   On a scale of 20, I give it three thumbs up and -25% off coupon to a medium 2-topping pizza at participating locations. Would recommend.

A overall amazing game, has potential to compete with shooters like CS:GO, Battlefield and even Arma to some extent.  Gun mechanics are finally a break from the 'you have 90 bullets in your ar-15 and they magically go in your mag when reloading'.  Some quality-of-life and realism improvements/Things I'd like to see: -More guns -More character interaction (the character voice interaction is A1 in this game) -Surpression being more useful (making your screen a little bit blurry doesnt do that much. Especially support classes would benefit from this, as their main role is to lay down surpression fire over long distances. Maybe make it so if you get surpressed, you start to yell more, giving away your position, and maybe being more innacurate) -Guns don't come out of the scope, ffs. -Maybe make it so, when you are being surpressed or in adrenaline rush, you reload faster or something? -When you aim down sights while standing for too long, your hands get tired and your sights/scopes start to sway (depending on gun weight. (This will help against rpg's maybe?) -Clips for Mosin? -More voice interaction -Make it so when you are in need to switch to your handgun/get a grenade you can drop your weapon instead of holsting it then slowly taking out your throwable/gun. Maybe we will see inclusion of shoulder gun belts? -More voice interaction please  Overall, I rate this game 8.9/10   Also, props to /k/ for suggestions  EDIT:  -Guns are noisy as ♥♥♥♥ in real life, especially LMG's, sniper rifles and shotguns indoors. If you keep spamming that LMB you will probably get some ear disease. Add earpro as a accessory. This will also make surpressors more useful (by the way, surpressors DON'T make the gun go 'phoosh'. They're still loud). -Make going prone faster, like plunching yourself on your belly, when getting fired at -Muzzle flashes are a big deal when shooting at night.  EDIT 2: -Add a .357 revolver that you can load either .357 rounds or .38spc rounds (obviously, the 357rounds will do more damage but will kick a lot more, and the .38spc rounds will have much less recoil (due to the low power and gun weight) but will damage less, making it a good hit-and-run weapon maybe? -Maybe add so you can adjust grain ammount in bullets, maybe make a Hollow point +P abomination rifle that will one-shot unarmored opponents?
> Joined a server > A random dude in the insurgency team keeps trowing grenades and yelling allahu ackbar in mic > Other dude keeps playing arabic music  So far so good

Sometimes people ask me, what is your most favourite realistic fps game of all time? Can you guess what I reply back with.. Insurgency, that is all I say.. Insurgency.  -Amazing audio (Especially with the realistic sound mod) -Plenty of mods in the workshop -Awesome community, always willing to help a newbie out. -Sweet, intense firefights -Satisfying to shoot RPGs.  -Game doesn't assist you in any way, it's just you, you're gun and you're survival instincts.   Game needs a bigger playerbase, so please.... do yourself a favour and buy this game.

The most exciting, immersive, fun, and lethal multiplayer FPS I have ever played.  The Battlefield...  If I had one word to describe the experience, it's TACTICAL. First, if you're coming from BF3/4, the COD franchise, or CS:GO/S, forget everything you've learned about gun fights. Two, or often one, hit will kill you which means you need to use cover, suppression, smoke, and flash to get around. Gun fights are TENSE - this is partly due to the lethality of weapons, but also the suppression mechanic: you can hear the bullets wizzing by your head, your screen blurs, and if you pop your head out at the wrong time - THWACK, and your dead.  MAPS are expertly designed, consistently updated, lots of variety, and new ones are created suprisingly often for such a small developer.  WEAPONS have character and I've found new favourites for given situations even 100 hours into playing. UNLIKE CS:GO where you have to memorize spray and spread patterns for each weapon, Insurgency weapons perform realistically in that, wherever the sights are pointed, THAT IS EXACTLY WHERE THE BULLET WILL GO - weapons still recoil, but you know exactly where the bullet is headed when it does.   GAME MODES - brilliant. Co-op is awesome, multiplayer modes are relatively diverse and awesome. What's really unique here is the emphasis on teamplay. You really need to coordinate with your team to win certain modes, whether its popping smoke or having someone cover you while you move up. What sets this game apart, other than everything else, is that players work together here - you're not playing with the silent majority on BF4 or COD - people are on their mics, strategizing and celebrating the game - mostly adults too (well, adults who yell 'Alloha Snackbar' as terrorists while throwing grenades at American Soldiers, haha). If you get this game, get mic please, you miss out on a lot of the fun and you contribute to making this game less fun for everyone.  Final Words...  One of my favourite games on PC. Kudo's to a great development team who keep this game alive with frequent updates and tourneys. They obviously have a passion for what they do, and it's part of what makes this game great.  It also happens to have a total conversion mod for my first multiplayer FPS (TPS*) addiction, Socom 1 & 2 ( 'Socom: Source' ).
This game has taught me using a Nokia can blow up an entire army. 11/10 would call mum again
Every time I die people yell 'Aloha Snackbar!' In a bad middle eastern accent at me over their mics. 10/10

Insurgency is the most realistic shooter / FPS I have ever played.  - Takes 1 bullet to kill someone unless they have heavy armour, If they have heavy armour it takes 2 or 3. - No jump packs / No jetpacks. - 15+ Guns. - 30 maps / Night and day maps. - Great gamemodes. - 10+ Classes. Worth every penny.

Do you want to get shot? 'Cos that's how you get shot!  This game has been described as a cross between Counterstrike and Red Orchestra 2, and I think that fits.  The arcadey pew-pew of CS is absent and instead you play in a more realistic environment where your cautiousness and tactical thinking is rewarded. The sense of immersion is greater than in CS, and while the pace is (generally) slower, as a result it's also more intense with the stakes seeming higher.  You WILL get one-shot-killed in this game. AND you will one-shot kill others. You know going in that this is the case: that bullets are very deadly. This affects the way you play and you value your life more, and this in turn increases the immersion.  You will NOT find yourself (as seems to happen in CS:GO) plugging several rounds into an enemy standing right in front of you who immediately one-shot-insta-kills you, and be left with the feeling that your death was somehow unfair.  The bots in co-op mode; waves of enemies that unlock after an objective has been achieved to protect the next objective or re-capture the one just taken (randomly triggered) behave, on the most part, very realistically. You'll get ones that see your head as you lie prone and headshot you and you'll get ones that rush past you, failing to spot you waiting round a corner (as well as ones who anticipate you hiding there). They never feel either under or over-powered and do a good job of convincing you they're real. The only exception is their tendency to disregard fire (from molotovs/incendiary grenades) and they will quite often simply stand in the flames and burn to death without fleeing or run straight into the fire, disregarding it and ... die. That needs fixing.  Co-op with 5 other players feels very good. Six player teams mean you don't feel too much individual responsibility most of the time, but that can suddenly change when at the last moment as your comrades have fallen you're thrust into the role of saving the team, capturing the objective and triggering their re-spawn against the odds. This can result in an Immense sense of achievement and reward when successful and (unless you're playing with Grade-A A-Holes) good-natured sympathy and/or hilarity when you fail. Communication with your team is often essential to succeed, the whole game mode is very enjoyable.  PvP is a blast and where the comparison to Red Orchestra 2 is closest. Squads of up to 16 players (although, as this is a Source-based game 12v12 is the norm) fight against each other across some beautiful and realistic maps.  You will love the warm glow of the sun in the late afternoon as you run through the crunchy snow, but you will also curse that very same sun getting in your eyes and obscuring your view of the other side of the ravine and that blasted snow for giving away your movement.  The feelings of 'oh crap, oh well, here goes' as your squadron marches into uncertain death that games like Red Orchestra and Planetside provoke is here, albeit on a somewhat smaller scale, but Insurgency does it better. It's prettier, smoother and more polished than RO2 and your value to your team is much higher than in both that and Planetside.  And did I mention how inexpensive it is? The Fun:Value ratio on this game is very, very high. If you have a few spare quid and a few friends to play this with, you will have a blast with Insurgency.

Insurgency has one of the most authentic FPS experiences I've ever had the pleasure of playing. The authenticity of this game is due to HUD realism (no radar, no hit markers), sound realism (let's just say you'll understand why people are hiding behind cover when you hear the bullets whizzing by), weapon feel and control, and loadout customization. The variety of guns, maps, and modes lend to its replayability. The AI in this game is probably the best I've seen so far, sometimes rivaling the skill of real players. The game supports the Steam Workshop where you can find some of the best maps, gun mods, and audio packs that really spice up the experience. One of the biggest personal selling points is the dedication and passion that the developers show for this game. Since release, they've released huge free content updates that include new maps, weapons, gameplay updates, and most recently, Linux support.  +Authentic experience +Loadout customization +Night mode +Great AI +Free content updates +Steam Workshop support +Linux support +Achievements +Trading Cards   No cons.

Brutal? Check. Realistic? Check. Solid Controls? Check. Balanced? Check. Dev support? NWI has provided an incredible amount of support and free updates for this self-published indie game. If you wish more games did near Valve level patches for years after release then please support this developer. Triple Check.

Insurgency is a tactical multiplayer FPS set in the middle-East and it's best described as a hybrid between Counter Strike and Red Orchestra. I would say the game is less realistic than Red Orchestra but more realistic than Counter Strike. The maps are also in between those games, so bigger maps than CS but smaller maps than RO.  Obviously, gameplay is the most important aspect of a game like this. Controlling your character and shooting just feels great. Since you often die in just a few hits, taking cover is essential and it makes your adrenaline pumping, every time you find yourself in a tight spot.  At the start of each game you have to pick one of the many classes and spend your points on guns (20+ in total) and other gear like; light/heavy armor, flashbangs, grenades or Nightvision goggles.   There are quite a few different game modes for you to choose from like; Ambush (one player is the VIP and should be protected, otherwise your team loses), Firefight (defend objectives from the opposing team). There are also a few modes to co-op vs bots like; Checkpoint (destroy, occupy and defend your positions, throughout the map), Hunt (Kill all bots and destroy their cache).  The graphics look great, nothing really to complain about.  As you would expect from a game set in the middle-East, most maps have a lot of sand and brown/yellow colors (although there are a few snowy maps as well). Still, there's lot of variety between the maps. Some for close quarter combat, some for open ranged combat, the developers simply did a great job creating interesting maps with the same template.  Personally, I prefer Insurgency over Counter Strike, at least for the time being. I can recommend this to anyone, who's looking for a good tactical multiplayer shooter.

I have around 200 hours in Insurgency, which is by far my favorite 'realistic' FPS game.  INS simply, has it all. (for what it is).  It runs great, it's brutal, nice graphics, everything works (it hardly ever bugs out).  CoOp and PVP modes are both great, there's a decent , large community playing.   The gun play is outstanding.  In terms of negative points, smoke and AI needs work, snipers will ♥♥♥♥ you off and well, thats about it.  Team work really pays off in this game, I like the fact it's limited in option's as it allows tactics to be deployed and for players to get better.  Finally, it makes me jump alot and the suppression effect is fantastic.

What the game successfully combines is the tension of real death CQC like the Swat series with the firefight intensity of any modern online shooter. John Wayne Cowboy tactics are death. Team communication and RWT are key. When the chips of wall are flaking away and the pings are dangerously close, your heartrate WILL increase. Then when you realize it's you yelling like a 4th grader, a smile takes over. Total noob as I just got the game, played coop for an hour and had a blast. Well worth it.

This is the game that will stop me from playing Counter-Strike, I didn't expect to have so much with it. I've played so many different FPS and for a long time, like Battefield (since 1942), COD, I've played every CS, my playtime is ~1000 hours on CSGO and I think I won't play anymore cause of this game, cause of how addictive this game is. I think Insurgency is now my favorite FPS, but I do wish to see a bigger player base in the near future for this fantastic realistic fps. You won't see any usable airplanes, tanks, or jeep, just you and your feet.  Insurgency offers severals mods for every map to play, and you can customize every weapon at anytime while in spawn. The gameplay offers a realistic battlefield experience just by giving 'nothing', I mean it has no spotting at all on the HUD, you have no clue (no radar, no crosshair) where your ennemies are and who is shooting at you until a teammate tells you or you see him, and that's absolutely great. You actually don't know if you've killed someone, until you see the blood on the wall or see his dead body where he was standing. You just see where the objectives are, like Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, ... You need to cooperate with your teammates to win, voicetalk can be a real asset, having a squad leader too.  Insurgency was a few years ago just a mod for Half-Life 2, I've played it and I didn't enjoyed it, the gun mechanic was not at his best, now the gameplay is INSANE. This is the one shot, one kill game, in a realistic battlefield, you have been waiting for.  The graphics are not the best, but guess what? The game looks better than CSGO and they use both the source engine. You won't ever find a game with such a great sound effects. Guns feel real, they sound real, they will scare the hell out of you. Getting a kill is so rewarding, even more when you are the HVT (High Value Target) and you kill half of the opposite team by yourself before you escape and win the round (hey hey). However, getting kills is not your only priority, you need to do the objectives to revive your teammates (called waves) or you will be alone. You need to watch your corners, stop rushing cause sometimes defending a point you hold it's the best thing to do.   Finally I want to say someting about the smoke grenades, how they look awesome and how really effective in this game they are, so cloudy, dark and huge [insert a bad taste joke here], those grenades are a real asset in the battlefield if you want to take control of a point (A-B-C). I also like what developpers did to bullets that hit the ground, it makes the dirt/dust goes everywhere around you, it's something that helps you to notify that an ennemy is firing at you, so you can take cover or just disappear right away. You can even see where the bullets are coming from if you pay attention to it.  tl;dr : I recommend it.   9/10 : -1 cause the fan base is really low...but it's not the dev team fault, so +1. 10/10

I love it for the fact that the Hunt & Nightfall DLC is free. The devs are constantly improving and upgrading this game without charging extra. The community's brilliant & growing (most of my steam friends are from this game). This is a big middle finger to the AAA devs and even other indie devs who want to milk their existing customers instead of trying to reach out to more people with a dedicated game.
One of my favorite games on steam, CHHEEAAHHH !

This game is just....wow. Everything is amazingly accurately depicted, from the grenade weight, the audio, the physics, the bullet penetration going through different materials, the suppressing fire system, everything about this game is intense and punishing if you ♥♥♥♥ up for a second while in a firefight.   It's times like this in a match where you're scoped in, looking to pick off any enemies, especially opposing snipers or grenadiers. You see an enemy sniper far away, and he sees you too. It's all a matter of who pulls the trigger faster, and you hear an empty dull click from your gun. No more bullets loaded in the chamber? You soon find yourself dead.   That's right, there's no ammo counter or anything that indicates how many shots you have left, nor a crosshair or a life bar. The only thing you have on your HUD is how many magazines you have left and a compass w/ a map you can toggle. This game requires good teamwork and communication to win matches, and it's rewarding to blow up the final enemy cache with a brick of C4 when you're the last man standing.   Bottom line: if you want a tactical shooter that delivers intense close quarters combat action, with a variety of huge maps as well, get this game, you will not be disappointed. My only gripe is that I wished the developers spent more time optimizing the game, because it only utilizes less than half of my cpu and gpu combined, which can lead to minor fps drops at times.  Oh, and get ready for all the 'allahu ackbars' on the mics.

AWESOME FPS mulitplayer game that absolutely nailed the core mechanics. Completely balanced weapons & gameplay, no health bar, no enemy spotting or kill cams. Just fun tactical coop & team play. Highly recommended if you are a fan of more 'realistic' or hardcore mode shooters.

A wonderful realistic military shooter that has some aspects of ARMA, Rainbow Six and CS that I enjoy. If you like the map styles of Counterstrike you will probably enjoy this game. If you like the simulation/realistic shooting in ARMA or Rainbow Six, I have a feeling you will enjoy this game. If you liked the old Ghost Recon games you will probably enjoy this game.  The atmosphere is top notch, the gunplay feels very very good (it has literally my favorite handgun/pistol gunplay ever), the controls are right where I would like them, the levels are well designed and most importantly it is just a blast to play.  After the horrible garbage that was Takedown: Red Sabre, it was so good to see another indie shooter that was gunning for the same crowd come in and just NAIL it, near perfectly. Every single aspect is better in this game, so fans of any of those games i mentioned above now have another modern style sim/realistic shooter that is fun to play with friends and calls for teamwork.  The ai is good in this game so you really have to take you're time and be ready for some intense firefights. I enjoy playing coop on this as I did in Ghost Recon/Rainbow Six back in the day, a ton of fun with friends!   In the end this is a shining example of how to do a indie shooter in a niche area and do it well. Also this was a early access game and another good example of how EA games should be. What are you waiting for? Pick this game up asap and support some pretty awesome devs! Two big thumbs up!
The most realistic game I've ever played.

So, I've logged a lot of hours into this game because honestly it's my favorite shooter and I say that wholeheartedly.   The graphics are great even on the lower settings, and the user interface is the epitome of barebones. The only thing that really shows on your screen is how many magazines you have left. There's no minimap, no radar, no '23/30'. It's great because it makes you rely on what you're seeing going on in the game universe around you as opposed to looking at a gadget in the corner. You can tell when you're being fired at because tracers will be lighting up the world around you, and you'll know it's close because you'll hear a hiss or a snap. You note that green tracers are used by the insurgents and red are used by the Security. Something like that I can appreciate because it is more immersive.   The gameplay itself is usually pretty hectic and a good number of the times in PvP you'll find yourself wondering what's going on. PvE is fun because there's nothing like slaying 40 insurgents with your friends, and the last one fires an RPG and every single one of you dies.   The workshop community is great, you can get anything from graphics updates to new skins for your weapons or even sillier mods that change your grenades to pokeballs and your weapons sounding like anime girls when you reload them.   Since I purchased the game back in November 2014, the devs have been meticulous in updating their game, they add new maps, fix glitches, and cosmetic changes like scope reticules and the like. As far as I can tell if the fanbase wants something, the devs will try to add it in if it's a good idea.   So basically it's a current game with fantastic gameplay and a dedicated dev team who actively upkeep their work.   10/10.

Somehow, this has managed to be one of the most refreshing online shooters I've played in a while. Despite the fact that you have shooters like ARMA, as well as games like Red Orchestra 2 and Battlefield 4 that encourage tactics, Insurgency manages to find it's own place that helps distinguish it from the rest while feeling every bit as deserving of a spot in your library. While running on the aging Source Engine, the games visuals consistently manage to surprise, especially considering how well it handles some of its more open environments and medium to long range combat without the slightest framerate hitch.   For those who have managed to read this far, the game offers several games modes. Two for co-op, one of which is a survival/horde mode, three that are similar to Counter Strike's round-based gameplay, and three that have a limited number of respawns in the form of waves, closer to Red Orchestra. 32 player limit, a decent number of maps that offer a lot of different play styles, a unique loadout menu, NO PERKS/KILLSTREAKS (yaaaaaaaaay!!!), and incredibly well done sound effects.  Again, this game definitely gets my seal of approval, and don't forget to try to convince some others to check it out too!

You shouldn't be reading this. Instead, you should be purchasing this game!  Listen, it can be frustrating at first. For the first 10-20 hours or so, you are going to want to throw your computer across the room... You'll yell in frustration as you have no idea why you are dying, struggle to come to grips with the idea that bullets hurt, and wonder why tatics you've used in other multiplayer FPS aren't working. It's going to ♥♥♥♥ you off.   But stick it out! Once you start to learn some of the tricks, you'll find an intensly rewarding gaming experience. Having well over 200 hours on this game, I still look forward to playing, and it never gets old. You have to remember this is a tactical shooter, so you have to be thinking with that mindset. Your job is to outsmart your enemy and complete objectives. Your K:D ratio isn't the focus of the game, and with the lack of crosshair, your going to have to aim down your sites if you hope to hit anything. Play the objectives, learn the maps and your K:D ratio will go up.   I'm still learning, but a few tips that may help in your adventure: Take it slow. If you try to rush into the firefight, you will die. Quickly. Check your corners, and re-check them. Play the objectives, and the kills will come naturally. Communicate, communicate, communicate. Most imporantly, have fun and don't let the frustration get to you!

Insurgency leads you into a realistic modern infratry game. 'Yet another one' you might think? well you might reconsider that...  The game is based on two different game types: PvP and Co-op mode, both modes includes a supply management: when you win objectives you earn supplies to add new gear/weapons to your character so choose well when you start and pick clever upgrades depending of the weapons and stragtegy you choose to go with.  PvP is a decent classic team deathmatch/capture point gametype but there's no doubt the most intersting part is the coop one: fights against clever bots with tactics and deadly accuracy.  If you are looking for a good co-op challenge i highly recommend it.  Note that this game is still in developement and there're many improvement to be made and things to be added.

Fast paced 5-10 min matches where every move counts. If you like shooters where communication,stratagy and covering your corners is key then this is for you! It's still being worked on but I have not had any major issues as far as bugs mostly rubberbanding and syncing probelms.That said it's 100% playable and enjoyable i give it a strong 8/10 at this point making it well worth the 15$.

Updated Review #2: I feel it's time to revisit the review for Insurgency. The game has progressed quite well since it left Early Access. The game has seen a multitude of free DLC map updates and additions to an already rock solid base of a game.  The ambience of the game is fantastic. The sound effects, the maps, the characters, and music all culminate into a perfect blend of FPS goodness.  NWI clearly has taken pride behind their work and has kept forward with it's ideas for it's game to keep it fresh and rewarding. I can't recommend this game enough as it's one of the best purchases on Steam that comes to mind.  Updated Review: I would say this is perhaps one of the best FPS purchases I've ever made. If you are a FPS fan you need to give this a chance and find out why Insurgency is awesome. The studio behind this game clearly had a vision and has supported this game since launch with A+ content updates.   Original review: Insurgency is a fantastic source FPS shooter that thrives on realism, teamwork, sensical, and most importantly tactical based gameplay. It's a blast, it looks good, the asking price is a fraction of what most FPS games charge out of the gate, and it's an absolute steal at their 14.99 asking price.  With a thoughtful system of each side having set open types of players who have a limited option of weapons that can be adjusted with attachments, secondary firearms, accessories, and points that determine what you'll be able to have and not have the game doesn't let everyone run rampant with the same setups. Each person has meaning to their side and there's none of that over the top arcadey FPS stuff here with streaks for assists and kills.  It's what I've wanted for a long time in a shooter and if you have found enjoyment with Red Ochestra 2 and/or Rising Storm this may be right down your alley.

Been on board since the early access of this game back in 2014 and boy has it been a wild ride. I met one of my best friends playing this game, it encourages teamplay a lot and it will rock your balls if you try to rush tactics. The mods always make me laugh, putting cory in the house on your scope is just something every game needs.  If you want a really rewarding tactical FPS shooter, then this is the game for you. Think about every step you take, move from cover to cover and know where your teammates are. If you try to go in with a battlefield or COD strategy, you get your ♥♥♥ handed to you. Get in there with a microphone, communication is essential.  Insurgency is one of those games that are just good at what they do, and in this case that is a tactical team based FPS

This game really deserves some attention. If you are looking for a solid old school coop fps, this may be the game for you. No crosshair, no health regen, no kill confirmation, no grindy leveling system, friendly fire on (default). The approach is realistic but it's not a sim. Firing rpg or triggering a c4 explosion will get you killed if you don't use them carefully.  Focusing on the coop part of the game, you will face unforgiving AI that will throw at you frag, smoke nades and will try to flank you. Speaking about the hardest settings, you may argue with me that AI bots seem like aimbotting but it's just what skilled players would do. If you don't pull the trigger first, they will. Maps are pretty intense and require teamwork, patience and tactical approach. No lonewolf rambo would survive much long here. There is also a nice radial menu to communicate with your team vital info without the use of a mic, which is not required but recommended. This game reminds me a bit of the first Ghost Recon. To me this game is already worth full money for only the coop experience, not to mention that it will get steamworks support.  About pvp multiplayer i cannot say much since i didn't play it enough, though the couple of games i played felt good to me. There are like 6 different pvp modes to accomodate most of tastes: some single life modes and some with respawns. There is still no pure team deathmatch but it would not fit this game because it relies on objectives you have to accomplish with your team.

The finest tactical shooter game I have ever played. Almost 400 hours in and I can easily see myself putting in another 400.  Despite being a relatively small, low budget project, Insurgency does many things better than triple A titles such as Battlefield. The no-scope mechanic is a personal favorite of mine, where getting hip fire kills actually relies on skill instead of luck. The suppression is insane, and while the graphics aren't top of the line, they are very playable. The fire effects are simply beatiful. Sound is immersive, combat is intense and damage is brutal, the grenade mechanics are unmatched (I mean, where else can you pull the pin and leave in the spoon for worry free cooking?), and the overall experience is simply amazing. I have nothing but good things to say about Insurgency. And with steam workshop, you can mod it in whatever way you desire, from the comprehensive World War 2 mod Day of Infamy to the classic Allahu Akbar Soundmod. Finest $5 I ever spent.

This game can easily compete with the top FPS games out today. It is geared towards squad based gameplay and is set on a 'Hardcore' setting. It has a fresh gamemode that is similar to domination fused with search and destroy. It is similar to Red Orchestra, with modern warfare elements.  The bullet hit is dead on; rarely have I been cheated out of a kill due to lag and/or those 'annoying moments' when you think you shot them and you really didn't.  There is no 'level up' system, instead you are given points for doing well in-game. You can use these points to put attachments on your weapon.   *PLEASE READ* THIS GAME IS NOT FOR THE FAINT OF HEART. IT IS NOT FOR 5 YEAR OLD CHILDREN. It is a tactical shooter; It is squad based. There is no room for drop shots, quick scopes or noobtoobs.  It uses the valve source dedicated servers, so those of you that enjoy source games and the support. This game is for you.  The game is incredibly well made even though it is in the Early Access phase.   I'm glad I made this purchase. I will for sure drop Battlefield 4 and put time into this one.

I died alot in the beginning, but with time and a good squad or two, oh the joy. As a long time advocate of BFBC2, this game reminds what devs can do to bring back simpilicity, TEAMWORK and awesome fun times all at once. BEWARE no killcam, no HUD, no MAG COUNT. Awesome again. Its hard and its challenging BUT that kill, that POINT CAP, can be soooo >>>REWARDING<<< because, you actually earnt it. This game is a good balance between ARMA, BF. CS and RO.  Can't recommend highly enough for those in the FPS community who are looking for an extra challenge. You'll mostly find a good community of players who understand Friendly Fire, Teamwork and VoiceChat as you'll need all to succeed :P Enjoy

A friend gave me a copy of this game when Humble Bundle gave him extras because nobody wanted them or whatever, I don't know. Looks like the good ol' boys are at it again by putting bullets from bullet shooters into the hearts of heartless terrorists looking to kick over my sandcastle. The soundtrack is top notch, featuring a cacophony of dropped cell phones and the noise a roll of toilet paper makes when it's just run out. You know when it's just the tube spinning on the holder thing? Yeah. Anywho, sound effects are great: they used high-resolution motion capture on-location in Afghanistan to accurately capture the sound of boots clopping on foreign soil. Graphics are crazy polygonal and you can tell coders put a lot of work into making background objects like dumpsters and coffee mugs.  Pros: It's like I'm transported to a game loosely based around a real place. Cons: I never got past training; Tom shot me in the back of the head. Overall: It's like your first bike, but handles like your idiot dad put the training wheels on the front wheels. Score: 500/50

Although Insurgency isn't the most realistic shooter as of yet, it certainly shines by combining elements of realistic, unforgiving, and hardcore gameplay. Zero health regeneration, quick deaths, and the fact that your opponent could be just around the corner make for very exciting gameplay that keeps players on edge, fingers ready on their left mouse button. Matches are usually fast and furious, adding to the tension and excitement. In addition, an assortment of gamemodes and maps exist for those players who like variety. Players can take on other players head-on in a Firefight match or attempt to survive against AI-controlled enemies in nighttime environments while playing Survival. Also, the community is rather friendly and they churn out marvelous stuff that is available in the Steam Workshop. Yes, I forgot to mention that Insurgency does possess Workshop support. These workshop items offer numerous customizations and could make playing Insurgency even more fun. The developers, New World Interactive, are also very active, often looking for opinions from the community on how to improve the game and releasing frequent patches and updates.   However, as is the case with every game, Insurgency does have its weak points. It can be quite buggy at certain times and the community is rather small at the moment. Nevertheless, these are not major flaws and are vastly overshadowed by the pros of playing this game.   For a relatively low price, Insurgency offers a very in-depth experience comparable to that of bigger and more showy titles like Battlefield or Call of Duty. This game is a must-buy for all FPS fans.   Rating: 5 stars. Not just any kind of stars. GOLDEN STARS.
I like it! So that means if I like it, THEN GO GET IT :D

Take to the streets for intense close quarters combat, where a team's survival depends upon securing crucial strongholds and destroying enemy supply in this multiplayer and cooperative Source Engine based experience. The follow-up game to the award-winning Source mod, Insurgency is highly competitive and unforgivingly lethal, striking a balance between one-life gameplay and prolonged action.

9.5/10 Intense and terrifying when under fire, a (noob-)friendly community that is used to getting killed for the slightest mistake, which is essentially part of the experience.   Is it the most realistic shooter out there? Definitely not. There is no wound system like in some other games, usually you get shot and you die. In all honesty, many of the characteristics that would make it more realism-oriented (a complete lack of respawns, wound system, no HUD, ...) would in no doubt hurt the gameplay, which is now excellent. It certainly feels like a real firefight and the coop is as unforgiving as the player-v-player. The gameplay is tweaked in such a way that teamwork is not just key, but also a necessity to survival. This makes it important to communicate with other players, which obviously makes it a lot of fun.  If youre sick of bunnyhopping-shooters where you can go full Rambo without repercussions or if you have grown insensitive about being under fire (it's not easy shooting back in this game if you're being shot at) then this is the game for you.   This is not a sell-out big company game. They do a lot of effort to keep the price low, reward it!

I just got this game in the latest Humble Bundle and have 16 hours on so far. Wait, 16? I'm not sure that's right. A good two nights worth of play so I don't think I'm up to 16. That must count afk time. Anyway.... It's a fun game! It's objective team based 'realistic' shooter with a terrorist/ counterterrorist theme. It features PvP and PvE maps based on which server you join. It's not a run and gun type of game. Running actually feels pretty slow and walking is even slower. There is a little run+slide thing for getting to cover and you can go prone so there's a little more depth than just walking and shooting. No crosshairs except for iron sights or mods that you put on your gun. Being 1 life to live, a couple twitch players (or cheaters, I don't know) can really turn a battle. Of course if you manage to kill that guy, it really hurts the team too. Built in VOIP is good quality but of course you also have to deal with trolls. Tip: To kick someone, hit ESC and Call Vote.  PvE experience can vary depending on your tolerance for aimbots. You are playing against bots so without good scripting the only way to vary difficulty is to change the speed of their aimbot. On Brutual, it's not uncommon to insta-die before you see the bot because he shoots you through the corner of a wall that you can barely see his foot past. PvE modes vary too. Most commonly you'll play checkpoint which is like progressing through an assault map in Battlefield. You push up to an objective, capture it, and then progress down the map to the next objective, continuing to do so until you win or die. 1 life to live until someone captures an objective and all players are revived. The most annoying mode is Survival where you run around from objective to objective, usually with just a pistol and knife, trying to avoid getting killed by bots. If bots are on Brutal, one of these maps will clear out the server if there isn't an admin to change it. lol...  PvP is good. Maps can be like capture the flag or assault-type maps like from Battlefield. Teams usually have 'waves' which is respawns as opposed to a ticker per life. Depending on the map, waves can be gained by capturing objectives allowing for some very fun and intense matches when your team is hanging onto that last wave, trading an objective back and forth with the opposing team. Weapons seem relatively balanced but I always do better w/ Security (CT) weapons than Insurgents (T).   The game could do with a few ease of life updates like saving preferred builds but overall it's a very good game. I don't know how much it normally goes for but that 4 pack bundle for $45 making it about $11/ea doesn't sound that bad. Of course I got the 4 pack as part of a $12 humble bundle with Saints Row IV included so I definitely think it's worth it!

Insurgency is what modern shooters should strive to be like. Setting the standard with extremely difficult but fair gameplay it draws you in by making you actually think about your decisions in game. 'Should I lean around this corner?' 'If I take this path will there be more enemies?'   The game presents you with tactical decisions that most of the time can and will decide if you live or die. The core mechanics of the game rely on teamwork, you have to communicate, you have to be vigilant and watch each other's back. Failure means somebody was not doing their job properly. I've been playing Insurgency since the early beta and I'm extremely happy with forward progress that New World Interactive has had. Despite that however, there are still some things left to be desired.    PROS:  Extremely tight, precise controls.  Good balance of classes and weapons.  Variety of games modes to play.  Very accurate representation of real world firearms.   Fun but challenging gameplay.  Great community of modders.  CONS:  Somewhat hostile PvP and sometimes PvE communties.  Bots that can snipe you from half a mile away with AK irons.  Random heatseaking RPGs out of nowhere.   Alt+Tab sometimes completely crashes the game.   Online Servers can be finnicky at times.   Hit detection can sometimes fail completely.   Suggestions :  More general profile stats; Games played, won, lost, accuracy.  Improved party system.   Better server search function.   Reworking the damage and range of shotguns. Most of the time I completely disregard the shotgun because of it's tendency either not hit an enemy from 5m away or just not do any damage if I hit them at all.  Reworking some maps, I.E. Heights.     Overall, Insurgency is a great game with a huge learning curve. You cannot jump into this game with the intention of running through and mowing down anything in your path. The decisions you make result in how much fun you have with the game. New World Interactive does an extremely good job of updating the AI's pathfinding and combat skills. I feel with every update the games becomes more challenging, and with that more rewarding when you finally beat a map. This is not a game for people who are used to Battlefield or Call of Duty play styles. Once you get past the gigantic learning curve Insurgency becomes a game that you simply cannot put down.

Worth buying, especially during the sale.

Insurgency is that one game between a mix of Arma, Counter Strike, and Call of Duty. The shooting mechanics literally make you bounce off your chair in some cases. Bullets whiz by and you really want to avoid them, and you take yourself with greater care when you want to cross a street. You die so easily that you make sure to yourself that every corner, nook, and cranny is clear before you get into opening up. Even so, people can get lucky by running away from bullets in certain cases. I found myself literally hopping away from AK fire like I did in CS:GO. While the shooting mechanics make it have that realistic feel, it still has it's casual elements aswell. If you ever play in a public game, be sure to pick the ones that involve long respawn times (or none) because it attributes to much more team work and strategy. If you pick a casual match where everyone spawns seconds after death, you're talking about a free run shooting gallery in a nutshell. Surprisingly, Insurgency can run on my single slot toaster thanks to the Source Engine. It's a great game, and definitely a thrill that is unique to the shooter genre.

Short review in English:

Insurgency... This game alright was underrated from the start! I had barely any interest when it first came out but by the time of the summer sale, I regret it soo much. You see, Insurgency is a combination of so many FPS games today such as Counterstrike, Arma, Red Orchestra, Battlefield, even bits of COD too form this hardcore shooter. The game modes offer a variety of fun, yet tense hardcore scenarios ranging from the classic Push mode to the more hardcore Firefight version. The sound quality in this game is amazing! Hearing bullets flying past your head and crashing into the brick wall behind you gives you a very nervous and epic feel to the game that others fail to do. My first taste of the multiplayer was amazing, running towards Point A in Push on Peak to capture it while my teammates fired at the Insurgents in the hills, it felt absolutely immersive and cool. From the PvP multiplayer is when i got into Co-Op.    Now this game mode is seriously AMAZING. The AI somehow overs more intense feelings to the already intense feel in a more realistic yet surprising factor. Lets just say the AI is stupid, but at the same time smart. Yes, they have the same extremely amazing accuracy but that just makes it more frusturating. The thing is, they throw grenade and molotovs that actually AFFECT you. I was in a game where my team was trying to push through a building to capture the point when a bot threw a molotov on top of us, burning us down until half of us died. Did i tell you Co-Op also supports teamplay? As the leader role in one of the Co-Op games, i guided my teammates by placing 'Suppress this area' where the enemies were getting us from and telling everyone to stay back, take cover and kill as many of the bots before they overrun us. Now that was amazing.  As you can see with my 16 hours, i havent made it so far in the game but those hours were worth the $7.49 i got for this game. So what are you waiting for? Buy the game NOW or else the Insurgents will get you. ALLAH ACKBAR!

Feels like a nice mix of Red Orchestra, ArmA and Counter Strike. A particually nice tactical shooter with, from what I've seen, a decent enough community.  It isn't the most realistic gaming experience in the world, but it is a particually immersive hardcore shooter. It misses aspects of realism found in other games such as ArmA 2 with ACE or ArmA 3 with AGM or various realism mods, but compared to Counter Strike, Call of Duty and similar arcade games? It's fairly realistic.  Haven't put too many hours into the game, just a couple of rounds so I will tend to this review in the future and go into more detail; haven't got round to trying the latest (FREE!) DLC either.

Insurgency is the game I always want to play. I've tried the free weekend version and I enjoyed it. So, when it's on sale, I decided to buy the 4-pack edition of the game so I can play with my friends. I never regret it at all.  Insurgency is all about teamwork, communication and pure combat skills. When you play this game for the first time, it's a breath of pure fresh air. It makes you feel like you're in real combat with adrenaline pump in all over your body.This game also feautures realistic damage, where one shot to the chest may kill you instantly, with no-kill cam whatsoever. It features multiple gamemodes and all of them requires good team coordination! Like CO-OP for example, bots are not really smart but the weapon damage bots have is the same to us, that's why they're deadly even if they are not smart. Also, the multiplayer is pure teamwork to win. There are normal gamemodes like Firefight and also interesting gamemodes like Infiltrate too.  The best part of it though, is, the workshop. I downloaded more than 20 workshop contents, like the ACR carbine, CompM4 RDS, DEVGRU uniforms and so on! There are plenty to download thanks to the great Insurgency community. However, original in-game contents are also good but workshop just adds customisation up a bit.  The downsides I found to be annoying (All in PVP gamemodes), are corner camping, like any player can basically just lay down behind a corner and just shoot you with ease when you round the corner or push in a building, however, they can be countered with good crosshair positioning and explosives. So about, explosives, they can be spammed in tight areas, which most of them are objective zones, like a house with a capture point, for example, if you're capturing it, be ready for multiple 10-meter damage radius grenades that will fly into the zone.  My conclusion is that, buy it now, realistic and hardcore FPS fans would love this game. There are tactical and realistic elements like Arma, mixed with medium paced action and objective teamplay like Battlefield. However, there are some annoying exploits or gameplay problems in PVP gamemodes but it's not game breaking. There is also a workshop full of usable in-game community items to use with too! 8.5/10

Insurgency is a fun and addicting semi-realistic FPS, with a prominent focus on teamwork. It basically has it all; Good graphics, intense gameplay, large selection of maps, etc.    Insurgency adds realistic elements to the gameplay, including limited hud, no killcams, reduced ability of the player to survive multiple gunshot wounds, etc.    It is quite an intense game. The feeling of adrenaline you get when you're pinned down by enemy fire, trying your best to stay alive is what makes this game truly shine. Now, what it lacks in quantity it makes up for in quality. There aren't a  whole   lot of weapons, but the game makes up for that in the quality of them. Most guns (excluding the sniper rifles and pistols) have the option of changing their fire mode. Usually the choices are Semi, Burst, and Auto, so you can choose whichever works best for you.    Since Insurgency is semi-realistic, you the player can die in just a blink of an eye. It only takes 2-3 shots and you're dead. It only takes one stray RPG rocket to take you and your whole team out. In this game, you are not a walking tank that games like Call of Duty make you out to be. In order to survive, you need to work with your teammates to finish the mission.    The game's Online community is usually pretty active, so you shouldn't have too much trouble finding some teammates to pair up with. In general, if you're a fan of games like ArmA and Rainbow Six, definitely check this game out.   Pros:  - Good graphics - Large variety of maps - Semi-Realistic gameplay - Active community  Cons: - Can be frustrating, especially if playing by yourself - Rather small selection of weapons  Final Rating: 8.5/10

If there is any game out there I would pay full price is this. Its challenging, fun and so ♥♥♥♥ing inmersive, without going over the top with silly realism like the ARMA series. Its something like 'arcade-simulator', that meaning it isn't so realistic about the physics (there isn't bullet drop, ie), but you will need some patience, focus and timing to master the tactics and movements of your platoon. Works better if you play it with friends, and VoIP is a must.  There are several modes in both PvP and PvE, and the community & developers behind this game are amazing. Running on Source, is a little bit outdated, but still holds his own ground against recently shooters, specially in the replay factor.  10/10 Best arcade tactical shooter ever. Would Allahu akbar again.  -  Si hay algun juego por ahí por el cual pagaría precio completo, sería este. Es divertido, desafiante e inmersivo, sin irse al carajo con el realismo frutero de la serie ARMA. Sería más bien como un 'simulador arcade', ya que no es tan estricto con la fisica (no hay bullet drop, por ejemplo), pero tendrás que tener paciencia, concentración y timing para agarrarle la mano a las tácticas y los movimientos de tu pelotón. Se disfruta más jugando entre amigos y la comunicación por VoIP es casi estrictamente necesaria.  Hay varios modos tanto en Jugador contra Jugador como en Jugador contra el entorno (el modo cooperativo soporta hasta 8 jugadores en simultaneos contra la IA), y la comunidad y los desarrolladores detrás de este juego son geniales. Corriendo en Source, el juego está un poco pasado, pero se defiende bastante respecto a otros juegos del género, sobre todo en la rejugabilidad.  10/10 Excelente shooter táctico arcade.

Rank:  8.5/10  Recommendation(s):  Play Counter-Strike and Battlefield Bad Company 2.  Major Theme:  If Valve was to design Battlefield and release it on Steam.  Bought at Price:  $0 - gifted by friend through Humble Bundle  I'm a huge fan of Source powered titles — even more so of mods going pro. Insurgency is yet another title like that of Contagion, but steps up to the plate ready and focused.  I played the original source mod way back when, and said this looked cool. It wasn't my taste back then as I found it too hard. There were some neat features, but that was it.  When the whole Battlefield/EA thing with Valve happened, I gave up on the series and haven't looked back. It's the classic milking the cash cow with Origin. The sad part is I still wished something like Battlefield would come along again. EA even wondered why Battlefield Bad Company 2 did so well (hint: it was the last title they cared about and put on Steam).  This is exactly what the developers of Insurgency do right. They care about their game, and take care of it. They push updates out for free, and don't try to nickel and dime you. You can see a lot of Valve's philosophies in this title yet Valve didn't have anything really to do with this game.  Released on the 'Portal 2' branch, this title does provide some solid looking graphics, yet isn't leading in any form. Players will focus more about the game mechanics in this game rather than the looks.   The gameplay is slow, yet fast. While you are almost encouraged to camp, there are benefits in rushing. Taking place in both wide open maps and urban towns and cities, you will feel naked sometimes.  Unlike Battlefield Bad Company 2 – the closest title which I can compare to – there's no dog tags, bonus pins and all that. It's more hardcore then Battlefield in many ways yet isn't as realistic. To my big disappointment, there's no blowing up buildings in this game.  Overall, Insurgency has filled the missing gap in my library. I’ve longed for a good title to put my money in to for a while now and this is the game.

What Other Shooters Should Be Aiming For   I remember when COD:BO came out, I was a fan of the hardcore and barebones game modes. There was no option to play hardcore barebones though. You had to choose between one or the other. I remember thinking, 'wouldn't it be nice if they had a hardcore barebones game mode'. Even though this game has weapon attatchments, this for me is as close as it gets. With kills taking only 1-2 shots from your mag, it feels almost more like a paintball game in comparison to other shooters i've played. The guns in insurgency feel and sound great too. Gun fights are intense in the sense that you have no hit markers and no way to tell if you killed the person other than a visual confirmation. So popping your head out for that second look could mean death, or that you're clear to advance. Something else thats nice about this game is that the   rich don't get richer  . Unlike most other popular shooters, there is no leveling system to unlock guns/attachments and increase character stats. And for ingame there are no killsteaks. This is a game that focuses more on the core game mechanics than visual polish. In short, if you are looking for a shooter that has a realistic feel and is tactical, i highly recommend this game.

There was one time I ran up to enemy weapon cache with ICD in my hands, ready to blow it up to hell. And as I dashed through the final door, the dreadful display was before me - five, maybe even ten outlanders, armored, armed to the teeth, all standing before me looking at me confused in their surprise, as if I caught them off-guard. I waste no time though, and instantly throw ICD at them, and after it flew over a short arc, it landed by the cache, just before them - but also just before me. There was no time to run away, not even to pray, and as I shouted to the mic 'ALLAHU AKBAR' I pulled out the cell phone, receiving rain of enemy bullets and hoping I can last just long enough to push 'call' button - and so I did. I sacrificed my only life but that wasn't in vain, victory was ours and my name will be remembered by my brothers.  9/11 would jihad again.

Insurgency combines the tactical gameplay of games like ARMA with the seriousness of death of games like Counter-Strike, except at a slightly faster pace. If you like the tactical feeling of those games, but hated the long periods of waiting in ARMA and the huge skill gap in Counter-Strike because of lack of iron sights, then you'll probably find Insurgency fun.  Working with your team is important, and you'll find that many players have mics ready to go, either over TS or the in-game VOIP.   The game's graphics aren't amazing, but the sound quality and voice acting is excellent, and they devs have done wonderful things with the particle effects. Muzzle flashes and sparks from impacts are really pretty, and the smoke that drifts from gun barrels after firing are a nice touch. Dust and smoke kick up from bullet impacts, which can obscure your vision and hinder you as much as the suppression system (similar to Battlefield 3-4) does.  There are a variety of gamemodes to play: online PvP, online co-op, and offline singleplayer matches against bots. The PvP gamemodes are similar to Battlefield's Rush mode and CoD's Search and Destroy, but the respawning is limited to waves or objective captures, similar to Red Orchestra 2. Co-op is a ton of fun, very similar to ARMA's Domination mode, but on a smaller scale. You can't just rush in and kill everything, you need to take it slow and communicate, or the AI will take you apart. There are several co-op mission types as well, Checkpoint being the best among them in my opinion.  The AI is better than ARMA II's, and they're decent shots to the point where they don't have to overwhelm you with numbers in order to kill you. Death happens very quickly, like in ARMA, where one bullet to the head or with a heavier weapon and two bullets from most other weapons will kill you instantly. On higher difficulties the AI becomes more numerous and even scarier shots, even better than another player would be. They lack the ability to move like a player does in terms of peeking and use of cover, but they're not the mindless robots of ARMA II's NPCs.  There's no HUD whatsoever, apart from indicators on your teammates within a certain distance, objective labels, and the number of magazines you have remaining for your equipped weapon. You have no way of knowing how many bullets are in the magazine unless you count the rounds as you fire them, which I think is a nice touch of realism. I would have preferred a Red Orchestra 2 style of things, where you could hold 'R' to check the magazine and get a general idea of how full it is, but this works nicely as well.  The game also remembers whether or not you have a round chambered - as you spawn you can reload most magazine-fed weapons to get a 30+1 ammo count.  The class system is a little annoying. You can customize your loadouts with the Supply system, which gives you a certain amount of points to spend on gear, which I think is cool, but each class only has access to a limited pool of primary weapons and equipment, and the class names are not clear on which one has what. Furthermore, the names are different depending on whether or you're playing Security or Insurgents, which only adds to the confusion. I figured out which classes had which weapons more through trial and error than anything else. Also, your squad only has a limited number of roles. If someone's taken the Support gunner slot in your squad, you'll have to switch to another squad in order to be their Support, again similar to RO2's system. It works well to balance things in PVP, I find, but it also means that if you're stuck with a crappy player in an important role your experience may suffer.  All in all, if you like the tactical gameplay of ARMA and Counter-Strike, working with teammates, and prefer iron sights and scopes to the lack thereof in CS, then you will definitely enjoy this game.   Population is around 4,500 every time I've logged on, and there are plenty of servers, At the time of writing Insurgency is in the Humble Bundle along with three extra copies, so that could be why so many people are on, but the game is definitely not dead. The devs also release free content updates from time to time, which means more things to do and more weapons to use at no extra cost.  However, if you get upset easily and can't handle dying suddenly and frequently, you may not find this game enjoyable. It's really not a complicated game, easy to pick up and play, and once you've done the training mission and played a few gamemodes you're basically ready to go, but you will get suddenly killed from long range quite often until you learn to use cover properly. Most of the players I've come across tend to be older, as well, as this sort of game doesn't generally appeal to younger players, which vastly improves your experience as far as I'm concerned.  I got this game for free as part of the Humble Bundle deal, but I feel that it's totally worth the regular $15 price tag.

I've had so much fun playing this, but I just deleted it. The gunplay is amazing, the scope sway and rifle kick are proper, and the netcode is optimized to prevent bs things from occuring. It's challenging, and unforgiving, and I really like those aspects as it's what kept me going back to it. That and you can mod the hell out of it with all sorts of different optics, firearm models, audio packs, among many other things without breaking gameplay 'balance'. But I have had enough: The movement is awful. Worst in any FPS game I've ever played. See that little brick on the ground next to you? You will get stuck to it, for some reason your incompetent guy just can't seem to navigate around that brick, it's anchored to the ground and you're stuck to it like a fly in a spider's web. I've died so many times just bashing away at them mouse when an enemy is right in front of me but I can't shoot because I'm in the middle of changing stance and apparently the guy I'm playing as is too mentally deficient to process pulling a trigger while getting his ♥♥♥ off the ground. Your mentally slow character limits how well you can channel your skill into performance. That limit doesn't exist when you're aiming and shooting, but movement is SO clumsy. An FPS game with awful movement mechanics becomes an arcade shooter except instead of a plastic gun you get a mouse and keyboard. Once you know the map, you start to do really well, and the game shines. Once you know all the spawnkilling locations, you start to do TOO WELL, and the game is ruined. I can't tell you how many times I've played through a whole game and just can't get out of spawn because an RPG flew into it, or C4 was planted right in front of everyone, or just some guy lying prone in a hall of death. It's non-stop dying until the match is over-no fun at all. Supposedly all of the problems should be solved when everyone can vote for whatever they want. Want to change the next map to XYZ? No problem. Want to kick player XYZ for being afk or excessive teamkilling? No problem. Want to kick another player on the other team for spawn-killing your team? Oh you can't do that, because that would be broken. You could kick the entire other team this way. This democratic system is completely dumb, even if someone is breaking server rules and spawnkilling the other team on your team, nobody is going to votekick them. That guy is the best person on the team, denying the opposing team any sort of action to attack or defend an objective, so nobody except for the nonexistent moderators will try to get them kicked. I'm not going to lie, I found myself sometimes being that ♥♥♥♥ in the corner gunning down unwary folks running out of spawn, and every time I hate myself afterwards for doing it even if my team rejoices after winning and complements me. It feels sickly wrong. How could I forget to mention, that some of the maps are FAR from balanced. Yes it's a difficult job to balance each and every map in the game, but it's absolutely crucial in order for the game to have any chance of being fun. For example, on Seige, if you're insurgent and you sit in A and hold that one position behind c4-proof cover, you win the match. If you're defending B on Dry Canal, just get to the rooftops and camp. Buhriz, Sinjar, Dry Canal, and Panj are awful on Push, if you're attacking and your team doesn't know how to use smoke, you're either going to do the smart thing and sit in the back and not play the objective, or you're going to be used as a meat shield. Because of the voting system, those maps will ALWAYS be picked by people who want nothing more than easy kills and wins. It's not to say however that you will always lose if you're on the wrong side, rarely you will find yourself on a team that knows how to use smokes and how to clear objectives with explosives. It's such a gratifying experience to play on that kind of team, but particularly rare. I will not advise this game to anyone, sure it's cheap as dirt and it's a full-featured multiplayer game, but it's not worth the endless frustration you invest into a game where everywhere where you turn you will be stuck on a pixel, be given an explosive dental treatment every other time you spawn, and have your vote never matter because it will always be overturned by a stupid majority of players who think every damn game is TDM. The mechanics of this game are so easily abused, there is good incentive to abuse them, and although the developers actually adhere to feedback from the community, they don't address fundamental flaws. Seeing as progress is kind of slow, I will reinstall this game in one year and see if I can be proven wrong. I really want to be proven wrong.

This is a game where you really HAVE TO do the objective, this isn't CoD like: Camp, kill, camp, kill, get good K:D. No, in this game you do the objective and kill enemies that are trying to prevent you to do the objective. You have to choose wisely your weaponry for close combat or long range engagements. Remeber that wearing kevlar and ammo will make you more heavier and make you more slower. So choose wise, heavy gear might not be good when you are stealing a objective and light gear might not be good while defending you last position.  AIM! hipfire is just for noobs that don't know what is right mouse button. Scopes are useful in long range engagements but in a small room Red Dot scope might be useful, but best is the iron sights. They will never let you down. Also remeber that small firearms ex. Submachine guns, shotguns, pistols are useful in close combat but when you need range it is time to pick up that assault rifle. Same goes for LMGs. LMGs are made for support and should be used for covering your own troops and keeping enemy heads down. Remember to duck when you load LMGs because enemies snipe you down easily while you load.  Remeber to carry molotovs or explosives while your playing flashpoint. It is important that blow up those targets because your teammates aren't always there to help you. Always carry atleast two because your first try might not hit. Also remeber that when you take explosives you lose equipment points so choose wisely what gun and what attachtments you take with you. Also sidearm can safe yourlife so always keep your pistol with you. 'It is faster to switch to your side arm than reloading' - Cpt. Price

It's a very difficult game that triumphs in skill and practice, but hey, isn't that so with every other multiplayer game?  Insurgency is a very realistic multiplayer FPS that makes every shot in the dark (sometimes literally) to make this game hardcore and real. You can take weapons available for your selected role in the team and customize them with attachments to make them easier to handle and deadlier to use. Every shot counts and getting hit will most likely mean your death, as a ton of the weapons deal high damage and all can be equipped with armor penetration rounds to make kills easier. There are even missions in the night, forcing you to use flashlights and night vision goggles to keep you aware of your surroundings.  Getting kills in this game is incredibly satisfying, because the weapons do so much damage, and you know that you got that kill because you outsmarted and outplayed the people that try to threaten the progress of your team. It's also rewarding to defend objectives, because a single person can single-handedly hold a chokepoint crucial to the other team's success, granted you can get past any of the smokes and grenades the enemy team throws down.  If you're the kind that has the patience to practice and adopt to high skill ceilings, then this game is definately for you.

A awesome multiplayer tactical shooter that requires teamwork or a rambo player that gets the drop on the enemy. If your looking for a singleplayer game this isn't it, it's mainly built for online and contains a lot of maps and modes to keep you busy. It has:  1. Classes (join one of the two squads, both contains different classes such as support or sniper which also contain different equipment)  2.Modes (want to play against a.i then join coop where there is mission based or just pure horde mode facing waves of enemies. If your wanting pvp then join the many modes of pvp such as siege where one team defends objectives and the other attack or play capture the flag or capture zones forcing players to work together to protect their bases.   3. Death changes everything (every mode contains 'reinforcements' however these reinforcements are limited so if you die your out until the next wave comes in meaning your team will be short a few soldiers until the reinforcement wave timer counts down to 0 spawning your fallen teammates back into the fight...just watch out spawns are limited so if your team uses the waves up then it's left to your remaining forces against whatever is left on the enemy side)  4. Teamwork is required ( this game isn't about running around blasting away...well it is sort of. But with your loadout some of your gear will weight you down changing how you move and how much damage you take. The game forces teamwork to get the job done...you need cover fire then get a support teammate to suppress that area...need a target sniped then work with the sniper members...need ammo cache destroyed then get your demo member in there. And with the spawns set on a timer and limited it makes each member important because when you run out it becomes a nightmare especially if the other team still has a lot more reinforcement spawns left)   Overall it's a great online shooter for those wanting a change from counter strike or Day of Defeat and really want a game based around working together.

This game combines some of the best elements of the various popular shooters, and adds a whole host of realism to boot. It is the first game that I've played in years that feels like one of the older mid-2000s shooters, like CoD1-2 (except modern, obviously). The gameplay is fast-paced yet tactical. Patience and accuracy are king, and rushing rarely gets you anything. It's not always a one shot kill, but it often is, so be careful. While body armor may save your life, if you are playing carelessly, you won't do well. But at the same time, almost all the game modes have some sort of control point capturing system, so if you sit back and camp, you won't be helping your team much. If you land on a team that happens to use comms, then it is a very fun experience.  The game modes are all fairly similar, but each has their own unique elements. There are only one or two game modes where a round can last for 10-20 minutes. If you die, you rarely sit on the sidelines for more than 30 seconds to a minute - you either respawn in that time, or the round ends. Most game modes require teams to capture and hold objectives, and your team gets rewarded for doing so with additional respawns. Run out of 'waves' and you will have a tough time coming back. The good thing about this system is that, if one team is much better than another, you aren't suffering through a 20 minute match getting spawn killed with no hope. The round will end, and then you can try again. All the game modes are pretty well-balanced, though. It's rare that one team will win all rounds on a map, and if they do, it's usually because they are communicating, not just because they are better.  You can customize your loadout by selecting between a number of primary weapons (depending on your class, but the class is much less restrictive than battlefield) and equipping a number of attachments. You can also select alternate weapons like explosives, a sidearm, or a chest carrier for more ammo and an extra grenade. The class and squad system allows certain weapons, but it's more like America's Army than BF. You can be a rifleman or a marksman or support, but that doesn't necessarily mean you have to select a certain weapon.  But my favorite thing about it is that, though it tracks your lifetime score and has achievements, there are no unlockables, no level bonuses, etc. All the attachments and weapons above are selected from a pool of supply points that you get at the start of each match. You may have 8 points, where a grenade is two points, a red dot sight is one point, body armor is two points, etc. Doing well at the game does not put you at an advantage by unlocking better items.  Additionally, and also uncommon and underrated these days, is that each side has its own types of weapons. Security forces use US/NATO weapons - M16, M4, M249, etc - and Insurgents use common militant weapons - AK47 or 74, RPG, etc. You can't just use the same weapon every game like you can in other shooters, so it adds another element of strategy.
