A modernized Red Orchestra with smaller maps. Most of the maps are amazing. However the problem with the maps is that the community seems to vote for the same 3 or 4 maps so there isn't going to be a lot of map variety (or at least there isn't in my time of playing). The guns are great and are even better if you download an enhanced Insurgency sound pack. One or two shots and the enemy is down, you won't have to worry about wasting your ammo... unless you're on full auto, that sh*t is hard to control at med-long ranges. There aren't very many weapons to choose from however but I've heard from the developers that they're working on new weapons.  The community is... strange, to say the least. Haven't come across too many problems in regards to people mic spamming and trolling. A quick vote kick will change that even if you do come across a mic spammer.  I'd recommend this game to anyone who loves first person shooters. It's slow paced, so don't go expecting to sprint around the map and spray the crap out of the enemy because you will die. It's easy to adjust to so don't let that 'slow paced tactical realism' description turn you away.   7.5/10

'Charlie has been taken over by the enemy, head to Charlie, I'll secure Alpha and provide cover fire..' You slowly head to Charlie, peak around the corner with the tip of your gun and you see noone. As you get closer they suddenly start to fire at you from a window, you sprint to a pillar closeby and take cover. While hiding for your life you communicate to the other teammembers telling there's a guy in the window close to you. Another teammember happens to be in that building and quickly clears every room taking the guy out. You move from cover to cover towards objective Charlie and as you arrive you spot 2 enemy reinforcements incoming from the other side. The other teammate from before has now taken position at the window and snipes one of the enemies. The other sprints inside a building where suddenly gunshots can be heard, he killed one of your other teammates. You have almost captured objective Charlie which is needed to win the game as you have conquered all the objective zones... As you look around for the last time you see that the capturing has stopped, the enemy is closeby. You check your ammo for your primary rifle and notice it's empty, you take out your sidearm and toss a flashbang at the other side of your cover. As it goes off you rush in, see the enemy all blinded and shoot him twice through the chest. It's a victory.   This is what a game of Insurgency can be like, its amazing.

I was surprised by insurgency when I purchased it during the recent halloween sale at how enjoyable it is. I am a fan of realistic first person shooters like red orchastra/rising sun (if you know those titles you'll understand when you play this) but wanted a more modern setting and I found it here. Insurgency is a good solid, realistic, team based game, where lone wolves will get picked off as well as those that run and gun.  The graphics are reasonable for a game I believe started life as a mod with well designed and put together environments. There are also a ton of maps, but like many games, after each match you get to pick the next one so you might keep seeing the same ones often. Game types are plentiful but I can not elaborate to much on those as I have only played push. As for music to me it sounds a bit like it is from the transformers movies but when I mentioned this everyone just wrote 'lol' in side chat.  The weapons are fantastic and you have access to them all from the beginning with no time spent to unlock the rifle to beat them all if you catch my drift. The weapons you use during the game depend on the class you pick though meaning be quick to get your choice in if you want the sub machine guns or sniper rifles. Weapons have a good feel about them when in use, the recoil is good and the sounds are almost spot on with brilliant textures.   The only annoying factor with insurgency and I will quote another reviewer here, 'I played so well that ISIS tried to recruit me' this game is strangely plagued with people who scream 'allah akbar' whether in jest or not if you are easily offended just mute people like I do and don't get involved. It can get loud but I have not witnessed any racism. I have not played long at the point of writing this but I have played enough to include this in my review as a warning.  To sum up Insurgency it is for mature players that are looking for a solid team-focused and realistic game with decent weapons, plenty of maps and is able to fufill that strange phenomenon that all gamers posses and thats shooting each other in the face for enjoyment.  Thumbs up and highly recommended. If you think the price is steep just think you'll probably spend three times as much on call of duty advanced warfare and really you only go there for the multiplayer anyway and from what I have heard it doesnt even work ;) (no surprise there then)  +There are also mods for this game that change weapon textures and adds maps ++Smoke is yours and those that are around you's friend, that is including the enemies who might manuever to out flank you!

This is the best FPS I've played to date. Don't mistake it for not being a twitch shooter, because it is. Insurgency makes the perfect balance between fast paced arcade shooters and hardcore tactical shooters. Think of it like a mix of Counter Strike and Project Reality. The maps are relatively small but they're very well done and balanced. Many different and some unique gamemodes helps to keep gameplay varied and interesting. The best part of this game is the hardcore approach to the HUD and what information that is passed to the player. You don't have any hit or kill markers, no score/xp pop ups, no medals or ribbons, no health bar, no crosshair, no minimap, no killstreaks. You probably get the idea.
If your looking for a REALISTIC fps, then this game is for you.

Dear Steam Users,  Insurgency is a one of a kind game that provides a realistic approach to modern warfare. The game is the perfect balance of realism without being too technical or 'advanced' for the average FPS player. You get intense firefights following the most suspenseful moments, a picture perfect representation of really being in a warzone. Insurgency submerses the player with stunning visuals and amazing sounds that makes it a one of kind game that deserves a spot on everyone's computer.

Tired of FPS shooters that hold your hand? Is Call of Duty making you lose faith in anything FPS?  Well, ♥♥♥♥ that peice of ♥♥♥♥. Insurgency is here to save the day.  I've been part of the Insurgency community for a number of years now, well into the establishment of the first HL2 mod up until this point. While it is a generic 'Press buttan shoot badguy' first person shooter in the long run, the game offers far much more than CoD/CS/Whatever has to offer.   If you've played any of the Red Orchestra games, you'll be quite familiar with how this one plays. With a focus on realism, there is no crosshair in th center of the screen, instead the weapons muzzle will drift along with the movement of your mouse. Iron sights, or optics are essential for accurate fire, as well as an understanding of controlling automatic fire. This game will keep you on your toes corridor to corridor with much to offer.

The full fledged Insurgency game is vastly superior to its old MOD counter-part. With improved graphics, much better voice acting, more game modes, weapons, weapon customization, co-op missions, bots, better sound effects, it's defintely worth getting if you were a fan of the original Insurgency Mod.  The best way I could describe it is Battlefield meets Red Orchestra.  You will never know true fear until you've thought you were safe, the battlefield is eerily quiet and then you hear your squad member shout 'OH ♥♥♥♥, RPG!!!'  That's often the last thing you hear.

Insurgency has pretty much found the perfect balance between realism and fun. All of the game modes force the players to coordinate as a team and approach tactically if they wish to come out victorious. The way the weapons handle, the rather slow movement speed, especially when moving backwards and sideways, and the fact that it generally only takes one or two bullets to stop anyone, makes it obvious that this is a game about out-smarting, rather than out-gunning.  The above in combination with the generally rather menacing atmosphere of the levels makes Insurgency a really immersive experience which keeps you constantly on edge.   It also has some of the best feeling and sounding weapons I've used in a game.

I like this shooter very much. Another 8/10 game. Here is a quick list for those who are considering this game. 1. The price is right for this quality game. 2. The movements of people and reaction to objects feels really good, quite realistic and changes with the amount of weight you are packing. I also liked the little movements like leaning, sliding and jumping. 3. The weapon sounds are top notch! When you are firing the shot gun, it really sounds and behaves like a shot gun. I was really impressed with the high frequency 'ring' that comes out of the guns. Anyone who fires rifles and shotgunsrecognise that they recorded and recreated a fuller spectrum of a guns noise. 4. Really good enviormental sounds. When you walk through water, broken glass, dry ground, grass, it all sounds different. 5. Great maps. Not too small, not too big. Tons and tons of little enviormental models, clutter, doors that operated, windows that break, garbage that you can hide in. 6. Really good terrain. Holes, craters, ditches, broken walls ect. Even when out in the open there is still some level of cover. Also great detail for buildings, most enterable with several floors and windows for shooting out of. They are aranged in a way that makes sense. Not meant to either force or limit a choke point. It allows you to play the way you want to. 7. The 3D proximity voip. I love all games that have this, and this one does it really well. 8. The game modes are awsome, competitve and makes sense. It's a great compramise between repawn and knock out shooters. Camp if you want to, but if you do it will most likely cost you the match because objectives count and if you let your enemy complete them it grants them 'waves' of respawns. 9. Mininmalistic HUD that can be customized. I like games that are as sim as possible. You still have access to all the info you need, but when you want to see it, not in your face. 10. Personality! The game has lots of personality. When a buddy gets hit, he screams like someone who has just learned what it is to have hot bullets enter his body! The rag doll is pretty good. The animations are also pretty good in general. 11. Great weapon options! Plenty of kit choices, but not over the top. Great looking scopes, and realistic scope to eye time. Anyone who has ever put a scope to their eye will enjoy this. It's not instant. Also I loved the flashlights, they look really good, illuminate realisticly and are somewhat blinding if you are looking right into one. I can't go on enough anout how fun it was to be a masked bartender serving up Molotov coctalls to some thirsty PMC nerds camping in a window. Bottoms up! 12. The game runs great. I had few issues with it. in 7 hours play I had 2 freezes that recovered quickly. 13. The game looks good, but not so good that it smashes your GPU and runs like a slide show. All the important stuff is there. Good shadows, good animations, realistic smoke and fire (even ambient fire hurts), glass shatter animations. Also it sounds good all around, not just the guns as I mentioned before. 14. Throwing mo;otovs on security gaurds. I mentioned it before, but it bares repeating.  I really don't have any cons worth mentioning. New maps seem to be being added all the time, and there are already many. I liked every map I played so far. There are lots of players, lots of servers and this game has alot of life to give. If you love shooters, then this is a must have. It dosnt matter if you are into arcady or simulator because this game offers the best of both and everything in the middle. I get the feeling like the devs are really into playing shooters and decided to take the best parts of all the best shooters and forge 1 complete game that gives the server host all the options they need to find their particular sweet spot in options. For me this game has the one quality that is just an abosulte must. FUN. This game is really fun to play.

THIS GAME IS INCREDIBLE!!! I've never seen a game this realstic and reliant on teamwork that also manages to be incredibly fun and engaging. If ARMA is a bit too much for you yet you want that realistic FPS experience, then look no further. Without doubt, one of the best shooters i've played this year.  Don't mistake it for another generic military FPS-Insurgency is one of the most unforgiving shooters i've ever played. No hitmarkers, killfeed or minimap mean: -You'll never know where the enemy team is (and spotting only marks their last known position) -You'll never know if you killed somebody unless you saw for yourself. -You'll never know who killed you or where from. Weapons also deal realistic amounts of damage, so dont expect to survive more than a few rounds. The solo run-and-gun playstyle common in many FPS's won't work in Insurgency. If you want to stay alive and complete the objective, you almost always require teamwork.  And thanks to well-done sounds such as gunfire and richocheting bullets, it's also incredibly intense.  Visually, it may not compare to larger AAA titles, but for a source engine game, it looks fantastic.  All i could possibly complain about is the small number of maps. This, however, is being resolved quickly with free content updates every few months.

The game is a very unique one. It is realistic, tactical, but unlike other 'competitors', such as the ArmA series, it is also very FAST PACED. Insurgency is a realistic, tactical FPS that distinguishes itself from the modern hollywood action FPS's which overpopulate the genre today. If you're inside a building and go running up the stairs with a knife, expecting to get rewarded for your rambo tactics...you die. If you fail to use cover and peek around corners, you die. If you think you can single-handedly go against five enemies without the faintest support from your team, you die.   Insurgency rewards those who use teamwork, communication, and sound tactics. If you're strictly a CoD or BF player, you most likely will not enjoy this game. However, if you're looking for a realistic shooter and don't mind a bit of a learning curve, then this game could be a great experience. And with a dedicated multiplayer crowd, it shows every indication of being around for a good while.   Insurgency flows through the same vein as the shooters I grew up with on PC (Delta Force, Ghost Recon). It's refreshing to be back at home with this great indie game. Highly recommended!!

Insurgency has potential. I've played it in its original mod form from time to time and always had good things to say about it. I saw they released a standalone version and decided to take the plunge. For the price, I am very satisfied. The game itself blends elements of some well known FPS titles, i.e weapon customization, variety of well known game modes, etc. with Insurgency's own twist. The difference from other titles is gameplay. Think hardcore mode from Call of Duty (a couple of shots kill you, no standard crosshair, only iron sights for precise aiming, etc.) with more emphasis on teamwork, thanks to a variety of classes to choose and customize according to mission objectives, and built in VOIP support. This allows for some very fast paced and intense gameplay as you have to work with your team to capture/defend objectives, destroy/defend weapon caches, etc.   There is also a co-op mode which adds another dimension and pits you against swarms of AI that you have attack and defend against, according to your missions parameters. This makes for a welcome diversion from PVP and can help hone your skills and try out some class configurations.   I only hope that Insurgency team takes the approach of releasing new free content to expand the original game (more maps, weapons + attachments) as well as purchaseable DLCs. DLCs that include more maps, teams (i.e NATO countries, eastern european countries, Russia, Chechnya, etc. etc.) and associated weapons and attachments would give this game immense replayability and ensure healthy community growth for years to come.   As a stand alone game, I would recommend Insurgency to those looking for something more tactical than CoD or CS:S. I think the Insurgency team are on to a winner and once they iron out a few kinks and make some optimizations for gameplay, and provided they spice this game up with free and purchaseable DLC content, this game has potential to become a must have title for years to come.

So far I've really enjoyed my time with Insurgency overall, but I've had a specifically fun time playing the co-op missions. It feels similar to Terrorist Hunt from the Rainbow Six games, but with actual objectives besides just 'kill the enemies.' Co-op requires a lot of teamwork, and it's in this mode that I've had the best social interactions as well. In a lot of standard multiplayer matches you will often have people not talking at all, whether that's because they're all talking on Skype or some other VOIP service, I dunno, but it seems like people are happy just running around on their own. That's not to say the multiplayer isn't awesome, because it is, I'm just saying that co-op is especially great. So if you're looking for a fun co-op game, I definitely recommend the game on the merits of that game mode alone.

Insurgency is a fantastic game that appeals to those who are fans of the CounterStrike series. I have always favored tactical shooters over ones that encourage induvidual performance over team performance. Despite a few minor bugs (the floating guns being one of them), the game performs very well and the graphics are quite nice. There are many different game modes to choose from but all of them force you to appreciate the value of your life due to the amount of time you'll spend waiting to respawn or start a new round when you first start playing.   It does take a while to learn the maps and figure out where everyone loves to hide out and there isn't a killcam so don't get discouraged if you die constantly at first from unknown locations. There are not as many people playing this game as I would hope but there are a handful of active servers to play on that almost always have between 20 and 30 people online at any given time. I would recommend using the server browser to find a server that you like rather than the automated server selection system.   I could see the community growing for this game especially if there is a regular release of content to keep players interested as well as the addition of some kind of induvidual player progression. I play on a server with a ranking system which is more than enough to keep me interested but I imagine that most players will want some kind of progression so they feel as though they are working towards something while playing the game.   In conclusion, I'd say this game is a great alternative to CounterStrike: Global Offensive that offers a refreshing take on tactical shooters. Remember, communication is paramount to success in this game. Work with your team and you'll have a blast playing this game.

After debating between this game and Counterstrike, I decided on this and am happy with my purchase. It's a pretty straight forward first person shooter. It's very similar to many popular titles, but ditches the bells-n-whistles; no micro-transactions, no story mode, no superior upgrades based on rank, minimum HUD, minimum perks, no vehicles. Getting rid of those brings more focus on the actual gun fights, which is more entertaining in my opinion. Matchmaking is abundant, game modes are plentiful, objectives are clear, and competition is fair. Choose a server, pick a team, assign your role, and decide your loadout, all whilst being immersed in an intense firefight; nothing more, nothing less. Only regret is not getting the 4-pack for my friends to join. Only compaint; it didn't automatically detect my video settings and would blue screen at startup (fix was to use launch parameter '-window' to change the full screen resolution).

I've put off writing a review for a long time, but today is a good day to finally write one. Think of where to start is hard, but i think the combat is as good a place. from the wide range of class on both sides many of the same guns will be in them, for example the ak-47, ak-74, m16, and m4a1, are found in almost all except for the sniper and recon classes. This isn't bad mind you because each are good gun, and the other guns in those classes are fun to play with as well, but clearly these are the guns that will be present on the battlefield the most. the suppression and damage mechanics make sense, usaully if you are pinned down with fire your screen becomes fuzzy, and if you are hut once or maybe twice, you are going to die. Recoil is realistic, aiming makes sense, and if you have a good reaction time you can hit what you shoot at. The community is what give this game such good memories in my mind though. When I first got picked up to play in this games upstart competitive tourny system I was a bit, how do I phrase it, ♥♥♥♥♥♥. The more i played with my team mates, the better I became. By the time our team broke up due to disaggrements with the DGL I was still not great, but i had clearly become better. I made many friends who I still talk too, and game with regularly a year and a half later. People that play the game today are for the most part very chill and very rarely will you get some asshat that comes into a go and starts ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ people off, which is nice to see. The dev team is also very cool, and if you ever get into a game with them you will figure out why I stated this. They bring fun updates every month or two, and manage to keep people interested in an amazing game.  So, I'd say if you are looking for a fun, cheap, team based game then insugency is the game for you.

Every Tuesdays and Thursdays I go to Sunny Brooks Clinic. I see this very nice lady in this very nice room. We talk about lots of things like 'how is your day going?' or 'how are the nightmares going?'. I have been seeing this lady every since I bought this game. I am diagnosed with Posttraumatic stress disorder, or PTSD for short. Every night is the same thing. I'm back playing Checkpoint on District with my friends. It was all fun when we were in the jeep on the way there. Dave bragged about how we had sex with this girl named Margret last night and we all laughed and joked all around. But as soon as we were out of the jeep, our feet landing on the soft dry sand. We move out as a unit. We see nothing at first but all of a sudden we are surrounded by Insurgents. Bill is the first to go down, a shot to the temple...quick. Phil was not so lucky. He was shot in the leg and fell onto his arm, broke it on impact. I still remember his screams. I couldnt react as I saw all my friends fall before me. Next thing I know I am liying on the ground, wet red blood splattered across my face and next to me is someones foot...no wait, my foot. The horror seeing the black burnt flesh of my own foot made me throw up. After I roll to my left and see Dave looking at me with these dead horrible seeing eyes. He's dead. I can bearly make out strange voices that I dont understand. Four men with turpens wrapped across their face hover over me and stare with their AK-47's pointed at my head. At this moment All I hear is a loud sharp pop and then everything goes white. This game scared me. I will probably never be the same. Dont play this game unless you like going to see a nice lady every other day.

Insurgency is a fun first-person multiplayer shooter. It attempts to blend the close-quarters combat of Counter-Strike and Call of Duty with a realism somewhere between Battlefield 2 and ArmA.  For the most part, I feel it does this job well. The wave system brings players back to the game (solving the Counter-Strike problem), yet still makes each life feel valuable, unlike other multiplayer FPS games.  As I'm not a weapons or military expert, I can't really attest to the realism of the weapons and gear on show or the general tactics and mechanics employed within the game, but it feels very much as it did on the original Insurgency mod.  I can highly recommend this game. However, the best experiences come if you find a decent server to play on with regulars. I'm not sure how many of the original maps made the cut into the release version of the game yet, but some of them are still pretty golden.

So you're making a stew. You take some Essence of Red Orchestra 1, Insurgency ( mod ), add some of the oldschool SWAT / Ghost recon type games. Then you let that ♥♥♥♥ simmer for a few years while the demand for a nice tactical shooter slowly grows. Enter Insurgency. Sure its a little rough around the edges still but theres the basis there for a very good game, the sounds are top notch, there's a good spread of playmodes and the maps are quite well ballanced. Also, I LOVE that there's no annoying leveling system which gives a massive benefit to leveled players. Weapon addon/selection works by giving you a set number of points, whether you choose to use those points on frag grenades, or armor peircing rounds for your weapon is up to you...  The graphics are nothing to write home about, but the weapon models are good, and the animations are also quite nice. I've had a few issues with hits not registering due to laggy servers / ping, so be warned that this game is currently VERY ping sensitive (as in try to play with a sub 100 ping).  If you're in the market for a smaller sized tactical shooter where 1-3 bullets will kill then insurgency may very well be for you.

Insurgency is a very atmospheric first-person-shooter that can only be truly described with one word:  Raw . This is just about the rawest form of an FPS game which you can get that is extremely realistic.

Insurgency is in its early phases, however at first viewing of it the game seems to shout out as one of the few realistic games, that are pickup and play. In that it does not intimidate with over-threatening control schemes or needlessly complex systems. Instead the game relies on its own realism to force the players on both sides to advance carefully, often together and slowly.  Its definately a game that would be suited to squad play, and the usage of smoke to block choke points etc is vital in certain situations, where what equipment one is armed with becomes vital. For example during one event I found myself pinned down in an alleyway by an enemy MG position, I threw a smoke grenade and ran AROUND the back of the alley, instead of rushing out. This was then followed by some super sneaky stealth stuff that made the navy seals look like clumsy junkies. After I'd made my secret flank thingy, I came up behind the Machine gunner who was deployed in a window, and took him out. This was followed by a rush of about 5 enemy troops from the next room who gunned me down within a half second of eliminating this MG. However thats the beauty of this game, it provides a rush and sense of satisfaction when you finally tag that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ wiping out half your team, and counter sniping is beautiful in and off itself, in short, its a game that should be on your top 10 buys this yaer.

Imagine if Red Orchestra 2, Call of Duty and Counter Strike had a little baby game and then that game grew up into a hard as nails, grizzled war veteran that will snap your neck with a flick of his wrist.  I bought this game at the start of the Steam sale and so far, I'm really enjoying it. It's made in the source engine so the netcode feels tight and the controls smooth. The graphics are surprisingly good thanks to some good texture work and character models and really nice use of HDR lighting. Stepping from a blinding sandy street into a darkened hovel is disorienting and scary as your eyes take a second to adjust.  The game has tonnes of different game modes but I've not played them all. I recommend Firefight if you are just starting out. In it there are three objectives. Each team starts with one and one is neutral. When you die you sit out but can respawn when an objective is secured by your team. You win by either killing all the enemy or (I think) securing all 3 objectives. The game is similar to CS in that there is no global unlock persistence but rather you earn supply points throughout a match that can be spent on weapon attachments, armour, explosives etc. At the end of the map cycle you start again with the base weapons.  It differs from Counter Strike though because the teams are split into a number of squads and each squad has a limited number of different class roles to be filled. Classes like Marksman, Sapper, Breacher each give you different starting load outs. I quite like this because it stops everyone from being the same class and generally stops the game getting dull with everyone being a sniper or whatever.  The gun mechanics are what really draw me to the game. They are similar to Red Orchestra with a small amount of float in the middle. It makes the weapons feel weighty and realistic and grounded in the game. In addition the game has lean, prone and a nifty cover system that automatically bumps your view up when looking over low cover through your iron sights.  It's an alpha but it's pretty stable. I've been dropped from the server a couple of times and it's frozen up when loading a map but so far no bugs of note at all.  The biggest issue with this game is the player count. It's actually grown quite a bit throughout the steam sale but there are still only a few players scattered across a few servers (it uses the Steam server browser which is a massive plus in my book). I've not yet had a problem getting into a busy server but I can see the play base disappearing if they don't get some publicity. They had a Kickstarter I believe but it didn't reach it's target - perhaps no one knew about it.  Anyway, I definitely recommend this game if you are interested in slightly more realistic military games with nice controls and no persistent unlocks.  [[EDIT]] The player count is looking a lot more healthy now with loads and loads of populated servers. Lets hope it stays that way.

Amazing game for $14.99! You can't beat it, it's a an awesome shooter that promotes teamwork, communication, and smart gameplay to get the objective completed. If you communicate (in-game or TS3,Vent) Insurgency is so much more enjoyable. There are a lot of groups out there who actively play, and communicate throughout each round. Don't get mad when you die, and don't care about your K/D (it doesn't get you anywhere in life). Work with your team/squad and you can easily win every game you play. Remember, you get more points for completing objectives, than you do for kills.  Stick with the game, and you will enjoy it in the end.

Insurgency is a realistic first person shooter,in which you can join an unknown American force or you join the Insurgents and proceed to spam the dobule A word in both voice chat and text chat and shoot your AKM's that you got for free into the air.  If you are tired of games that dont have sprinting or aiming down sights or any type of advanced movement *cough* CS:GO *cough*,and are looking for a more adrenaline pumping,heart racing game,buy this masterpiece. You can also download a WW2 mod on the workshop (you only get the americans and germans in the mod)  Weapon modifications are available,however are very limited. Optics,Ammo, and about 4 more parts can be modified. However,this game is all about the skill,not the shiniest and prettiest weapon.  As for armor,there is only Light and Heavy armor. If you dont wear armor,you die from a single shot from any gun to the chest in one shot. Light armor reduces the damage done to the stomach and chest by 60%,and the Heavy armor increases it to 90%.  tl;dr Dying Simulator 2016

You thought CS:GO was realistic: WTF, NO. You thought COD was realistic: NO You thought Battlefield was realistic: Maybe You thought Insurgency was realistic: HELL YES  Why? PROS- Well, first lets begin with the basics. Sniping is enjoyable, bullets kill people with one shot. 1 shot from a sub- machine gun can kill somebody. Grenades are actually your best item. You will spend half you life checking corners and running through smoke on the chance that you wont get shot. IED's and C4 absolutely blow up everything known to man. You will actually take a weapon off automatic to single fire to improve your aiming. Machine guns are OP especially the M249. Hip firing takes skill and last but not least you will get killed by an RPG repeatedly. There is no killcam, thank god. Not to mention, INSURGENT weapons are not as good AS SECURITY weapons because REALISM. You will kill your teamates especially with explosives, but most people are generally friendly about it. HIGH PINGS GET KICKED, TEAM KILLERS GET KICKED.   CONS- You will get spawn camped but that is actually your team's fault for dying, abnoxious teammates that yell ALLAHU AKBAR or ALOHA SNACKBAR or every known interpretation of the saying all the time. That one RPG or AT4 that will kill everyone on your team ( Then annoying ALLAHU AKBAR all over mic). You will play with teamates who just play it like it's COD (People don't absorb bullets in this game). Then there are those guys who ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bag team kill.   ALLAHU AKBAR /10 would play again

Insurgency is an all around great game for anyone wanting a serious challenge, or even veterans of other tactical shooters. If you're looking for a good, challenging, tactical shooter, pick up Insurgency, you won't regret it.

First Review:  Tapping > Spraying.  This is an objective and strategic based game. This is on par with CS-GO. If I can be objective, it has the potential to be better than CS-GO. I played CS for 15 years now and I been playing a lot of other FPS games, HF, quake, COD, BF, wolfestien, dirtybomb, warface, warframe, borderlands, you name it, I probably had played it before.   This is one of the best strategic FPS out there in the current market. It is a unique experience compared to other FPS games.   Suggestions for developers:  If they can push the realism to next level, it will be the best strategic FPS in the market. I have hope for this game. I would want to see more variety of realistic firearms for starters. I want more personalized firearms, not just in skins.  let's say being limited to five sets of different primary firearm per role will be a good start.   Conclusion:   If you enjoy tapping > spraying guns.  You enjoy practicing of game theory.   You happen to enjoy realistic FPS, situational and strategy based game, this is one of the best in the market you can get.

Do you want to taste the leathalness of real gunfight, but still have an excellent tacticalfps experience? These both in same package, here is   Insurgency  !!!  Personally I like this game a lot: An excellent mix of CS and Red Orchestra, good old school fps that takes you very close to events. Everything happens in seconds and sometimes you simply couldn't see it coming. Own score isn't the priority nro. 1 but the teamwork. This is not ADHD CoD arcade where you can dominate alone, this is where you are doomed to lose if trying to solo too much, sometimes even a bit. And the other (a bit more experienced) players know it already. Graphics, sounds and especially the atmosphere is awesome with a great touch of teamworking. So for those who are looking somehing challenging,  team  playing based tactical fps, I think you have found what you are looking for! But if you are going to let others to do the objective meanwhile you stay behind, dont even bother to get this game, you probably will be kicked out every server because n00b playing.

It's like Call of Duty game number 5000, where they actually realize that a good gun game is realistic.  It's like Battlefield, but without the Frosbite engine. Instead it runs off of Source and isn't broken.  It's like Squad except, well, not Squad.  It's like Counter Strike: GO but no skins and lots more guns. Also, much less spraying and moving.  It's like Counter Strike: Source but it's not Counter Strike, and it looks and plays way better. Note can no longer support low end toaster ovens.  It's like you are a soldier, except you respawn, and you have much worse team mates, and much less training.   It's like Halo, but not futuristic, and there are no aliens.  It's like not having hitmarkers or a HUD.  It's like not having the option to disable a HUD even when there is no HUD.   It's like someone yells RPG, and you die instantly.  It's like the entire enemy team is shooting at you and your team. This is about the time when you discover who is stupid and stands up to shoot thinking they could actually 'hit' something.  It's like discovering you can hit the right mouse button, but not anyone on the other team.  It's like discovering you made the wrong choice and stood up.  It's like taking 3 bullets to your living body, and receiving 30+ more bullets into your corpse.   10/10 would not stand up again.

A great game to play with friends, the general feel of the game is great. One minute you are running to a tactical spot, the next you are shooting an rpg screaming aloha snackbar! 8/10 would play again

This game is, in my honest opinion as a PC Gamer, the best first person shooter I was ever given the pleasure to play in 17 years of gaming. The quality of this release is almost beyond words. I'd encourage ANYONE to buy a copy. This is one of the rare games I'd pay full price for without a moment of hesitation. Free DLCs on top of it all from weapons, attachments, maps and game modes.   This is not the stereotypical Call Of Duty Halo shooter where run-and-gun tactics are acceptable. This is a game accentuated with mechanisms that clearly favor camping but with game modes that force you to play fast paced. Bullets, yes, can kill you in one hit. Life is a fragile thing and the game represented it well. This is the only multiplayer I've ever seen with accurate dynamic fire suppression mechanisms.  This shooter is a mix of a mind game and a skill shooting gaming. To be able to actually be GOOD at insurgency, you must know your environment and try to guess enemy movement.  Pros:  - Good feel to the guns - Incredible memorable maps - Incredible atmosphere - Multiple game modes - Surprisingly many players - Incredibly well optimized (Source engine) - Complex learning curve - Customization - Intensed methodical pacing - INCREDIBLE value - Raw and realistic combat - Free updates  Cons:  - Shotguns are incredibly lackluster and borderline useless. They damage reduction is way too strong on medium distances. - Netcode is awful. Always play in a server below 100 ping. (fixed somewhat now playable 100-150 range) - Dated visuals (although I'm not bothered by them) - Community is ♥♥♥♥ing annoying sometimes. The ammount of times Insurgents scream 'Allahu Akbar' on the microphone when they win a game is ABSURD. It gets old pretty fast but only generally happens in games with more than 14-16 players.

Insurgency is a game that's kinda hard to review. I really enjoy the challenging and realistic parts of it which is reminiscent of a FPS version of the Demon/ Dark Souls series. Yet, there are a couple of existing bugs and balancing issues that turn me off sometimes. Quite often while playing with my friends online, it just crashes (black screen) in middle of the game. Night time maps should be brightened to improve visibility and the AI with super human accuracy level should be nerved as well.  Bottom line: Regardless of the negatives, Insurgency is still a surprisingly fun and challenging game that I enjoy playing online with my friends. Really looking forward to future updates/ patches that will address the issues highlighted above.

To have fun playing some tactical, realistic FPS. Insurgency is a great game, and if you're not playing it, you're missing out!

Insurgency is a FPS that has a type of extreme competitive play-style to it in a pretty fun way. Would I suggest buying this game? Yes. Why? I would suggest buying this game for many reasons like the fact that this isnt all too much like the shooters out right now. This FPS doesnt include a radar and more importantly it makes sure you feel like you are in a warzone. You work with a pretty big team made of 2 squads and work to complete objectives. There are many types of gamemodes that you can play that require different tactics to get the job done most efficiently. Using real world tactics and strategies inorder to move from one room to another with out getting ambushed can be pretty fun. Still not feeling like its that competitive? The only other thing I can think of that gives the game an extra edge is that you never truely know if you killed your target and it is very possible that the 'enemy' that you killed was a teamate and it gets intense when you are alone in a quiet battlefield fighting an unknown ammount of enemies. Playing this game requires some quick thinking and skills. Would I suggest this game for people who are casual players? You could try it, but I would HIGHLY suggest that competitive players get this game.

This game isn't for everyone, it can be frustrating at times. But I find the absence of minimap, magazine bullet count and notifications of hits on enemies and messages about who killed who very nice and refreshing as it adds to the feel of constant caution.

There's a lot to love about Insurgency. It's inherent realism, paired with stellar gameplay mechanics and also it's ease of access.  It's quick to jump right into a game, although as of now, there are only a few good servers which have low ping - being in Asia. Despite this it's still easy to get into a match and have fun. I have not played too much of the PvP game modes but the Co-op is extremely fun. I think it's the fact it's very easy to die, which makes survival and being tactical very important. You will not survive if you run around like a lunatic - which believe it or not, this can be done in a lot of FPS games nowadays. Continuing, the spawn system works perfectly, only being able to spawn if your team capture or complete an objective, this adds to the tension of the game. This game really strives to deliver an almost unparralled raw and realistic first-person shooter. Extra postives: Solid gun sounds, good gun related animations & decent graphics. Negatives: Sometimes unstable when joining game but it is only temporary.   Tl;dr: Solid realistic FPS worth the money.   Update 1: July 7  I have since played more PvP game modes and have really enjoyed it, I think this game is gaining more and more players which is good.  One way I could see it improving is only through aesthetic customisation of your soldier, possibly a system which rewards unlocks from kills or experience. I say this because there's not too much to strive towards whilst playing but the most important aspect is already here: fun. If they could expand the game in that way I think it would be even better for people who love this game.

Great tactical squad-based shooter. Recommended for those who want to take Battlefield to the next level, and if you hate running around scoring kill-streaks. Really runs your adrenaline, can be intense and exciting.  LIKED: Gun play felt realistic and fairly balanced. Sound effects were insanely detailed and believeable. Ministry and Sinjar are great maps, and Peak is very experimental. (Re)-spawning system was great, just needs spawn kill protection of some sort. Movement feels fast/tight, you can get to an objective, hunker down, lean out and maneuver easily. HUD stays out of the way.  DISLIKED: Spawn killing can get pretty bad on some maps. You can get completely stuck in some places of some maps. No leveling system.  SUGGESTIONS: Names of teammates should appear faster. More map variety. Plain old Deathmatch/Team Deathmatch modes? A few more weapons? Mines or some sort of claymore would be badass. Simple leveling system to add more points to the loadout system/unlock guns or maps? Blood or some indicator of a kill.  PRICE: Regular: 7/10 | Steam Sale: 9/10 ENTERTAINMENT: Singleplayer: 5/10 | Multiplayer: 9/10 OVERALL: 8.5/10  TL;DR: Buy it if it goes on sale or you LOVE tactical squad-based shooters. If you play with friends it is even better. Tight controls, realistic gameplay, and a decent map/player variety. Array of guns/maps/gamemodes is average, but you can't complain for $14.99!

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.  Eat.

Insurgency is relatively realistic. It looks like a Ken Burns documentary compared to Call of Duty’s and Battlefield’s more Hollywood approach. For one thing, your screen isn’t filled with information. You have no health bar, no compass, no map, and no aiming reticule. Flashy text doesn’t congratulate you after every kill.Without it, Insurgency looks cleaner and more authentic than its peers, letting you focus on strategy and action instead of keeping track of an enemy’s location on a minimap in the corner of the screen.Insurgency also doesn’t have a lot of the flash you see in modern shooters.At first glance, you’ll want to compare Insurgency to Counter-Strike. Both are competitive, team-based shooters that pit terrorists against counter-terrorist forces, but the two play differently. While you only get one life per a round of Counter-Strike, most game modes in Insurgency permit you to revive your entire team if you complete an objective, like capturing a certain point on the map or destroying a weapon cache.This dynamic provides for some fun comebacks.Insurgency offers roles like demotion, sniper, and recon, but you can’t necessarily be whatever you want. Each match offers a set number of slots for each class. The available loadouts change depending on the map and mode you’re playing. Since Insurgency is so much more realistic than most shooters, it’s also a good deal more complicated and less forgiving.Also, you won’t find any sort of training or single-player mode, so your only option if you want to improve is to jump into some online matches and suffer through some punishment. Insurgency was originally a Source-based mod, but this standalone release still uses the almost 10-year-old game engine. As a result, Insurgency isn’t the most-detailed game, with a lot of textures looking flat and dated. Ultimately, Insurgency is going to win fans for its gameplay. The action is highly competitive and focused.Sure, it doesn’t have the flash that most shooters proudly throw at your face these days, but Insurgency’s quieter, more realistic, and tenser take on modern warfare deserves a look, especially if you’re tired of instant knife kills and exploding buildings.

I really am enjoying the game thus far. It has a large number of game modes all which really force you to work as a team. Your goal is to win, not to get as many kills as you can by yourself. The game tries to focus on realism, with no HUD aside from teamate designation and capture point info, and nearly every weapon in the game killing in 1-2 hits if aimed precisely. The maps for the most part are well designed and the night versions of the maps give them an interesting twist. The only gripe I could have with this game is that a big part of doing well has to do with map knowledge and that takes a bit to get acustomed to. I would recommed playing the 'push' gamemode to start as it lets you learn the map in chunks over and over again, rather than having the whole map open to try and learn. The community for the most part is pretty welcoming and not littered with 10 year olds. Overall I really enjoy this game and would recommend it to anyone who wants a satisfying multiplayer shooter experience. I picked it up for $6 on sale so if youre still holding back just wait until it goes on sale. Well worth it.

The mechanics simple, the action brutal. Insurgency is as close as a modern battlefield most games get, as every move, every shot, every kill can be the difference between life and death, victory or defeat. Skill, tactics, and a lot of patience are key to success in this gritty first-person-shooter, for it will be merciless to those who wander the battlefield haphazardly exploring its environments. The only downside to the game would be the limited map enclosures that force you into certain chokepoints without any real alternatives other than to charge in guns blazing.

This means that each bullet feels like it is deadly, and therefore the weapon in your hands also feels like an actual weapon and not just a visual representation of a weapon that doesnt feel dangerous. I cannot stress how important this is for the mechanics of a first person shooter. This changes the flow of the combat and it makes teams cooperate instead of just running around and competing against each other on the team. For me, this is the way a team shooter should be, and I think this game pulls this off in a very good way. The maps are not gigantic like they are in project reality, but this ensures that there isn't too long between each fight.   I love this game and cannot recommend it enough!

I have to openly admit that I was not a fan of the Insurgency mod. However, this standalone version is a lot of fun. I'm not very good at multiplayer yet, but games are balanced and you never feel overpowered or underpowered. Unlike many shooters today, you have to strategically choose what is most important to you on the field. What do you want the most, is that grenade or a few extra mags more important? Do you want attachments on your primary, or have a seconday weapon just in case? What about body armor? These are the kinds of decisions you will have to make, and it really does keep things fair. In additon to competitive multiplayer, Insurgency has a fantastic co-op mode. Working together is key and it breaks the mold of your typical run-and-gun shooters. One of Insurgency's best assets is that it makes you feel vulnerable (but not to the point where it's unforgiving). Running from cover to cover is key as is leaning around corners so you don't give the enemy too easy of a target. The game feels solid so far, even though it is in early access. I can't want to see what's in store for the finished product.

I'm crouched against the wall with a hallway behind me and a stairwell to my front. I'm carefully listening to the enemy as they discuss a startegy to flush me, the only surviving player, out of my hiding spot. Suddenly, I hear a guy running up behind me so I lean right and look into the hallway and peg the guy six times in the chest with my silenced MP5. I turn around and check the stairwell, another enemy tried to sneak in but gets capped and rolls down the staircase, with dust, gunsmoke and blood plumes following him. I turn around again and another guy tries creeping up behind me through the hallway, but I get the drop and spray his face off. Again, I turn around just to have a tango staring me right in the face, so I instinctly fall to the prone position and shoot his guts out. My pro-clutch abilites are going haywire at this point as I make my way to a leaned position in the stairwell. I overshoot the lean and get caught by an M16 to the chest.   Would I recommend this game? Hell yes I would.   From the sounds of ear-snapping bullet effects, the blood-curdling echoes of cries of death in the distance, and the overall realism the game offers, I'd say anyone who enjoys the Counter-Strike games, or looking for a first-person-shooter w/ a good bit of realistic immersion, needs to get their hands on this one.

You don't have levels and there is no sense of ranking up in the game. Ther are special loadouts for each particular class, generally with four different weapons to choose from and assorted attachments for said weapons. This game is pretty realistic for a game, none of that CoD B.S.! One shot is lethal, you don't have to empty your whole freaking clip into a seemingly invincible enemy. You have to be careful, just running and gunning won't cut it, the game takes teamwork to new level. The current maps are fun and offer great gameplay! I highly recommend this game, it's an awesome price too! :)

Insurgency is very lethal, delibarate team shooter. All the weapons are deadly, handling is more difficult than most games, and tactics take a higher seat than twitch shooting. This is a game where if you take your time, check your corners, and read the flow of battle you can really turn the tide of a round with a huge flank. This is in contrast to game like CS:GO where you are a bullet sponge by real-world standards and can turn on someone shooting you in the back. The variety of modes is good for keeping things fresh even if some of them are just a minor variation of another. I also have to give credit to the sound designer. The cracks and thuds of rounds are terrifying when the battlefield silence is broken with one.  The only gripe I have about this game is the community. They are just terrible pieces of ♥♥♥♥ for the most part. It is best to just disable voice chat and leave a game when the TKers arrive.  $14.99 is the perfect price point for this game and was worth it at $20. The game is unforgiving to lazy play but very rewarding to calculated maneuvers.

Modern Military Shooter that feels like an alternate present day where tactical team based first person shooters reigned.   **How I found this game by rage alone is at the bottom  I have been a huge fan of Rainbow Six since it launched in the 90s straight through when they stopped making Rainbow Six games in 2004 and I've got to say... Insurgency is making me feel really good right now. I had forgotton how satisfying it is to have a plan and excecute it.   This game isn't Team Survival-centric like Rainbow Six 3, but the way that respawns are incorporated into the game makes sense. There's nothing wrong with having respawns as long as the way the game plays encourages you to make the most of the first (and potentially the only) life you have. In Insurgency, your team can earn a 'wave respawn' if you complete an objective. So, if you are the only man alive you can resurect your whole team by taking down a control point. The control points are spaced out so you'll have to respect the possibility of not respawning at all and play smart. This IS NOT a run in there as the star player and win the game for your team type of shooter. You'll need the help of your sniper to pick off targets in the distance while your support gunner lays down covering fire... all while not feeling like your role is shoe horned in.  Speaking of roles... I'm sure we've all seen a video where someone's whole team was camped up on a rock a million miles from the objective pretending they're helping, right? Well, in Insurgency only one player can play each available role. That means you have a list of 'jobs' to pick from before the round starts and that job will have a specific loadout by default. That can be changed within reason, but you will be expected to play that role... so demolitions expert... BRING C4. That also means that if there's one spot for a 'sniper' then you'll never have more than one 'sniper.' It also means that people who want that role can't hide behind the fact that they are one of a million snipers... they are all you've got... so they better be mixing it up and helping the team. In my first 10 or so hours with the game... that was the case.  Customizing gear comes with a system of points with each option for your gun/gear having a point value between +0 and +4 (from what I can remember). That means if you ditch your +1 side arm you can put a +1 heavy barrel on your M16. You can bring heavy armor, but you may have to ditch the holographic optics to do so. Each class has weapons/gear that are specific to that class and some others that can be carried across all classes. Everyone I've seen can carry a frag grenade, but a rifleman can't carry C4 (IIRC) no matter how many points he has available. Get it?   Basically, this is a MODERN FPS with OLD SCHOOL roots. It really does feel like the direction I thought games were going in during the early 2000s. It's all the stuff I liked with a ton of new stuff I'm falling in love with quickly. When people mention 'old school' or the like they normally mean that all the comforts and upgrades that have come about in the last few years are gone. That's not the case here. If you're coming off your thousandth hour of Battlefield 4 or Call of Duty: Ghosts you'll be right at home... you'll just need to adjust to the MENTALITY of an old school shooter. In Insurgency you're no longer the army... you're a part of a team.  **The title 'Insurgency' plus the trailor PLUS the promotional artwork they have posted made me think this game was some political message piece where you play as the 'insurgents' vs what appears to be US troops. It really didn't sit well with me so I went and checked out some gameplay videos to see if my feels was reals. Turns out they just have no idea how they are coming across (to me at least). A realistic, squad based, modern military FPS, simmilar to Red Orchestra 2. A fair bit has changed from the mod, some good, some not so much. Loadouts are customizable, with what's available, and the supply (a sort of currency to limit what one person can have and attach to their weapons) cost changing depending on what side you're playing on, and what class you are.  There's a host of modes for competetive MP, all objective based. And a Co-Op mode which has you progress from one end of a level to the other, capturing objectives, defending against counter attacks, and blowing up ammo caches. A defensive hoarde mode (last I knew) is in the works as well.  I'd recommend this to fans of the mod, of Red Orchestra, and perhaps America's Army as well.

Great game if you can pick it up for cheap. I believe this title does however have issues and feel it falls under the catagory of a work in progress. They simply have not worked out all the bugs.  PROS- tight gameplay, alot of the community run microphones for working together, realistic sound mix, objective game modes, simple and balanced for the most part, developers seems very involved and are constantly updating with patches and DLC.  CONS- server stuttering, player icons not showing up sometimes (friendly fire), hit detection seems off sometimes (could go hand in hand with server issues), no ranking or stat system (play for fun)  Keep in mind this is a hardcore shooter and not your run and gun type game, 1-3 bullets drops you. Overall I've gotten my 15 dollars out of the game so far. I recommend this game for anyone who wants to put a headset on and play the objective.

2300 Hours. Only a few of us left now. I'm surrounded by Terrorists. My comrade is nearby, shaking. He's been through the ringer, and he just gives me the Thousand Yard Stare. We can't move, the enemy set up a sniper position, moving now would just be committing suicide. Someone just got back from being AFK. He runs out into the open and yells 'LEEEROOOY JEEENKIIINS!'. He dies on the spot. Damn sniper. My ammo is almost depleted, it's nearing the end of the round. I hear gunshots being exchanged, the guy in the corner is no longer there, and blood is the only trace of him. A few moments later and it's quiet, too much for my own good. I feel myself tense. A terrorist rounds the corner and spots me, in the end, I'm down to no ammo and I'm near death. I hear an enemy nearby. '♥♥♥♥ it,' I thought. I pull out a grenade and hold the pin, I run out into the fray. I scream into my mic, 'ALLAHU ACKBAR!' Me and the enemy both die in the ensuing explosion. But what's this? We win? The guy that was in the corner from earlier was the last one remaining, he somehow took out the sniper. We indeed win, victory. But at what cost? I am forever tramautized. 9/11-IGN, Would PTSD again.

If your ideal first-person experience focuses on Kill to death ratios, a big-brand name, more shooting and less cover, and nothing but full-auto madness, you've come to the wrong place; But if you seek a game that emphasizes on teamwork, tacticality, immersion, ammo conservation, realism, using cover, and as close to the adrenaline levels of a real firefight as it gets, look no further. This game is likely the most realistic and immersive first-person shooter out there, and though the bullets are not real, the panic will be. You'll be scared out of your mind as an insurgent rounds the corner and blows you away with an RPK. The guy with the AKM on the hill will manage a perfect and seemingly impossible shot from time to time. The militant with an RPG will wipe your entire team with one pull of the trigger. It's the nature of the game, and it is tough. Your job is to work together with your teammates, and be deliberate in completing your mission.  Favorite gamemode: Elite Coop

While not without its flaws, Insurgency is a fantastic tactical shooter that many enjoy as much as the extremely popular Counter Strike: Global Offensive. The two games share an engine, both running on source, so it will run on nearly any hardware.  The game is set up in a few different modes, that range from 32 player firefights to 6 player Co-op vs. bots and everything in between. Most game modes center upon playing the objectives, rather than just going for kills, but certain modes are very kills oriented for those who are interested. Teamwork is very important, as is carrying out your squad role. The learning curve isn't steep and there are plenty of skins and customizations in the workshop to get things tuned the way you like them.  The community is pretty good, from what I've come across, and people are good at helping new people on the more casual servers. Every once in a while, you can get on a team with trolls and that can really ruin a game, but it isn't to hard to switch servers, and trolls are infrequent.  The game is still being actively developed at the time of writing, and sometimes they introduce new glitches or change the feel of things just a bit, not always for the better, but the bugs are usually fixed again quickly. A new build on a new engine is said to be coming, so that may be interesting. I hope that it is Source 2, but I don't think they have said.  I'd definitely recommend the game to FPS fans or CS:GO players looking for a different feel. Lots of fun to be had, and great team work to enjoy.

I have purchased too many games in early access, and I have been dissapointed with plenty. However, this game emerged out of a mod and is without a doubt the most complete and impressive alpha I have seen. The jist of my review is this, if you enjoyed counterstrike source, you will most likely find this a worthy successor. It meets counterstrike's tactical gameplay with meticulous projectile physics and the 'advancements' in modern fps...ses halfway. Considering what's on offer, $15 seems like a more than fair price to me, if it were ever on sale for less it would be a steal.  The visuals aren't breathtaking, but they certainly get the job done and communicate a bleak atmosphere. The sound design is quite good, the crackle of gunfire is satisfying and each gun produces a unique sound. The controls are pretty standard fare. The level design on the maps is pretty good, though there are occasional balance issues depending on the game mode.  Insurgency does have flaws, there are bugs- perhaps the most notorious of which is crashing during explosions, but the devs seem on top of them. Running into walls or other obstacles seems to get you 'stuck' occasionally, and sometimes there are strange shapes or movements that can be distracting. However, most of these seem like minor things that need ironing out, and not structural problems.  For fans of CS, I can't recommend this enough. For me at least it recaptures the unique tactical firefights and pace of counterstrike in a sleeker more modern package. Anyone looking for a big budget, graphical powerhouse of jingoistic testosterone full of cinematic setpieces and vehicles and such, keep walking.

Insurgency is tactical, authentic, and intense. Up to 16 man teams of Marines and Insurgents face off in various game modes, including CTF, Skirmish (point capture, players only respawn once their team captures another point) and Push (attackers gain reinforcements for successfully assaulting objectives). The key to Insurgency's charm being it ruthless lethality, and immediate resolution of the game at the depletion of one team's reinforcements. Think modern Red Orchestra, but with Counter Strikes map design and equipment model.  Presentation: A blood-pumping heroic score graces the menu, and somber or heroic resolution themes get your morale up for the next match, or aide in your subsequent defeat. I like it. Bullets snap past your face, dust puffs up, explosions rip through buildings with a trembling roar. The ecstatic shouts of the accurate and chilling screams of the slain ring out as the thrum of a firefight rolls across the map. Graphically, you can tell Insurgency was formerly a source mod. Building and terrain textures are perfectly passable, but 'this ain't Crysis'. Night maps have superb lighting, and tracers are appropriately bright and harrowing. It might not be a looker, but the sound design more than makes up for it's mediocre graphical fidelity. Character models are likewise passable, and the surprisingly beautiful mountain and farm battlefields are offset by brown and muddy waddis and urban hellholes. We're here to shoot things, not to admire walls.   Gameplay: The true meat of an FPS experience. Each team uses points to select factions specific equipments, allowing for surprising diversity but still thankfully reigned in on the side of authenticity. Support gunners can forgo extra ammo belts for heavy armour, or by spending extra points, equip carbines. Assaulters can forgo pistols in favor of extra grenades or attachments for their rifles. Interestingly, the factions are clearly different. The Insurgents only have access to Soviet-era weapons and special explosives, while the Marines have advanced body armour and accurate weapons. Movement is fluid, made more so by a slide when ending sprints. However, slow cautious gunplay is the best strategy. Bullets are near 1 hit kills, so suppressing fire by LMGs quickly must be met by smoke to avoid random casualties. Most engagements are exchanges of fire at around 50-100 meters, with occasional rockets and grenades breaking holes in mostly clearly defined battle-lines. Armour-less and suppressor equipped scouts attempt flanking maneuvers, while shotgun and flashbang laden breachers clear the apartments, as hulking combat infantry and gunners slowly advance down the chaotic streets below. Battle is a complex dance, with perceptive squad leaders issuing suppressive fire and movements orders, and the rough-and-tumble infantry just enjoying the intense and nerve-wracking chaos of combat. Insurgency is tactical, authentic and intense.   Technical: Source mod, you know what to expect. I never dipped below 60 fps, in the most intense gunfights with all settings set to ultra.   As someone who wanted a tight and deadly close quarter FPS, Insurgency is perfect for me. Anyone wanting the no-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t '1 hit and out' gunfights coupled with traumatic and frantic twitch accuracy combat will absolutely enjoy this FPS experience. Well worth the cheap price of entry.

I bought this in early acces, I thought it was fun for a while but then just stopped playing. But as I played it now, I was amazed. This game isn't your ordinary 'military shooter' no, this is far better. This game has the strategy and tactics of an Arma game, but plays out like Battlefield. The online community is pretty good, but I have ran into some asshats. The realistic feel to this game is what amazes me. There is no hud whatsoever so you need to rely on pure guessing (unless you count every bullet fired.) You really feel victorious when you win a match or get a kill. I forgot to mention the health system. The health system in this game really is not forgiving, one to three shots is all it takes so be careful. A word of advice, stay in cover, don't go prancing around the map COD style. This game really suggests you stay behind cover or your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ will be jammed with bullets. The graphics are nothing special, but the gun detail is amazing, each shot you fire off has smoke and hot gas come out of the muzzle, you can see the scratches and notches in the weapons. Soundwise this game is eargasm worthy to me. Put on some headphones and you will feel that the bullets flying through the air are actually coming towards you. The crack of bullets, the explosions, the random allahu ackbar through the mic all make this a better game. Animations can be a little wonky at times, but they make you laugh so I don't mind it. If you like gritty, realistic shooters this is the game for you. If you don't like waiting for the next reinforcement wave and/or easily rage, this is not for you. I rate it a 7.5/10 for it's realistic gameplay and pure fun, ALLAHU ACKBAR!

If you like super-realistic gameplay like ARMA, fast-paced action like CoD, strategic team play like Battlefield or CSGO, then this game is the Messiah of video games. I got this game for free over a year ago and I find myself constantly returning to play it despite owning many new games over that time. The intense fun that this game delivers puts triple A titles to shame. This game is $15 bucks, and the devs give out free content all the time. They have no paid DLC. Free maps, free weapons, tons of fun. I feel as if I stole this game by getting it for free from humble bundle. It's worth far more than $15, not to mention it's constantly going on sale!   Let's look at all the content this $15 game gives you: Countless maps(with more coming) Several awesome and balanced guns(with possibly more coming further down the line) Online PvP Online PvE Offline PvE Tonnes of gamemodes(with occasional additions of new game modes) Legal Workshop mods  Let's not forget that the PvP and PvE modes are almost two entirely different beasts in this game. In PvP you have to face other players, using advanced tactics and teamwork to outsmart your enemies to win in a game where map knowledge and tactics are key. While PvE deals with 4-12 players(and more on custom servers) facing off against VERY SMART bots in several different game modes different from PvP. That's right, both PvP and PvE have their own unique set of game modes to give more content!   PvE may sound pretty easy, but I assure you the bots are not stupid by any means. They are easily the smartest bots of any shooter I've played. They know how to take cover, retreat, fight in groups, pre fire, how to properly place grenades and rockets, how to locate gunshots, and more! These AI are almost as good as other human beings playing the game. It makes for a load of fun and challenging missions, often times leaving a more rewarding victory than PvP modes.   Finally, the thing that gives this game even MORE content: making the game truly yours through workshop mods. Yes, almost all workshop mods are available for use in PvP and PvE modes(player model changes can only be used in PvE however). You can apply gun camos, player camos(to clarify, camos are allowed in PvP, but not changes to the models themselves), sight remodels, and even gun replacements. For example, you can 'replace' the AK-74 with the AK-12. Or you can make your Security team soldiers have a US Navy SEAL camo. Let's not forget sound mods! Yes, sound mods are in the game as well. I recommend the realistic sound mod and the all-time Classic 'Allahu ackbar' mod, which makes Insurgents scream the phrase when throwing explosives.   So as anyone can see, this game is a boatload of fun, and it truly gives far more to the player than any other game I've played. No microtransactions, not a lot of misbalance, good optimization, and most decent rigs can run it. If you're into shooters, especially more tactical and realistic ones, then you'd be a fool not to buy this game.   11/10.

i like this game a lot. very realistic gunplay, a lot of fun, great customization but as always i have gripes!  1) enemy AI vs friendly AI-no contest, your friendlies are dumb as bricks, standing in the open, not firing at enemies 3 feet in front of them while getting shot by them, not covering me at all, basically dont rely on them and have them die ALL THE TIME. enemy AI will flank, use strategic points, surround you and pin you down, they will also be as cheap as possible to kill you like use RPGs and grenades. they are also super numerous and they know it rushing you with 15-20 men at a time and you frantically run out of ammo trying to kill them all as the last man standing. devs spent a TON of time on the enemy and 0 time on friendly   2) attachments not for all the classes-i always want an m16/m203 with a red dot and suppressor. its good for every situation. they wont allow the supressor or grenade launcher for all classes so you must pick one or the other. about 80% of attachments are in every class but special ones are class specific which is kinda lame since there are already gun variations and gun barriers to begin with. like the grenadier class cant get a saw+rockets? like wtf. the argument of balance is thrown out the window when a rifleman and a grenadier get access to the same kit.....side note, the grenade launcher range sights are not on the side for the m16 or m4, they are on the top rail between the forward and rear carry handle/sight. they only exist on the side for the gp-25 on the ak47 and ak74u.  3) modding/weapon selection- this modding community is amazing, one of the best ive seen in my experiences, tons of stuff. the issue i have with it is the NEW weapons they offer are only replacements. come on devsss let them add stuff not replace!!!! its free content creation for your game, if you ever want to add the new weapons to the game its a simple, pay them for the model and boom implemented. for instance i would like to have the ACR in my game but having it replace the m4 in the game just isnt fun cuz then id have to unsub from the mod if i want to use the m4 again.   overall i still like the game 7.5/10
