Insurgency is the game I've been waiting for since I began gaming, certainly in FPS games. As a (until a couple of years ago) a COD console gamer (yes I know) I had several problems with most FPS games. I like the realistic, brutal games they can be, but rarely ever are, as COD went downhill after MW3, Battlefield tries to be realistic while maintaining a quick respawn and points system, and CSGO has the typical valve idea of no ADS or sprinting, which detracts from the game.  Gameplay- 9/10 Hyperrealistic with no crosshair, no dumb dive to prone, realistic aiming speeds and maintaining some peripheral vision as you would aiming down a real scope. Some emphasis on teamwork as it has a hotkeyed menu of squad commands etc that can be used while moving, which is handy when you can get pinned down after you remember you can't lone wolf take out the entire enemy team. Good bullet damage, and no exaggerated ballistics I hated in BF4. Maybe a little added ballistics and bullet penetration thru materials, though not the COD 'shot thru a 5 inch brick wall' style. Guns actually have realistic mechanics, so no more sprinting down the map sniping with a pistol.  Loadouts- 10/10 Unique loadout system where you pick a class on match start, and each class has a pick of certain guns, E.G. snipers can pick from 3-4 snipers and DMRs, Recon from 4-5 SMGs and shotguns etc. You can then equip attachmens, sidearms, levels of armor/ammo packs and grenades but are restricted by your number of 'tokens' and your total carry weight. More items= more firepower/armor/ammo, but slower running speed and less stamina. No OTT weapon stats so instead of picking a gun based on bar charts you pick it on how good you actually are with it, so a bit of a learning curve for the first 3ish matches while you find your favouites but thats adds to realism. Decent grenades to pick from, as you get smoke, frags, molotovs and C4. I would like a proximity mine, though for a high price 'cause those things can be a ♥♥♥♥♥. Also, grenades differ slightly depending on your team, E.G. insurgents get IEDs while security forces get C4. Good attention to detail, because seriously, when was the last time you saw a terrorist *cough* sorry 'insurgent' with serious military hardware? No progression/ unlock system most FPS games seem to use, which may seem like it detracts from the sense of achievement, but I feel just got in the way of the game.  Maps- 9/10 Varying map sizes from COD small AF size to huge BF style maps, which can be restricted down for gamemodes needing smaller combat areas, or dynamically changing to open up more areas/shutting off areas when objectives are completed. Good map design so sniping actually feels worth it while other close range soldiers can also fight in more built up areas without worrying every five seconds if a sniper is gonna no-scope them thru 3 houses and a dog, You also get matches at night on the same maps, where the underbarrel torch gets really handy or you can get some useful toggle-able nightvision goggles, which again are realistic as you can be blinded by torches and your in-game 'eyes' take a moment to adjust to the NVGs.  Matches- 10/10 Loads of different (mainly objective based) game modes which are hosted on servers that, unlike other games, there is always a server open for a game you like with a decent amount of player (usually full or missing 1-2 players). Very good lobby sizes with 2 squads of about 8 men on each team (so 16 men on each team). Very good 'respawn' mechanism as once you die you wait for the next wave of reinforcements and then respawn as a different soldier but using the same loadout. Good match lengths, as they end when you run out of reinforcement waves, when you complete all the objectives or when the (lengthy) timer stops, so you don't have to rush around worrying about the match ending before you can get a decent kill count. There are also solo and coop game modes which are very well made, with every coop enemy AI being a serious danger, instead of a vague annoyance like other games. Again high emphasis on objectives which will pose a challenge. I haven't done much solo, but it has a tutorial mode, with a bit of a twist.  Decent DEVs which release free updates and will listen, though the updates aren't all the time which I like as the game has no real bugs I've found so the updates are more like DLC map packs, only free. Other FPS game developers need to think about cheaper DLCs that are actually decent new material, not just reskinned maps from previous games for 15 pound. Lookin at you Treyach/Activision.  As I said, this game is near perfect for my tastes, so anyone who likes the more realistic side of FPS, or big team games. or just games you can use to ♥♥♥♥ off the COD kids because it actually needs some skill, then look no further- 9/10, because I generally don't give 10/10 until I know the game back to front, whereas I've only played about 12 hours.

I am a huge fan of FPS. And I bet you are, too.   I bet you're thinking 'should I buy Insurgency right now?'  The answer depends on what you are looking for:  A casual arcade experience: Call of Duty A team-based (still casual) experience: Battlefield  An ultra-realistic experience: Arma III A competitive experience: CS:GO A visceral, PTSD-inducing experience: Red Orchestra 2  If you want aspects of everything above, get Insurgency. Casual enough so you can just jump right into the action, but realistic enough to make you cringe everytime you see a squadmate die.   This game is worth so much more than you will buy this for. Tired of hearing words like 'Hardcore' and 'Tactical', only to discover the game is either insanely complex or just a reskinned COD/CS clone? I am; and I'm proud to say this game is hardcore, and not in a buzzwordy way. When you are getting fired at in Insurgency, you will surely know it; from the particle effects when a round impacts and object to the not-very-over-the-top blur (I can barely call it blur but it is there), this game has a tendency to make me jump when I hear an unexpected crack as a round whizzes by my head, or (when playing versus AI) when I hear a friendly soldier yell out 'RPG RPG!', Insurgency is very immersive-while from a technical stand point Insurgency isn't very impressive, from a gameplay perspective it is absolutely astonishing. The game excels in it's Player versus Player, providing a unique and entertain experience, for example: I had just finished a game (we lost) and as per usual, players talked trash or congratulated one another over VOIP (note that it was friendly, sportsman like trash talk- not 10 year old Xbox trash talk). The next game proceeded to start and the teams had been switched around, but I noticed one of the more confident players from the VOIP at the end of the game was on the other team-I didn't think much of it at the time. Then mid-way through the match I am slowly creeping up a staircase to an objective past a few friendly dead bodies when I hear: 'Yeah, it's clear.' -That guy... again... I love proximity (♥♥♥♥ spelling) voice chat! Especially when I can hear my enemy! Back to the story... i heard 'Yeah, it's clear.' and in a foolish yet unique and fun turn of events pressed my push-to-talk key and exclaimed: 'Or is it?' Turns out I killed one and then got taken out by VOIP guy... Next game VOIP guy and I are on the same team, versus his friends on Teamspeak. Long story short: the community is pretty cool.   Pros:    prox. voice chat to all players*   immersive   WEAPON HANDLING 10/10   grade A particle effects   community is nice**   sound assets are fantastic   low system specs   perpetually high frame rate***   '1-shot' type hit to kill ratio   no HUD   night is DARK    Cons:    graphical fidelity is sub par   linear level design****   sitting out entire rounds on death*****   *Please note that there is also chat to your entire squad (1-3 usually 2 per team) it just combined with the prox. chat **Please note that this statement is entirely subject to change, is subjective, and may be different based on your experience ***Note this is dependant on your hardware and the settings you run the game on.Additionally note that there are some problem areas ****while the maps offer multiple angles and what not, either the objective is constantly contested or one side to the point that some maps always have the same outcome *****Depending on how you play, what gamemode you play, and your team

I will not give this the best review, but I won't trash it, either. The servers are laggy at times, and the game does not seem to like Shift + Tab for Steam functions, or Alt + Tab for Windows. Getting back into the server after this, you have a virtual seizure with mutliple repeating gunshot sounds before you can load in. These are the things I don't like about Insurgency.   Here's what I actually DO like and why I recommend this game:  1. Realistic weaponry and terrain. 2. Teamwork is a must here - know your role and what is required of you.  3. Insurgency is like a cross breed of Counter Strike, Battlefeild, and Arma. It has the crazyness of Battlefeild, the feel of counter strike, and the tactics of arma. Its slow pased when not in battle but once you hit combat your adreniline rushes and it becomes really fast paced. It's a hardcore FPS so any COD fans should stay away. There is no radar, hp meter, or ammo meter. There also isn't a kill cam which keeps you on the edge of your seat, checking every corner to find that person. The gamemodes are fairly basic and usually revolve around the same concept. This game is fairly difficult and you wont be getting long killstreaks. Insurgeny is a good example of what new FPS's should be.(insurgency isnt new, it started as a mod for HL2). I highly recomend this to any competitive FPS fan or Tactical FPS fan. I give Insurgency a 8.5/10.

Insurgency is a real breath of fresh air when it comes to FPS games. It's more realistic and focuses on tactical movement and common sense than other run and gun types. If you try to run and gun, you're going to die very quickly (before or after the supression effects have you runnin straight into a wall). There is a large selection of guns for either team (obvious things like AK's for Insurgents and guns beginning with M for security) with a great amount of customisation. There are specific classes which can carry what guns and items and you get supply points which stop you from loading up like rambo. It's a very goodsystem for equipment but if you're one of those guys who thinks that being patient and covering an objective (n00b camping for all you CoD fanboys) is stupid you're also gonig to die very quickly. The player base in generally very good (except the occasional idiot who shouts 'allah ackbar' after every insurgent win) and willing to work as a team which is very refreshing and enjoyable comparing to a lot of other games in which my teammates and enemys have had sexual relations with my mother and in which I'm gay for my other family members (don't forget the classic 'brush your teeth you British ♥♥♥'). Teamwork is critical in this game, a team who is mature and cooperative will beat any other team 9 times out of 10. Overall, even for it's some frustrating moments I feel Insurgency is a brilliant game, well worth the £3.50 I paid for (on sale).

Your experience on this game can go one of two ways:   1. You learn how to play well, becoming a decent, or a good player.  2. OR, you can do horribly, Dying every left turn you take, and when you decide to go right, you still die. There is no turn around, no back, just forward.  The game itself: Insurgency is an addicting game. The graphics are wonderful, giving you something to look at whilst you shoot and kill people for you own fun and enjoyment. You will find yourself firing your weapon to just hear it, and your reasoning is will probably be understood by your teammates around you. The Grenades are spot on, and the weapon models are designed to perfection. Although the game has a few bugs here and there, they are far and few.  The annoying yet still fun part of the game: Your spawn-in can go three ways: A. You walk/run peacefully out of spawn B. You take fire whilst running out of spawn(Because trust me, you WILL be running) Or C. You will die.   Your teammates, usually, are well receiving of 'Noobies' to the game, although try not to go Team Killing MLG because they will try to kick and ban you. The actual battle(In longer words, you run through a cornfield thinking you are safe and hidden, and then you reach the middle and you get shot/blown up/cooked) can be intense or slow. One side will take the bad, and the team members will die left and right, and the other will get many kills and less deaths. The Spawn-in system is by wave, and you, of course, have a limited amount of waves. But when you take an objective you receive extra waves and time, on both attacking and defending sides(Depending on what mode you are playing, which there are many).  Overall, This is a great game and believe many others would enjoy it aswell, and it worth much more than what it is currently priced.  11/10 Would run through that cornfield again  12/1 Would go MLG team killing again

This game (at least for me) is insanely hard to learn, it requires patience, concentration, tactics, and strategy. I think that there are two reasons these factors make the game so great. 1. It stands out from other first person shooters 2. It acts as a filter to the people who make Counter-Strike as cancer as it is. If you are ready to endure a steep learning curve, and ruthlessly good opposing teams, I can whole-heartedly recommend this game to you. If you are used to combat like in Call of Duty, you WILL struggle, but if you have the patience to learn, then it will be one of the best investments in a game you can make.

Ok. Honest disclaimer here going forward, yes I am a fan, but not in that annoying fanboy type of way where a person thinks their favored game's @%#% smells like roses, but a fan when you feel someone just hit a nerve, but you are not sure why or how but you walk away with that feeling of , well....Damn..... It's not perfect by any means and obvious areas that can be improved, but let's just say this game can scratch that hard to reach itch so many other FPS's just never seem to be able to reach because they are too caught up being busy signing autographs at their photo shoots at the awards ceremony and planning on their next PR angle. So on with it already!!!  It's Back!!!!...... Better Graphics, slightly different feel from original mod, but all the best parts and fundamentals are there.   Teams’ selection and load kit implementation is, I guess a necessary evil to be able to be competitive to pacify the BF and COD crowd, but overall pretty good.   My favorite part is jumping into a game and everyone on the other team (we had all speak on so I could hear them talking) ^@!%^ in their pants when I started taking them out and they never saw me coming. So much fun. People literally screamed when I would just come out of nowhere unexpectedly and drop them. I loved it when they tried to move and they realized they made a mistake and I saw them. They would suddenly yell 'Oh my god...He spotted me!! Run!!!'. Just friggin hilarious. None of this 'Ok, let’s strap on the body armor and call in air support with satellite drones and heat sensors and take this dude out. It creates instead a natural human instinct....Run...run or die.   Be honest with yourself. When was the last time you played COD or BF just to have an absolute blast? No really? Not to grind, 'level up', cap out, hit the high score, or to earn some achievement....just to go and have some real fun?  I've played BF and COD and they’ve got nothing like insurgency's ability to make a player AFRAID. In BF and COD, a player tends to get the 'invincible' mentality and feel like you are a war god or something. Drones, air support, helicopters, armor, health kits, battle tanks, 4gaziillion power scopes, etc. Run and Gun and re-spawn....No big deal after a while. I mean come on people! Radar showing you where every player in the map is? For Petes sake people do your eyeballs have a on screen indicator that flashes red in the exact direction the bullet comes from? I mean that’s cool and all, but that right there is what kills the REAL. I find where someone is by the direction the blood of the guy in front me splats. How's that for real?   COD and BF have too much to do in them. Level up, get dog tags, prepare for an airstrike, blah, blah. All in all, it ends up taking away the one thing you actually came to play for.......War. They focus too much on gadgets. Anyone that has ever been in a real firefight can tell you, all that high tech crap goes out the door when you have to start laying down some serious lead just to survive. That is where Insurgency shines. No frills, no super fancy-smancy bells or whistles, no leather appointed interiors. Just you, your team, the weapon in your hand (can you say IRONSIGHTS anyone) and a kill zone around you with your buddies dead and bleeding in front of you and you don't have a DAMN clue who or where they got hit from.   Since there are none of those 'AAA' game gadgets to distract you, you can actually focus of being more into the environment. The sounds of the enemy breathing behind you and the bullets whizzing and ricocheting around and suppression, footsteps and voices just start to rack on your nerves physically and eventually your mind mentally. It becomes viseral somehow. Not like some horror survival thing or Zombies, or anything like that, but just somehow manages to tap into the fear that you are 1 second away from dying and one single mistake and you are going to be watching someone walk over your dead body and no, they aren't there to 'get your tags', they just wanted to make sure you were dead.
the best, realistic FPS iv played in a very long time, few games can match the fresh feeling of this game in a genra that is to say the least over done.  if you get one shooter this year make it this

Refreshing & much needed shake up to the FPS genre. A cocktail of Counter-Strike, Arma, CoD & Battlefield all rolled into one game making it potentially enjoyable for anyone willing to try to give the game a proper chance.  Let me weigh the game up with pros & cons from my perspective for those on the fence about trying Insurgency.  Pros:  - Bullet Damage/Behavour: This game plays quite like an Arma game in the sense that everything tends to operate fairly realistically. You won't be running down the middle of an open road like Rambo, tanking bullets from 4 or 5 guys firing at you like you would in say softcore Call of Duty. 1 or 2 shots depending on the range & calibre of weapon is enough to take you down. It doesn't mean you can't rush in the game, all that it means is that you'll have to be more clever with how you approach your rush. It is hardcore in every sense of the word.  - Weight system/fatigue: Again, draws on the Arma system that if you sprint for 30 seconds then immediately try to aim, it's going to take you a few seconds to compose & steady yourself. The gear you select & it's weight decides how quick you can move, how quickly you can become tired (ie needing time to recover to steady your scope) & how protected you are. You can drop your heavy vest, meaning you'll be able to move quicker, but it will also mean that you may not survive that 1 shot to the chest.  - Shooting mechanics: Very solid, it's hard for me to even name a game that they are similar to. It feels like it has elements of Battlefield, Arma & even Call of Duty & CS (except obviously in this game you can aim down the sight with all weapons).  - Tactics: Very good once more, I've played maybe 10+ multiplayer games & 10+ Co-op games as of right now & on every single one there were people on their mics communicating with each other to achieve whatever the goal might have been. Very reminiscent of how people play Counter-Strike & Arma in particular.  - Game modes: A lot of good & enjoyable game modes that will suit people trying to play coming from any other FPS shooter I can think of. You've got modes similar to S&D, Domination, HQ etc.  - Weapon/Gear Customisation: A variety of attachments & ammunition changes available from the second you fire up the game, no need to unlock them just balance them with the rest of your gear. Every player has a role within their squad & can select the gear best suited to that role.  - Steam Workshop Game: Meaning there will be countless weapon skins, maps, modes, character models available the longer & more popular the game becomes. So long as their is interest in the game new things will be added by talented creators, meaning there will always be something to keep the game fresh.  - Price: I bought my copy in the sale for £7.36, however full price it's £10.99.. very reasonable even for people who just want to give the game a go. The co-op modes alone will provide you & your friends several hours worth of gametime alone making the game good value for money I feel.  Cons  - Character Models: The default character models are probably the weakest thing graphically in the game. They look dated & unfinished. Also in the training mode there is an AI soldier taking you through your training & his mouth doesn't move.. the character models feel dated. Although with Steam Workshop it will be improved by creators eventually.  - Graphics/map textures in general: Graphically the game feels kinda dated.. it doesn't look bad by any means, it just looks dated when you compare it to the likes of Battlefield, Arma 3 or even the latest Call of Duty games. To best some up it graphically would probably be on par with the likes of Call of Duty 4/Modern Warfare 2. Neither of which look bad by any means, they just look dated compared to some of the newer games hitting the market.  - It's a little TOO hardcore at times: I'm all for no radar, no silly juggernaut, dead silence type perks.. but something I'd like is perhaps a kill message that appears in the chat window just to let you know you've killed someone or something. I realise this probably is intentional to make you move up to confirm your kills if you've shot someone who's body has fallen behind cover. But it's something that even Arma games have & it's a war simulater for goodness sake. I'd like kill messages appearing in the chat window that people can either choose to see or ignore.  - Lacks a ranking/statistic & competitive system: Pretty basic, they should impliment the sort of ranking & competitive system that they have in Counter-Strike in which your wins, loses, kills, deaths, accuracy & objective playing statistics impact your rank as opposed to one similar to the likes of CoD/Battlefield. A ranking & competitive 6v6 or 8v8 like system I feel would be good to help the community grow as people do tend to like to know how good they are & what they need to improve on in order to keep the game fresh for themselves.   That's pretty much it, I've got the game & already I regard it quite highly as I do like more tactical games such as Arma, however this has more of a CS/CoD style map handling for their Search & Destroy like missions which is why I'm enjoying this thus far. Would highly recommend it to any fans of Arma, Counter-Strike, Battlefield or even Call of Duty if you fancy a change.

I've now spent over 100 hours playing the Early Access of Insurgency and figured since they are very close to an official release I'd share my thoughts.  This game is very similar to Red Orchestra 2 / Rising Storm. The early access was very fun but felt slightly 'arcadey'. Not anymore. This most recent patch has been a huge step in the right direction. Tactical play and teamwork is a must and running and gunning is now even more likely to get you killed than before.  The developers seem genuinely commited to actively implementing changes based on feedback and creating the best game they can.  The controls have a good tight feeling while still applying the important real world limitations you would expect in a tactical FPS. The developers have made the wise descision to, like RO2, allow for individual adjustment of general movement and ADS (Aim Down Sight) sensitivity. The fact that in 2014 there are still FPS's lacking this feature (BF4 anyone?) is absolutely ridiculous. It is a dealbreaker for me and I refuse to play any FPS lacking it as a feature. So I was very pleased to see that like RO2 it is put to beautiful use here and once you find your balance the controls feel fantastic.  You usually only have 3 to 5 objectives but the overall mechanics are deceptively simple. There are layers of complexity and like any great game it is easy to get into but hard to master. Aiming carries with it the appropriate amount of difficulty such as sight sway, limited movement speed while prone, recoil etc. The 'If you can see it you can kill it' problem that troubles some FPS's is definitely not present here, and seemingly simple shots can be complicated by breathing and other factors.  The kit selection allows you to customize your loadout by spending a limited number of supply points on modifications (AP and HP rounds, scopes, suppressors, barrel mods etc.) These modifications actually have an effect on the performance of the weapon, and the balance on kit items is excellent. Nearly every gun can be used with the stock iron sights (hell yes!) or you can opt to attach a holo sight or 4x score if your play style is more range based. You can choose between light and heavy armor or just skip armor altogether in favor of increased movement speed. Every modification choice is a balancing act and the overall system works well in allowing players to customize their equipment to their individual play style.  The game looks good and the sound design is FANTASTIC, but none of that matters without a solid core of well engineered gameplay, and I'm happy to say Insurgency has that core.   The gameplay is skill based and unforgiving. There is an option for a killfeed but nearly no server runs it. Death comes swiftly and in many forms. You will find yourself suddenly down and have no idea where you were shot from or even who shot you. A seemingly random explosion can take out half of your team while you sit wondering what in the hell just happened. And then you realize... The guy who was peaking out from behind that wall wasn't holding a gun... It was a detonator. And that guy is probably laughing his ♥♥♥ off. The great thing about Insurgency is... Sometimes that guy is you.   I give Insurgency (in it's current state) 4 1/2 out of 5 (Stars? Bullets?) It's honestly just an excellent game overall. I have never written a review for a game before, but for some reason felt a need to for Insurgency. If you like tactical FPS's then THIS is the kind of game you should be supporting.
wow linear realism

Unforgiving. Is the first word I would use to describe this game. It is the lovechild of tactical team-based shooters like CS:GO with the modern finishing of games like Call of Duty and ArmA (ADS, Sprinting, Sliding, Leaning). The guns feel solid and the recoil a real thing. The sounds in the game are spot on. Explosions ring your ears, and you hear the supersonic cracks of bullets flying by. Graphically, the game definitely won't strain your gaming PC. There are some nice set pieces, but it runs on the aging source engine. Definitely not for everyone, if you enjoy games like Rogue Spear ( Damn I'm old ) and Red Orchestra - you will like this game a lot.  DEVS: I would love to see features like a ranking system and persistant stat tracking. You guys are doing a great job, keep the updates coming, and grats on this successful release.

CS:GO meets Red Orchestra. Or.. Red Orchestra: Modern Combat. Sounds cliché enough, but its uncanny how much this game feels like Red Orchestra.   Platform: Source engine, so I didn't expect much. The game is a hyper realistic take on Terrorist vs Counter Terrorists, just like CS:GO, the difference being more of a simulation feel than the arcade feel CS has had since 1.6. I've got to say, I'm unexpectedly hooked. There is no UI, no bullet counter, no automatic reloading, no overhead map, all of these things require attention to manage properly. I have to pay attention to where I am, listen for footsteps and position gunshots in the distance. Strategy is a must. The run and gun mentality isn't present, people talk to each other and watch corners. Very simulation like. A huge emersion factor is the sound, which reminds me a lot of Dayz. Supersonic bullets crackle past you, footsteps are directional and fade with distance, radios and voice chat can be heard within range. You can suppress enemies, meaning if you light up a window a sniper is hiding behind, the sniper's vision gets blurry and his heart rate increases. The weapons are interesting too, some are as old as WW2 era and are representative of what guerilla militia would have to work with. Weapon upgrades are logical: Heavier barrel, optical or red dot sights, for grips. Amours and munitions vests are a trade off to weapons upgrades. It's a game that requires thought and strategy, and actually makes me believe that each round might actually come close to what fighting in an actual battle might be like.   The most ironic thing for me is, I bought the game with money I earned selling all the items I'd won in CS:GO! Apparently the game is under development and will get better. I think its worth $15 as it is.

'When a bullet hits you, face the consquences. Every step the enemy takes may as well be their last. Teamwork is the focal point of Insurgency, and it is why this FPS will be the foundation for what future FPS games aspire to be.'  Insurgency isn't just another vanilla fps that relies on the quick go get-em pray and spray kind of multiplayer FPS that we've all become acustom to these days, but instead in its own right has brought back the realism back to a genre full of too much clutter. It's fresh. It's intense. And it's got substance. It's not a game for those looking to pop off a few rounds and kill an entire squad, but more so for the patient fps gamer who is looking for a fps game with 'teamwork' being its central mechanic.   Albeit, Insurgency may not appeal to most fps gamers because of it's minimal HUD, or lack of features, but at its core, it proves that sometimes simpler is better and that maybe that sometimes when a bullet hits you, you have to face the consequences. But who's not to say Insurgency doesn't come with its fair share of bugs? A beloved mod turned into a standalone game has a lot of work to do, but for the price point you really can't complain. An accomplishment all on its own. It offers a lot for the price being advertised, and the community involved with Insurgency offers more value that you can't get with other FPS games.  The maps blend the nostalgic feeling of many beloved FPS games and incorperates what Insurgency does best. Teamwork! In the game modes in multiplayer may feel repetitive at first, but play with the right team and every go around will play differently and keep you on th edge of your seat. One bullet to the chest and it can be game over. One slip up, and your weapon cache is destroyed. Every action has a reaction and vice versa.   Escorting the vip together, guarding an objective, and trying to out-smart the other team is what makes Insurgency a FPS game that's worth every penny.

Your back is against the corner as you aim down your sights at the point between the objective room and the doorway to your left. Enemies could come from either side. You are completely focused, your hands waiting for any twitch of movement to snap into action. Suddenly, the radio tells you you are the last man standing. Your heart begins to pound. Seconds pass, then minutes. No one drops in. They have to come through here. You just have to wait them out. You don't know how many there are or where they're coming from. You see a head through the window, and jerk towards it, but they pass before you can get a shot off. Did they see you? You break into a cold sweat. Then you see them run in, eyes on the objective. You fire. Bullets ping off the walls as he disappears to the other side of the door. You have to pursue. You run forward, he runs backward, you exchange fire and he drops to the ground. Suddenly, as you back away, his buddy comes in too, and you quickly drop him. Only seconds remain. You're almost there. You cannot believe you survived that gunfight. One wrong move and you would have been dead. You reload, preparing to fire randomly to celebrate your victory as the clock runs out, when in from the other door comes another enemy. He's headed straight for the bomb with time running out, and you instantly riddle him with the bullets you meant to waste. He was the last one on the team. Insurgents win the round.

I am a big fan of realistic shooters. I love the graphics, the mechanics and the general way that the guns work. There are a few things that I dont like, however. One of them, is the way that this game discourages advancing forward, and heavily encourages camping. If you camp in a corner with your sights aimed at the door, you will have 2 opportunities where someone passes by and has absolutely, no chance to live, even if they anticipate that youll be at the corner. You simply have the tactical advantage, and thats the way it is. If you try to advance forward, after scanning the area for enemies, a lot of times youll find that you missed someone by a bare pixel, and youll be instantly dead the moment you are out of cover. I am new to the game, and I probably have those problems since I am new. But thats the whole problem: The game is VERY harsh on new players. I know a game should have a learning curve, but this one is the type of learning curve that could scare people away. The thing with steep learning curves, is that you can see your improvement and have at least a tiny notion that you are gonna get better. In this game, you keep dying instantly for getting out of cover for a mere second, and you just can't see the chance of getting better. Other than the way this game welcomes me as a new player, its great. I'm definitely going to keep playing it.

8/10  Excellent somewhat realistic shooter game that finds a nice balance between two worlds. Those familiar with the old mod will most likely enjoy this shooter. It does suffer from a few bugs and visual issues, but otherwise the weapons look and act nice, the gameplay mechanics are all fairly smooth, and the map/game elements are fairly well done. Insurgency bares quite a resemblance to games like Counter Strike, however it is less of a twitch shooter and more of a tactical team based game where if you get shot, you will drop; you won't be turning around and shooting back...so watch your back and keep moving.  Pros: -Plethora of weapons and gear that all function accurately -Realistic FPS game, without being overly complex or slow -Multiple game modes, dedicated servers, all of the fun things you expect from a source game -Plenty of new and free content regularly.  Cons: -Biggest problem is it's high learning curve, like most tactical shooters. -A lot of downtime waiting for rounds to end and such, but not nearly as much as CS. -Quirky animations and sometiems some small graphical bugs and such.  Updated review because several problems were fixed.

Insurgency is the perfect blend of Red Orchestra 2/Rising Storm style combat with the urban map layouts of Counter Strike. Starting out as a source engine mod, the game definitely looks its age but if you can get over the fact that its not running on the latest greatest engine you'll be welcomed to one of my favorite FPS experiences in a long time.

Insurgency is one of the best tactical based shooters going right now, period.    TLDR: Buy this game. For price to value this game tops BF4, Ghosts, BF3 and MW3 (all arguably) which were 59.99$ titles. This game is 14.99... It's way to cheap for the quality.   IN DEPTH REVIEW   It's game modes are fresh and it has a simple interface which lacks all the gadgets AAA titles give to dumb down content which is a nice step forward in challenging the easing of difficulty in FPS games to make them rely more on percision, tactical awareness, teamwork and cooperation rather than who can spin and click the fastest around corners.  This game is not for the faint of heart however... It has no mini-map and friendly fire definitely exists. Bullets really do what bullets do best. Kill. In Insurgency you're most likely to take 2 rounds before death, 3-5 over my experience either relies on being a heavily armored soldier or luck as the game has a very well balanced damage system based on where bullets hit you. You rely on teammates for supressing fire, which isn't obnoxious like BF3 but it creates a realistic atmosphere of what it may feel like to have a SAW unload on you, you rely on teammates for cover fire, support, positioning... Teamwork is key.  THERE IS NO 'UNLOCKING' OF WEAPONS... I say again that you do not unlock anything. When you purchase Insurgency it doesn't baby you along and expect the only reason you keep playing is to 'prestige' to the next level... Insurgency isn't a game for children, it's war. You get points allocated to your armor, ammo loadout, primary and secondary weapons and explosives. Everyone gets the same points... Everyone is balanced equally.   Insurgency simplifies warfare to a point where it places you as close as you'd ever possibly wish to go to an actual battlefield but it doesn't make the content easy to 'be good at' without your team. Whether you play as an Insurgent (terrorist) or Security (US) you will enjoy the differing challenges associated with your roles and abilities.  Final review? I may be biased because I've been getting tired of AAA titles being terrible (ghosts...) but... 9.5/10  Score factors in price to value ratio, weapon handling, game modes, graphic quality to price, game dynamic etc.

This game is the best tactial multiplayer FPS on the market right now. NWI has done a brilliant job of recreating the urgency and tension of modern combat. The gaming experience is both challenging and fun, without sacrificing realism. If you want a game that provides enjoyment and a healthy fear of bullets, this is it.

I don't think there is much to this game gameplay-wise. You play as a Marine (I think) or an Insurgent. That's the entire content. I guess you could make up a backstory about how your family was killed by American bombs, or your dog was killed by Osama, but the game gives you nothing there. So why is this fun? 1. None of those annoying kids screaming insults at you. 2. Multiplayer (which is the only way to play this game) is insane. One bullet can easily kill you, so people die a lot. Somehow my bullets rarely kill anyone, though :( 3. Limited spawning in most games so games tend to be over soonish. This means I can sneak in a game pretty easiily.   People say 'no crosshair, omg so 1337', but I'm a noob, so I'd rather have the crosshair. But I get that they're trying to make it more realistic, and it doesn't detract much. I shouldn't be shooting from the hip anyway. The graphics are nothing amazing, but I don't really care much for graphics. I can see my gun, I can see the enemy, and I can see myself die. That's all I really need.  Negatives: -Not a fan of the 'ticket' based respawn system: Essentially, your team has a number of spawn tickets. When a spawn event occurs, the team loses one ticket. But it's one ticket regadless of the number of people spawned. I'd much prefer a per-person ticket system so each player spawned reduces one ticket. -No tutorial. That's a constant gripe of mine. The controls are pretty standard, so running around, crouching, going prone, shooting, etc isn't an issue. This only came up for me when I had to put on my night vision goggles and I had no idea what to do. IIRC it's not explicitly defined in the key bindings either. But it was the only usability issue I had.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Very intence game, It may look like a counter-strike knock-off. But its unlike any fps game ive ever played. Community is much more mature than COD, or any other. And pure strategy and skill are what make up this game and how you play.

Think COD4 Promod meets RO2 meets BF:BC2, respectively.  PROS *Tight controls, no mouse acceleration (aside from ADS), clean UI *Best gunplay feel in the past few years *Sound (directional needs some work, though) *Fast matches which reward disciplined, aggressive movement *Stupid 'suppression' effects punish the suppressed but aren't rage-inducing *Game modes feel varied *Wallbanging *Decent community from what I've seen thus far  CONS *Movement fluidity usually limits the player from outmaneuvering other players when caught off-guard; first to shoot is first to kill (intended, but lowers the game's skill cap) *Hit reg feels like 66 tick *TTK is a bit too high *When you think walk speed, think your grandma on a walker with the tennis balls on the bottom *Maps aren't clean and are loaded with debris and clutter (intended, also stupid)

Insurgency is a realistic First Person Shooter that focuses on realistic gun play.  The Really Good:  Fantastic feeling to the guns. Almost anything you can do with a real gun you can do in this game. For example, reloading twice allows you to put am extra bullet in your gun, which is surprisingly helpful.  The Really Bad:  Nothing is really bad, however, the main issue with this game has to be the optimization. The Source Engine is being pushed beyond its limit, causing beautiful graphics with the problem of stuttering and low FPS. (This will likely be fixed with Sandstorm, which will run on Unreal 4. If you wish to see how your computer runs this engine, try Killing Floor 2. If it's well optimized, Sandstorm should run similarly.)

Okay, does this game look like a 2014 game? No, but it looks better than GO, and that's saying something for still being Source.  Superior map design.  Incredible weapon balance.  2-10 second load time FOR THE WHOLE GAME.  Dedicated servers.  Super simple controls and UI.  Lots of guns and maps, and different game modes.  Super realistic weapon behavior.      This is todays Day of Defeat: Source, and it is unimaginably well done for being a former mod. Best $15 I've ever spent on steam.

No vehicles. No killstreaks. No ammo counter. No BS.   Insurgency is the tactical shooter you've always wanted.  This game regularly goes on sale (a week or so ago it was $3!) and it's a great game even for its regular $15 asking price. The combat is deep and tactical, while remaining fun. It's not ARMA level realism, and it shouldn't be-it's that right balance between realistic and fun. There are a good amount of weapons with a lot of weapon modifications such as sights, ammo loads, extended magazines, and foregrips.  The Security and Insurgent teams are imbalanced in a very balanced way-the Insurgent weapons are a bit more dated and advanced weapons are more expensive, but they also have a number of deadly explosives and hit hard. It's not asymmetrical, but the current of battle flows differently for each faction, and it's very fun chaos. Oh, and there are also AP and HP loads for all conventional firearms.  Insurgency runs smoothly and looks beautiful running a recent version of Valve's Source Engine (2011 or 2013? Not sure which.) The bots act a little goofy, but higher-difficulty bots will give you hell compared to bots from TF2 or CS:GO. While, as a Source game, the graphics options are a bit limited, it definitely looks very impressive and it runs like a dream on most modern cards.  There's also a great deal of movement control given to the player, with left/right lean options, prone, and running slides. In addition, the maps have linear objectives but many ways to go about solving them, and all maps support various gameplay modes, both co-operative and PvP, on both day and night settings.  Did I mention co-operative? Yes, this game is also a co-op shooter. You can have a team of 8 people in various co-op gamemodes against bots, from frantic Insurgents surviving an onslaught of Security forces to standard checkpoint games to defend-the-cache survival and so on. And, yes, this game does have night maps-all day maps also have a night version, and they all support all gamemodes. The night combat is just as thrilling as the daytime firefights.  Oh, and it's also a World War II shooter. The officially-supported Day of Infamy mod that places the American and German armies in a conflict on the Western Front is somewhat integrated into the main game, with DoI servers showing up on the server browser in both PvP and co-op, and super easy installation of DoI-just go sub to a workshop collection.  EDIT: Day of Infamy is now its own Early Access title.  This goes hand-in-hand with the way New World Interactive, the developers, treat their community-they are very connected with the players, often have livestreams and Q&As, and are just genuinely nice people.   If all these things don't convince you, I don't think anything will. Buy this game! You'll have a blast.

I'm just gonna put this in two lists: pro and contra.  PRO -Best gunplay I've ever seen in any game -Realistic weapon damage (Except maybe grenades) -Team communication is pretty much always good, even if you don't use the voicechat -Intense gameplay -Cool and atmospheric scenarios  CONTRA -There are always idiot who don't understand 'friendly fire = true' , shoot you in the head and leave.   And now what pi**es me off the most: The game automatically kicks you from any server when your ping is higher than 150. My ping is normally at 200 or 180, well playable. So if you have bad internet, do not buy the game. I tried joining some servers today but I got kicked from every single one. Singleplayer doesn't really work either, there are only certain maps you can use bots on and on those you have to spawn them in using the console which is really annoying.  Not being allowed to play is a MASSIVE contra for me (Duh), so I will give this game, which I love for it's gameplay, only 4/10 points.  *EDIT* So, as you can see, a dev answered this review. The ping kick is not on all servers. I didn't know that, so I guess if I spend a little time with it I'll find a server without. This makes my contra argument invalid and the community service is just amazing.  How about 11/10?

First of all,  THIS IS NOT  the Über-realistic, hardcore experience some people say it is, gameplaywise think of Battlefield with heavier character movement, more recoil, 1-3 shot kills, little to none HUD, and smaller maps. Nonetheless this multiplayer-only game is pretty fun.   The game also has a fair amount of game modes, going from playing with friends vs AI to skirmish which combines 2 game modes in one. Also If you rush in FPS, this game might not be for you. I consider myself a rusher and that lead me to have 8:15 or worse KD in my first matches, if you rush or peak around corners in the middle of the battlefield expect to watch how your teammates play the whole match. Speaking of teammates the community is friendly, active and it is getting bigger. The only thing I dislike about the people playing the game is that everybody is jumping in and out of the server in the middle of a match, there should be a penalty or some kind of auto balance.   So take your time, move in packs, be patient and learn how your team and enemy uniforms look like, I have killed a lot of my mates and spare the lives of some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s having a lucky time due to not knowing if it was on my team or not.  All and all this is a great game, I recommend it if you are looking for a fresh FPS experience and for the price, I think this game worths every penny. I hope the developers keep adding weapons and most importantly maps... cause if I use the 'Find a match' option I almost always end playing on the same 2 maps.

The community is very insensitive to those that live in middle eastern countries.  Indeed, at one point, they began chanting Allahu Akbar, until it morphed into a new word.. they called it..  'Alala Snackbar'  Attrocious. But in all seriousness, this game is one of the best I've ever played in the genre. First of all, when you start the game you will notice the amazing design of overlay and HUD, they nail it on the head with simplicity and excellence. On top of that, this game looks great with the max settings on, I won't lie. But the main core element of this game is the realism, both in gameplay and sounds. Every explosion and gunshot sounds realistic and can change depending on where are in relative position to it. The aiming is executed greatly, with a system where you can hold your breath to increase accuracy, and mount your gun on a tripod when crouching to shoot from lower angles. Every death seems well deserved, and executed in a usually one shot one kill style that is realistic to actual warfare. No one in this game is a bullet sponge by any stretch of the imagination. Even one stray bullet could kill you. The maps in this game are also amazing. They are brilliantly designed and dynamic, with stealth and tactics in mind. They also include day and night cycles for all of them, creating a whole new feel for the maps and new options for the way you fight. Overall, spending a few bucks on this game is well worth it.   Just be aware that the community is a bit immature.

I really love this game. I loved the first Insurgency even though I really sucked at it. I felt that at the time when it was in peak popularity (keep in mind, it was a free source mod) that it was very different than most modern shooters. It was extremely fast-paced and you could just fall on your face and be dead instantly because someone sniped you from a hilltop half a mile away, but that's just the way it really is. This game is currently in Beta and I highly recommend you pick it up now before it rises in price again. I've played the game since the Alpha and there have been some major changes in it. They have completely refaced some of the maps to add more color and so much more, as well as adding new guns and even implemented a class system similar to the first game. When the game first came out into alpha, it was relatively a generic shooter but as it progresses it is picking up more and more of what made the first game unique. There are many attachments for guns, including the type of bullets themselves, that can be purchased in-match with Supply points that you earn by getting kills and completely objectives. Different classes specialize in different weapon types and sets, with some classes having you spawn with decked-out weapons that you would otherwise have to pay supply points for all of the attachments. To clarify, Supply points are not a real-money currency, but are only present during a single match. They are received and spent in-match and do not travel over to other matches. This game has come a long way from the Alpha and I am very sure that this company will continue to expand on their new take on this game, as well as continue to modernize and consequently re-implement maps from the first game, some of the most interestingly layed-out maps I have ever played in a multiplayer-based shooter. Pick this game up while it's still cheap, as I'm sure the price will go up once the game continues on its way out of beta.

Set in the year 2017, Insurgency allows you to play as either Trump™ Mercenaries or Militant Mexicans in the battle to build the wall.  12/10 Liberalism is a disease.  In all seriousness, Insurgency is a great game. It looks sub-par by today's standards yet seems to have a very convincing feel to it. It is much like a dream in that it immerses you, yet after you wonder why it seemed so real. While some might see things like swearing as cheap modernization, it seems more in line to realism, in character and out. For example, when you get suppressed in most games, you might hear bullet impacts and maybe you alerting your team on voice chat but not much else. In Insurgency, you hear the supersonic cracks and bullet impacts along with your frantically assembled speech while your screen blurs. You don't even have to say things like 'Holy ♥♥♥♥, dude!' after an RPG flies by, the game does it for you!

This really brings me back to the firefight feeling of Day of Defeat Source mixed with the 'I have no idea where he is' from something like Arma, well, maybe not as extreme. Sitting behind a truck as you struggle for cover while bullets bounce off every surface is something that this game does very right. When bullets hit the clinking noise as well as the effect are terrifying and immersive, as well as the echoed gunshots.  Gunplay is another thing this game has gotten very, very right. The way hip-firing doesn't just shoot straight ahead but you can adjust it to fire slightly to the edges of your screen, recoil and screen shaking, and the sheer volume of the weapons compared to other things make gunplay extremely satisfying and challenging. Landing a hip shot as you burst into a room of a guy standing in a dark corner of the room, destroying the counter that was right behind him and watching all the bottles and pots that were on it go flying is the coolest thing.  And the sheer size and scale of the maps, but the way they are focused make for dynamic, tense and altered gameplay without it getting boring or leaving you saying 'I just want something to happen' is a feet within itself.  This is one of the best multiplayer FPS games I've gotten my hands on in a while, and for 15$ that kind of quality is nothing to pass up. I'd recommend this game if it was a 30$ title.

Pros: -Good shooting and cover mechanics. -Good variety of modes.  -Hardcore, 'realistic' gameplay. -Good servers and tickrate.  Cons: -Some modes and maps are unbalanced. -The game can get tedious. -Depends on teamwork a lot. -Looks outdated in some areas.   Insurgency is a hardcore FPS that revolves around methodical gameplay and strategy. I expected the game to be harder to access and get used to, but I was hooked and did well in just few matches; the reason behind that is no stupid controls and low tickrate.   Controls were nice; they were fast and responsive, and didn't control like some 100ms lag tanky Battlefield ♥♥♥♥. The damage is high, and weapons have a strong recoil and weapon kick. Hip-firing actually works (due to high damage), but you will most likely be going from cover to cover and carefully observing and clearing each area. Team work and map knowledge is required too.  The maps (get used to suburban, middle-east/iraq-like maps) are nice, and the modes are fun and unique. There are some issues in the maps where some teams are more favored and have access to better routes, but they are not glaringly broken.    I would recommend the game to anyone who is looking for a change from the generic online shooters and how absurd they can get. Be warned though, as Insurgency is supposed to be a slower-pace, lame game--a combination of chess with shooting/dexterity requirements.

What can I say, like I said in the review for Guns of Icarus Online, this is not a game for everybody. I got this while I had a timeout on CS:GO, me being quite an avid CS player along the years. It's definitely hardcore, you can die in one hit and most of the times you WILL. At the time of writing this review the game is really not that well optimised, not running that well on a GTX 560 when more graphic-intensive games run better.. You can also say it's more or less a work in progress. The game is fairly complete, but many updates are being released regularly, and you can see that the vision of the devs is quite a few updates away.  There is a 'coop' mode and 'versus' mode. The 'versus' mode being Team Deathmatch and objective-based maps, and the 'coop' being you playing against AI enemies on the same objective-based maps from 'versus' mode. I can say I had the most fun on the 'coop' mode. Like any online team game, you need to get matched with fairly decent players to have fun, and many people are still noobs at this game, running and gunning instead of being tactical, but fortunately the game offers you options to educate them, via team chat or microphone. So 'coop' mode is very fun, but if you're not satisfied you can try the more competitive 'versus' mode.

I can't come up with something funny at this time, so I'll make a normal review.  Now Insurgency is a great game, with the night time being my favorite option due to the added intensity of not knowing where the bullets are coming from.  A few things that I disliked about this game was the auto healing. I'd prefer a medic kit type of healing if any healing at all, and the medic kit wouldn't be a spammable option and you'd have to wait out the effects.  The 'Competetive' 5v5 game mode is a heavy joke for a person like me used to the competetive scene of CSGO, which in it's own right is a joke. You can drop in and out as you please, and it's not very fun. There's no competetive ranking in the game, only the normal mod ones.  Now this isn't to say I don't enjoy this game, albiet not playing it very often. If the competetive mode had a ranking system and a no-drop-out style I'd log hours upon hours on this game.  Recommended.

Having played this game for more than Steam states (around 50hrs compared to 28) I have learnt of the excellence of this game. There are a number of reasons why this is.  1. Controls - More cmplex than your aaverage fps but not like ARMA. Nice control over a fairly agile character that makes it a lot of fun.  2. Atmosphere - The game has awesome moments on most modes and maps that really are great advertisements of the game such as when you are trying to capture the last point on push and both the attackers and defenders have not reinforcements left.  3. Difficulty - The game has a punishing amount of room for error as many guns need only one headshot to take you down armor or not. Weapons like the AK are almost unstoppable if you leave yourself weak on one side.  4. Performance - This game performs perfectly since the recent update on MY LAPTOP. To me that is ludicrous as many games perform poorly with way lower requirements.  5. They're still updating - The last update was awesome and brought a new map, loads of new weapons including a revolver :D and also have reinvigorated the community.  6. Range of weapons - There are a lot of weaons in this game that suit a different playstyle. On one match of push the attacking side my use the M16A4, a burst fire/semi-auto rifle while the defenders may use an ak. Also for each class there are a number of weapons that can be used differently.

Insurgency is a mix between the two popular video game franchises known as Call of Duty and Counter-Strike. I was sceptical at first, because I had read that Insurgency lacked important aspects to a FPS such as crosshairs, ammo counter, no mini-map and no kill notification. I started playing though and realised that the lack of these made the game so much more realistic than Counter-Strike and Call of Duty. I believe that those 2 video gaming giants could learn a thing or two from this great indie game. Since playing this for the first time, it has become my favourite FPS and a good way to blow off steam. I would recommend this game to anyone wanting to play a shooter with a bunch of their friends.

Crepe Recipe: Serves 8  -1 cup all-purpoused flour -2 eggs -1/2 cup of water -1/4 teaspoon of salt  -1/2 cup of milk - 2 tablespoons of butter melted  Directions In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the flour and the eggs. Gradually add in the milk and water, stirring to combine. Add the salt and butter; beat until smooth. Heat a lightly oiled griddle or frying pan over medium high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each crepe. Tilt the pan with a circular motion so that the batter coats the surface evenly. Cook the crepe for about 2 minutes, until the bottom is light brown. Loosen with a spatula, turn and cook the other side. Serve hot. Enjoy and BTW buy the game

The game has a refreshing multiplayer experience, it's a tactical oriented gameplay so you'll need to play with friends or have a mic'. Any of the gamemode proposed are objective-oriented and there is no room for CoD's tankers. The particle and sound effects are well done, even better than some AAA games out there. You can't judge the graphics since this is using the Source engine but they are promizing. The fact they support the Workshop and don't have planned a list of DLC is a cool move.   However, they have a lot of work in optimizing the game for pople having a low end computer, it's still playable but you will encounter some lags in-game and it can even make Steam freeze sometime. And I've noticed some minor random bugs in the physics side of things.   If you've played Arma 3, battlefield, Counter Strike and/or Call of duty MW3's hardmode then this game should be familiar to you. But be aware, it is nothing compared to the previously quoted titles, the gameplay is much more frustrating and you MUST be vigilant. Skill matter here.  Finally, I do recommend this game but you'll need a clean computer or a decent rig to make work at the moment.   Final verdict of 9/10 as it is for now and I'm sure it will continue evolving in the right side of the gaming industry.

I'm a big fan of realistic shooters and Insurgency does a great job of scratching that itch for intense combat. The maps aren't as expansive as Squad or Arma, but they're still very big. I actually find myself playing Insurgency more now over Squad because the smaller maps put you into combat quicker. The sound design is very good, you get all the bullet snaps and cracking and your charcaters even yell when they're getting shot at or performing actions.  For $15 this game is a great buy, and yet they STILL put the game on sale for 85% off of that.   Overall a must-have for fans of military/realistic shooters. My only complaint would be the lack of a medic class.

Where zombies come none stop, and you can't sit in a corner bash away your mouse 1, cause they will flank you.  The Skirmish I haven't touched much, but it's far easier than brutal AI for Co-op with the aimbot snipes from cross the map just abusing the mental dexerity on your 3rd, 4th and 5th try. If Vac bans applied to bots this game would be banned.  The community has a mixed age group, with varing degrees of try-hard mil-sim aspects to it. Insurgency is a game where there is no HUD. That means it doesnt tell you how much ammo or health you have left. There is also no mini-map. You may be thinking, well thats stupid. No. The reason for this is so that the game is very realistic. This game is not like COD where you can just run to the objective. You have to check your surrondings and make sure all the enemies are cleared out before capturing something. Note: there is also friendly fire. When you get shot, your screen will blur up a bit. Also it only takes about 3-5 bullets to kill you. The reason I love this game so much is that It is so realistic, it makes it harder to play but more fun altogether. I see a lot of people say this game is a lot like CS:GO because of the graphics. The graphics may not be the best out there, but they beat CS:GO. I'd say this game is a lot like Battlefield 4.  ~11/10 Watch out for RPG's.

OMG. I am a huge battlefield player and I also enjoy LevelCaps videos. So, I was so happy to get a gaming rig and try out Insurgency! I have played around 20 hours of it and I can tell you that if you are a Battlefield fan then just stick with Battlefields Hardcore mode. This game has zero simliarities to Battlefield and IMO, it is extremely Overrated. Heres why:  Its boring.  Here is the gameplay: Spawn in. Run a little bit. Then Camp. Wait to see a guy or maybe two and get a kill. Or get instant killed. Then, wait 15 seconds to respawn. Rinse and Repeat.  Theres no flow to the game what so ever. I can see why people like this game but coming from a Battlefield background, there are no similiarites. I could never see myself putting 1000+ hours into this game like I have for every single battlefield.

But here we go with the problems during the Singleplayer Experience:  -Friendly AI sucks... They're really useless during firefight, they die almost instantly leaving you all alone to fight like 20 jihadi's. And the game pretend you to win.  -Another dumb thing, the game gives you just +3 Men plus you = 4 soldiers in total to fight a whole army of enemies. That's dumb, unrealistic and almost an impossible game experience.  -9 times out of 10, there's an annoying glitch with the Friendly AI that makes them like spinning around you like magnets. The thing itself is not annoying just because they spin around you for no actual reason, but because they begin to stalker you until they can spin around you and make your character move (without pressing any button) on the right and left. Basically due their body contact with your 'virtual body' you get pushed with them.  -Another problem with the SOLO Gameplay Experience, is that is not realistic at all. You really don't fight the enemies like in a real war. They simply spawn here and there, after getting triggered by some 'Checkpoint' on the map. It's freakin' dumb and i don't really find the terms to explain how stupid this way to make a game really is. This game pretends to be realistic, but no, it isn't and i'm worried if Insurgency ever will be.  Basically in few words, what this game pretends to be is a Low-Res version of Battlefield 3, nothing less and nothing more of that. Another bad game. This one has been advertised as some kind of realistic game for those who are tired of Battlefield and similar shooters and their shortcomings. Through various Youtube channels this message has been hammered. However, it fails in exactly the same regards as its big brothers: poor netcode, tons of hackers and haphazard gameplay that does not reward skill. Here we have a floating camera type of game with one-shot kills and 'realistic weapons'. Footsteps are close to impossible to hear, even if a player is running on a concrete floor next to you. Accordingly, the gameplay quickly becomes the blind chicken-gameplay Battlefield and COD are so famous for, albeit with much more camping. And just what is with one-shot kills that is supposed to be 'realistic'? Would you automatically fall unconscious/die after being hit by 5.56 round? Really? Is this how reality works? You could say I'm being nitpicky about some of this games rather unsufferable shortcomings but I'm not this game is ♥♥♥♥ in a lot of areas and to any preferred tactical shooter this is never a good thing.  Insurgency provides a fair amount of weapons and attachments for these weapons - clearly inspired by Battlefield - and the weapons admittedly have a great feel to them. But the contrast between the 'realistic weapons' and the rubberbanding players running around at a speed that is anything but realistic, leaves me unimpressed.   At best this is a better version of Counter-Strike:Source.

Welcome to game with probably the worst designed everything I've ever seen. Map design alone is horrendous with one map having you run out of a tunnel into the enemies direct line of fire from their spawn at the very start. Horrible. I've describeed this game as 'The developers took the worst parts from CS:GO and ARMA and combined them into a game.' Im sure you'll see reviews about how 'tactical, and team based it is.' That's an out right lie. You still have everyone running all over the map lone wolfing it, even when there is only one objective to defend people still just do how they please without supporting the team. Gun play is 'meh' at best. Sure you kill people with an average of two bullets but its so lack luster and shooting is so clunky it's hard to feel any sense of enjoyment. More time than not you'll get shot when in cover, or you'll try to shoot through something that is 1 way bulletproof, usually the other guys side, sorry. Kills don't feel rewarding and deaths don't feel justified. And that is a combination that ruins a players experience. Now I know the screenshots make it look squad based and team focused but you'll encounter hackers, the grenade spamming is off the charts, lone wolfers, etc. Also the head glitching is probably the worst I've ever seen in a game. Eyes are not necessary it appears as the top of a helmet or turban suffices for an enemy to mow you down. And the top of headwear dont register as places you can shoot so you are severely at a disadvantage. I havn't had a single moment of fun or enjoyment from insurgency aside from maybe the funny tutorial dialouge. I would say avoid it and try to find something else. If you want team based shooting try to get into the upper tiers of CS:GO competitive, if you want open maps and MILSIM style engagements pick up ARMA 3. I hope this review swayed you towards not picking up such a mechanically frustrating game.  Edit #1- Corrected spelling

Use to be a good game. Now, not so much. The Dev's, like so many others, never seem to address the main issues of their game. For starters, Source Engine but not much anti-cheat in this game other than what VAC gives. Lots of wallhacks from what I have seen in games. NEVER have I seen a single ban from this game. I can tell you right now, the anti-cheat is no bueno!  Secondly, no matter how much 'safety' you have in your spawn, it does not stop you from being spawn killed by other players. Yep, spawn and insta-gibbed. Wait another minute to respawn. Another broken system in this game.  Third, goes back with your spawn protection. The maps are pretty much gauntlets with not much room to move around. You are pretty much forced to fight head-on every game. If you DO happen to flank an enemy, you will be met with a 'Restricted Area' notice, where you cannot do anything but turn around and take one in the back. Yep, this game doesn't reward tactics, only latency.  Is this a good FPS? Well, it could be worse. Do I have fun playing it? I use to, when you could tell everyone was on an equal playing field. Would I recommend? Nope! I would tell you to go play Arma 3 if you are looking for something realistic and tactical.

I should start off by saying that this game isn't a bad game; I like the concept, and I like that they're going for a realistic feel. There's no hit indicator, no ammunition count (especially concerning how many rounds are still in your clip/magazine), and a very minimalistic HUD that doesn't allow you to spot your enemies or see your squad's movements through walls. All of these things create a much more realistic experience than you would get if you were playing something like COD. I like the concept, as I said earlier, but I feel as though the verisimilitude is lost on gamers due to technological limitations. In real life, you'd be able to hear where the enemy (and your squad) is better than you would in a game; you'd have better communication than you would in a game; you'd be able to better understand your injuries and your capabilities than you would in a game (there's no health idicator in Insurgency, so you don't know how much health you have). While this game does provide a fun experience for people who want a more realistic alternative to games like COD, I would still say that it falls short of what it is aiming for. I would say that this game would be totally worth it if it supported Occulus Rift in 4k resolution, if you also had high-quality headphones on that supported surround sound, and if you had a mic. Then you would have a more realistic experience and be more capable of reading and interpreting your environment. As it stands, the games minimalistic approach is not suitable for people who have a single monitor and mono (or even stereo sound). Without the features that make up for the fact that you're playing a computer game (i.e. hit indicators, health, spotting, etc.) the game isn't able to give you a solid understanding of your environment.  I also think that the game - being a source engine game - is quite similar enough to the Counter Strike games that you could purchase the Counter Strike games and get a more computer gaming friendly experience. As it stands, Insurgency feels like a graphically suped up Counter Strike game with a minimalistic HUD. If that is an experience you're looking for, then give Insurgency a shot; if not, then you could just purchase or stick to Counter Strike and you won't be upset for having done so.

Where to start...  Lets start with the AI in this game. ( I've only played hardcore Co-Op ) Its like playing a 2003 game as far as AI goes. They are dumb but can 1 shot you from a kilometer away.  Multiplayer : Camp, Camp and more camp. Almost no one goes for the objective.  Graphics : Uhm.. it looks like a 2003-2005 game. And it still cant hold 60fps.Even though my rig far exceeds the recommended settings.  Community : Awfull.  Gameplay : I mean.. it adds something cool when u cant see if you hit or killed an enemy.. but it can also be verrrrry annoying. Also 9/10 times when u get killed, you have no idea where that lethal shot came from, but you know it will be from a cornercamper. Hitboxes are REALLY weird in this game. You might think you nailed that headshot only to find out it wasn't a hit and then u get 1 hitted by a spraying enemy.  Be prepared for a lot of waiting while ur dead. Sometimes this can take up to 1 minute, which is a part of the game i understand but it doesnt help it one bit.  I mean i guess it could be fun if you have a full team with people who know what they are doing, but pub is just a mess with campers in every corner.  I cannot reccomend this game to anyone to be honest. It was far better years ago when it was still a free mod. It rocked back then. But now.. there are waaaay better 'tactical' fps games. I use the word tactical lightly as it only stands for camping in this game. Its like Rainbow Six Siege... but with more corners to camp in. NOTE: before you read this review, you should know that it's mainly about the Multiplayer.  Pros:  - Insurgent players shout ''Allahu Akbar'' into the mic when they use explosive gadgets or win a round (I almost died of laughing) - real good Atmosphere of War - realistic Gunplay  Cons:  - too many Players use highly zoomed scopes, regardless wich weapon they use, it makes players who walk around an easy target - Maps are too big so players can hide everywhere ( I almost drived crazy, because I get killed before I even spot them) - too many windows, rooftops and corners that offer marksmen a nice camping area - enemy AI is absolutely fanatic of RPG's; if you stay more than 5 seconds infront of an enemy in long range, prepare to get blasted away with a rocket  4.5/10  My Opinion and the Rating on this Game will probably change, when I get used to it but right now, I'm filled with despair and frustration and I didn't have fun on this Game a single minute.

Bug-filled mess with virtually no future nor prospects for fixes.  Pros:  Can be fun. Great realism. Large pool of guns and roles. Gun mods make gameplay unique.  Cons: God awfully optimized. (Sub-60 FPS with a GTX 970 and a 6600k on LOWEST settings 1080p) Aim is horribly inconsistent and 'floaty'. Sensitivity is different for all 3 aim modes, (Hip, Iron, and Scope) and never feels right between the 3. Video settings take at least 1-2 minutes to take effect, and you're stuck with annoying looping audio as the menu loads. Playerbase is dwindling, with only about 2k players on worldwide at any given point. Competitive play is all but dead. Map pool has not been updated, and the game modes are stale and repetitive.  Due to the above 2 reasons, the game lacks visceral intensity, and makes for matches that border on completely casual. Graphics are not at all impressive, and rather aged looking, surprising considering how intensive the game is on rigs.

Boring game. If you already have CS, you may as well stick with that.  There is also a small matter of hit detection and weapon balance. I can pump about 4-5 rounds into an enemy and he might get a bit wounded, but he won't die (bearing in mind I ALWAYS use AP rounds, rifles and pistols). That same enemy could easily turn around and kill me with 1-2 rounds. *Some* people could be cheating, it's a possibility, but more often than not, it's just the game being a prick (Yes, that's right. The game itself is a prick)!  Also, I am a casual gamer. The only thing I'm truly hardcore about is simulators, racing sims to be precise, so I'm not very good at this type of game.   Which is a problem.   Most people who play this aren't too dissimilar from COD players in the sense that they play it so religiously that it's borderline unfair on newbies like myself, which is why I personally think the game would benefit from a system like Blacklight Retribution where certain levels mean access to certain servers, so noobs can fight noobs and pro's can fight pro's. A noob vs a pro just isn't fair, I can't get into the game and I only ragequit whilst contemplating why I even bought this in the first place... Doesn't exactly inspire me to keep trying!  One final thing - a LOT of people **will** scream 'ALLAH ACKBAR!!!!' when they're on the Insurgents team. One simply **must** learn to love this, or else one will find it funny for a little while, then one will begin to get annoyed very quickly after. Hell, they may even do it on the Security force team. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED!  If you have CS, don't bother with this, you won't even need this. It's not as good. I can't speak for CS:GO, never played, but even CS Source is more fun than this.   If you're a casual gamer, don't bother. You won't have fun with this.   If you don't like hearing the same jokes over and over again, don't bother.   Don't even care if this review gets bad ratings, I think these are valid points. You're better than this! You don't need this, run whilst you still can.  On the upside, oh, wait.... Nope. There isn't really much of an upside.  All in all, I give this a 4/10.   TTFN xxx
