Insurgency feels like a very bland military simulator set in the Middle East. The graphics themselves are shabby, as are many of the maps. The fighting that occurs and the gunfights are very redundant, as all weapons seem to have the same damage count, but with different accuracy and limitations. The game is physically so realistic, that it takes no skill in any sort of firefight, other than knowing the map locations. It barely takes any shots from your gun, to kill the enemy. There is little reaction that can be done once you are fired upon. The learning curb is so small, it makes PVP frustrating since it's more of a camp and wait sort of game type. COOP with your friends, allow you to take on the AI, and even they possess less of a challenge, as you can easily kill them.    I've read that it's hardcore… not really. Again, a very small learning curb. You'll kill just as many people, in PVP, as you'll die. The game's vanilla maps, all set in the same general geographic location (save for some), tire a player out, and custom maps allow some extensibility.    Yes, you can assort your weapons and your equipment, which makes the game appeasing, but how many other games do that with better benefits? That does partially give you an advantage in any fair fight, but the guns have almost the same capabilities, when placed with each other. You can hardly notice the difference between an AKM and an AK-47, other than the design of the gun on your screen. Changing your bullet type won't even hinder a difference. Now there are some weapons out there that are so very poorly done (Shotguns), but other than them, the Rifles all tend to mimic themselves.   The game can be considered a very hardcore realistic shooter, but it's bland. It's the same ordeal every time.
It really sucks. Gameplay feels clunky and slow. Wouldn't recommend. Even on sale

Take to the streets for intense close quarters combat, where a team's survival depends upon securing crucial strongholds and destroying enemy supply in this multiplayer and cooperative Source Engine based experience. The follow-up game to the award-winning Source mod, Insurgency is highly competitive and unforgivingly lethal, striking a balance between one-life gameplay and prolonged action.

Insurgency feels like it's missing somthing. It doesn't feel complete, also if you're one for graphics, this may not be the FPS for you. The sound effects in this game have impressed me from the start. It's not terrible, don't get me wrong, however if you're more of a cs player this is way to slow paced.   While already extremely playable, I would wait a bit as this game gets updated and irons out the bugs. I havn't been keeping up with the developtment of the game, however I think a system of ranking or gaining levels or somthing would add an incentive to play. I wouldn't be shy about giving this a try as it's listed at a good price.

It's stunning when it works. My first thought upon joining a match was 'War is hell.' Despite running on a very old engine, the visuals pop well, and the gameplay is very tense. Every death matters, you know that, and you know beyond a shadow of a doubt that shooting without aiming is a recipe for disaster.  But constant server lag, often so bad that others on the server will point it out over voice chat, is an even more potent recipe for disaster. It's a shame that the server side of this game seems to be so poorly designed, because this lag is 100% of the reason I stopped playing this game.   The action is tense, the visuals are surprisingly great, the audio is even better, but unless you're planning on playing on LAN instead of over the internet, give this one a pass.

How this game got such high ratings, I'm amazed. It really makes my word seem like nothing.  This game was pretty fun for the first 5 hours of playing it, as I enjoy realistic FPS's thoroughly and thought it would be a cool to play one set in modern times.  However, this game I HIGHLY do not reccommend.  It's literal design is to make you think 'Wow, $15 is pretty cheap. Im gonna buy it.' and then you play it for 20 hours or so before you stop playing it permanantely. Is it really worth spending $15 to have 15 hours of fun? Maybe. Depends on your financial situation.  This game is fantastic for squads of friends to play against each other, but usually ends up like this;  Round starts, everybody throws cheap to buy frags across the map and kills over half of each others teams without skill. Continous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t ensues, with the players who dont have 200+ hours getting ridicoulously mad at each other and at the other team. One team wins constantly, usually 6 and 0. You rarely will find balanced teams. When teams ARE scrambled, things somehow always find their way back to where they started.  My biggest problem was overall gameplay. Your gun doesn't shoot for some reason, the game saves your previous weapon fire-selection so when you get into close-quarters you shoot one round instead of fully-auto, tons of people have a glitch where they aim straight up and cant fix it until they restart the game (and it comes back), and also how terrorists get amazing equipment, did I mention random calls?  'RELOADING COVER ME' when you're the last guy alive doesn't help you very much.  Look, I know that the game is trying to be fair, but when a terrorist using surplus 1952 grenades from the USSR is BETTER than a united states frag, something isn't right. It seems that terrorists have little to no recoil while the US ♥♥♥♥ing flies everywhere, and in it goes against everything a Kalashnikov stands for.  Once more, if you've read all of this, I congratulate you. You're one of the few to do so.  I may just suck at it to an extremely unrealistic amount, but I've played tons of FPS's (Red Orchestra/Rising Storm, Battlefield(s), CODs, those are what I mostly did/do) and I'm good at them, but this was just ♥♥♥♥ing abysmal.  Only the best players with 200+ hours can thoroughly enjoy this game all around it seems. The rest quit after 20+ hours.  Dont buy it unless you're making $20+ an hour at an easy job and can waste the money

The newest EDIT: Steam library/Insurgency/support/I want to permanently remove this from my account/OK DONE :)  Original: First of all, what the heck is wrong with the optimization? Truth be told, my computer is not exactly a rocket, but the graphics is not that damn beautiful for me to be forced to put every setting on low and still get lags while I'm able to run nicer and newer games almost maxed out. It crashes everytime I alt+tab too. Take this review as a warning that if you wanna play Insurgency, you're gonna have to sacrifice a few hours on fixing problems. Devs will recommend workarounds instead of really fixing them.  Secondly, I played a few rounds and all I saw were the same modes and same gameplay that millions of other first person military shooters offer. So this is nothing extraordinary OR I didn't feel it in it. Although I liked the option to apply different parts to your weapons, like scopes and various bullets, according to what you prefer.  I got this game by accident because my friend had a few spare copies for which I'm grateful, but I don't see myself playing this after the  terrible performance issues that are not on my side . I am not a military lover and still I'm trying to judge this game objectively but understand that I simply cannot recommend a game this badly optimized. I'm sorry but this is barely   4/10     EDIT 3/30/15:

Update: This review got more attention than any of my reviews so I decided update it  One thing I wanted to add was that I now have logged almost 40 hours in the game because I have had a few realizations. Here they are:  1. There is nothing else like this. What I mean by this is there is no other multiplayer shooter that takes place in the middle-east between Security Forces and Insurgents. Not counting the shooters that are in the middle-east but involve the whole Russian influence thing. This is a pure Iraqi War themed shooter.  There is games like Arma, but it's really intense simulation style of play [not sure about 3], Call of Duty, and I could name more. But for $14.99 it is a really good deal for those wanting a military shooter. And to reiterate....no other shooter with this theme...that has a relatively big size community. If there is, show me.  2. You eventually forget about some of the cons. All the rage enduced fits paid off. All those times of dying cause I get stuck on terrain no longer make me so angry. The obvious hit detection mistakes are only noticible if you are intently watching. The night maps are not a bother cause you know what to look for in the dark even with the blinding light bulbs that you can't shoot out. Why? Because I am so used to them it doesnt bother me. It's a list of mistakes that you eventually learn how to work around.  3. I still can not recommend this game. Why? It is most deff. not for everyone. And a lot of my friends I have convinced to try this game usually complain about the same things I did and quit before getting used to them. NO ONE wants to learn around the mistakes WHILE learning how the game works. Take Arma for example. I got it recently for the DayZ mod. I learned how to play the game in the campaign, went to DayZ, killed some people, played a little bit of ACE [it's a mod] and kill some more and guess what? I didn't get killed because of flawed game mechanics. Insurgency is good but at the end of the day it asks you....'Do you recommend this game?' not 'Do you like this game?'   Original:  I really really really REALLY REALLY wish there was a inbetween option called maybe or mixed.  Insurgency is one of those games I'll probably have over 20 hours in [15.3 as of this review] and I'll get those people who say 'Oh you gave it a negative review but you still put time into it?' So I am going to explain why I like and dislike this game and why I decided to give it a thumbs down.   for the people who don't want to have to read a long and drawn out review--here is the pros and cons list with a section I include called 'Both' where it depends on who you are if it is a pro or con.  Pro: Intense gameplay due to the lack of informational hud [ammo in the clip, mini-map, etc.] Realistic Gun Mechanics Realistic damage [you die in a few shots] Achievements  Both: Teamwork is required to win Score is more than important than kills [You can go killess and be high up on the leaderboard] Night Maps that require night vision goggles or flashlights Suppression Maps from the mod Different classes that have unique weapons from the other classes No Medics No Bulletdrop Friendly Fire No vehicles No Killstreak rewards  Cons: Often get stuck on small objects or terrain Hit detection seems [to me] to be off sometimes Invisible walls around terrain keep you from shooting [you aim over a rock but still hit it] Maps are really straight foward and small Spawn killing is rampant People [I'll explain later]  Now that we got that out of the way time for the explaination of some of those things  The maps are so small. Some are Call of Duty big and some barely meet the size of the smallest Battlefield maps. If you ever played Mag on PS3 then you got the idea of the map size. Some maps seem to be huge but there is restricted areas for both factions. You can only go so far behind the map of the other team. Which is good I guess, but it still doesn't eliminate spawn killing....but I'll get to that after this rant. I am not one of those guys that want earth sized maps. I personally think GTA 5's map is a little too big. The reason I wish the maps were bigger is due to the realistic gun play. Hip firing is pretty much no scoping with a sniper rifle. Even if you have a lazer light or a fore grip the gun will go uncontrollable if you hip fire. Not saying that is bad, but on a map where close quarters is 85% of the time the realism of gun mechanics just make the game feel....clunky. Iagine if call of duty or battlefield had realistic kick and climb. Battlefield wouldn't have been too bad, but if it happened to Call of Duty it would just end up in people getting lucky.   I'll use Rising Storm as an example. The maps aren't exactly the largest maps in the world, but their open terrain and lack of buildings creates less of close quarters and more of shoot outs. There could be a squad of guys in a pillbox firing at your little nest in the trees. It's an intense game of 'who is more accurate' instead of 'who was able to control the kick in a corridor.   Maybe I am the only one who has beef with the gun mechanics mixed with the small maps, but It bothers me. Love the gun mechanics, hate the map size.  Wonder why I said people? Why is that a con? One thing I will defend Call of Duty on is that one guy can win it for the team. In Insurgency you could win it alone but it is highly unlikely. While I love teamwork games, I play this mainly by myself so I can talk to someone in skype and create atleast a 2 man team. It comes to me putting faith in trust in my team which usually bites me right on the bottom. Any game that requires teamwork is going to be fustrating and annoying. Quite frankly, the majority of Insurgency players never go pile up on the objective when there is only 20 seconds left and no waves. It seems like either no one knows how the game works, or they want a positive K/D ratio.  Rising Storm had the same problem only a million times worse....just proof teamwork is annoying unless you have friends  Speaking of Kills......spawn killing....holy crap is spawn killing a son of a beach. Restricted areas would make you think you can't spawn kill but oh boy they don't. On the map Sinjar....oh Lord Sinjar....there is a spawn for Insurgents where if you run straight out of spawn [the direction you are facing] you can get sniped. Spawn sniped, spawn sniped. Eventually I learned to go left or right. I shouldn't have to take a detour, but that spawn makes you since it is so dumb. Every map with the exception of maybe one or two have this problem.   If don't understand what I mean by the invisble wall on objects and terrain I'll paint you a picture. On the map Peak I was on the Insurgent team using the SKS with a Kobra sight, fore grip, and AP rounds. I run to a rock, peak around the corner, aim down the sights and shoot at a Security Force squad charging towards me. I fire and all that happens is dust gets kicked up. I was shooting the rock appartently, and the Security dudes shot me to death. It happens to me all the time. It drives me insane.  For me, Night Maps suck. You can't shoot out light bulbs so when you are using NVGs sometimes you'll be blinded. But if you take'em off you can't see nothing past that light bulb. So Now I use NVGs and flashlights to ensure I can see at all times. It's a minor inconvience but it gets me killed.   A lot of my complaints are minor and don't happen all the time. Getting stuck on small objects and terrain doesn't happen too often but when it does it's annoying. This is why I give Insurgency a negative review. I didn't have to get used to the controls or gameplay or anything like that. I had to get used to the clunky mechanics and the minor problems. I like the game, but as far as recommending it I have to say it depends on your patience.   Since there is more things wrong with this game that right....I have to give it a thumbs down

I would probably describe this as a mix of CounterStrike, America's Arma, Call of Duty, Arma and a noteable piece of Red Orchestra. Now, what does it mean if a game is a mix of every other major title in it's genre? It's generic.  You got guns, you got a minimalistic hud, shots easyly kill, 'realistic' firing models, stuff like that. Sure, that was innovative once and it's still not a standard, but it's nothing spectacular either. You got a few 'classes', but since you can fully change the loadout for most classes to whatever you like (with a few minimal limitations on primary weapons) this came really can't be called class-based. CQC maps play fast and action-heavy, strongly reminding me of AA or CS, whilst long-range maps play like RO or Arma (whoever spots first lives longer). All already done. 'Squad'-system is barely better then giving you differently colored teamnames.  So, what do we have, overall? Just another basic FPS which for sure isn't 'bad or anything', but has, in my oppinion, no real interesting concept or strong point either. The only thing innovative, at all, are the gamemodes (one life per player, 3 objectives, every time an objective is taken the team of the aggressor is respawned).  But that really doesn't save the game at this point. If I want to play a generic FPS, I got loads of them already, no need to buy another one. This game is, indeed, in early developement phase, which means it COULD still get more fleshing out later on. But right now, I really don't see much of a point playing, even less so buying it.

The game features smooth FPS/Military sim controls, that are in the same vain of Call of Duty. This allows for an easier learning curve than something say ARMA where the controls themselves take a fair amount of time to learn and master. So if you have played an FPS before you should be able to run around and shoot. There is not much of a HUD though in the game, you will have to count your rounds as a result (which I personally am all for, though the use of tracer rounds helps you realise when a magazine is near empty). There is also no crosshairs as a result of the diminished HUD, bullets will generally fly in the same direction of the gun but do be wary that this is not preferred as recoil, and movement will greatly decrease this accuracy and you will most likely be killed.  The shooting is very responsive and the guns do have (in my opinion) a good weight. I haven't felt like I've been wielding a pea shooter, this also means that AI and players are easy to kill, as well as yourself. Thus learn to conceal yourself and use cover appropiately.  The AI has shown to be very smart, flanking and out maneuvering as it advances players, they will also hunt you, moving to flashlights of players and recent gunfire locations. They will prove a challenge, especially at high difficulty, in which there are 3 difficulties for AI's. Do be aware of checking the difficulty servers are playing on if you are new to the game and are still learning how to play. Though sometimes the AI makes some, very lucky shots, lets say but from how I've viewed them shooting in AI matches it appears they fire generally from the hip, so it is more of a random factor then an instant targetting mechanic they have. (This may change)  Communication can be done with preset lines like what you would see in Tribes, normal messaging like in most multiplayer games and also voice chat. So far using any of these with the team will serve appropiate, probably reset your voice chat key to something that is easier to reach.  All guns are available from purchase of the game, there will be differing choices available depending on what class you choose in which there are to many to name but each serve a function and will have relevent weaponary, including equipment, armour and accessories. There is a point system like in the recent Call of Duties so you can't pick everything unless the server is constructed that way (most are not).  There are a few game modes, though each match doesn't feel like the same as the AI will move differently on general each match, so don't expect to always be working the same way each match, be prepared to adapt.  Steam workshop is also available, you can get skins for the guns, different sounds on top of many other possible features you can change or add. None of the workshop content requires money so far as I know, I've myself picked up some skins for rifles that people have released.  The game does not have veichles so if you are looking for large scale warfare you would be better looking at ARMA, but if you are looking for a strong infantry skirmish with great gun mechanics, AI, maps and a step away from the norm of lone wolf multiplayer shooters, I would say this game is most likely for you.

Extremely fun game. It has elements of counterstrike and battlefield that are obvious yet it remains a very independent and wholly different game. Graphics are good without being too demanding of graphics proccessors and even on low settings the game looks very nice. There are approx. 20 guns, and you can edit your setup throughout the game, adjusting for various situations. There is a plethora of maps and game modes and, given that the game retains a purely multiplayer center, repeating the same maps and game modes is rarely a hinderence on enjoyment. Being as non-conjectural as possible given my few hours at the time of this review I believe I can definitively say that this game has potential, but in saying that I am simaltaniously attempting to convey my belief that the game is in a juxtaposed disposition of balance, and it is strikingly asymmetrical --- in a VERY good way. In other words, the game is great in its current unaltered state, but has further potential that could be realized, and more than likely will be realized since the developers are not ravenously avarice in relation to big names like the call of duty ♥♥♥♥up devs and producers, who don't deserve to be named in this review.     TLDR: ----- buy this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ right now. It is cheap, has potential, and in saying that IN ITS CURRENT STATE it is ALREADY AN AMAZING GAME!!!!

This review focouses primarily on the co-op vs. AI modes.   Best played with a few close friends and voice chat, insurgency FORCES you to be tactical. Weapon choice, weapon customisation choice, having to reason with your friends to take silencers/etc where necessary. Every session makes you a better oiled machine. It's not about kills or kill/death ratio, it's about positioning, information, effective communication and I'm actually POSITIVE there is so much more I haven't ♥♥♥♥ing copped yet.  It forces you to think about things and work together.  'where's Jim? He went far away and is killing thing there.' No. 'Where's Jim? He went far away. Rip.'  My friends and I got the helicopter-view of the map and drew paths and key positions/timings on an imageboard.  Each level is really a whole project.  Some suggested mods: Realistic sounds Realistic muzzle flash Native Language (arabic) Realsitic blood see-through menu  Suggested other things: Changed view map from N to TAB. Turn off game music.  This isn't my best review, but I seriously love this game. It's not a 'I'm bored, gonna game' it's 'Ok, everyone let's specifically organise a time we can all play together.'

Insurgency is a hardcore FPS. I like it more than other games becasue of its realism, as you will see in the Pros and Cons below. I have just started to play this game and its already been a great purchase even at its $17 price tag. I play on a mac and it was good for a bit and then crashed while changing maps. I tried to reopen it but it crashed on startup. Long story short, you need to go to the context menu on Insurgency (right click it in your library), click properties, go to the tab called 'general' and uncheck the box that says 'Enable the Steam Overlay while in-game'. You will not be able to shift-tab in the game but at least you can play it. I have two monitors so I play on my main monitor and have the chat and friends list on the other.  Pros: -Very realistic -no minimap -minimal HUD -no killfeed (you can have it on if you want but most servers don't allow it) -don't save ammo when reloading (i have 29/30 ammo in a mag and I reload and the 29 bullets are gone) -realistic damage model (1 hit headshot, 1-2 body shot etc.)  Cons: -Crashes on mac sometimes -Not very many players 1000-2000

Insurgency a game with all the realism of the old Rainbow six/Ghost recon games that inspired it coupled with fast multiplayer similar to counter strike ( if a little more methodical). Here we take the role of either the Security forces (USA) or the Insurgents in a thrilling multiplayer game.  I always get an itch for this type of game ever since I played the original Rainbow Six back in the day. The simulator esc shooter where one a bullet or two can take you out, the sound of bullets makes you ♥♥♥♥ your pants. Going low and prone is often a life saviour. Not to mention the stress inducing darkening of the screen as you come under fire. This game can be downright harrowing, COD this is not; fast? At times, but you need to pick your shots, many modes make you wait to re-spawn increasing the need to think about where you are what you’re doing and what’s the next best move.  The game has fair few modes from single life modes like Strike and Ambush to Battlefield esc modes with waves such as Push and Occupy. It even has a co-op vs bots mode that can be really challenging, from survival to a checkpoint challenge. There is no levelling up, rather a unique reward system where you given a point each round and can use it on your equipment or weapon making things flexible in the sense you can try be a tank with heavy armour or a speedy run and gun solider of fortune.   If you like Arma or the old shooters like Ghost recon and Rainbow six this may be the shooter for you it’s a nice balance between realism and arcade shooter fun. I have very few gripes even worth mentioning. The weapons are too few in my opinion I know this is an indie title but there could be more. At times it all becomes to much there a small group of players who are insanely good , they will show no mercy to new players which may turn newcomers off if they are unlucky enough to join some of those guys servers. The community is all over the place there are trolls there and people way to keen for their own good but generally speaking it’s not hard to find a game and most of the players are easy enough going.   I Highly recommended this game its one of my favourite shooters out there and I hope more developers take note on how to make a fun well balanced first person shooter that can also be realistic.

To keep it simple, here is a list:  Cons: - doors are quite narrow (death traps in stressful situations) - where I like that hipfiring is not encouraged you still should be able to at least hit someone from 1-3m without aiming - conflict in the Middle East (it's just repetetive nowadays) - rocket/grenade launchers (not neccessary for infantry only)  Pros: + hardcore realism (hit to the leg slows you down, hit above the hip kills you) + tactical teamwork required + you get the shivers if shots impact all around you and you have no idea of the origin + infantry only (okay, you have to like such a thing) + balanced gameplay + many game types (there is something for everybody) + weapon customization (you decide how pimped your rifle is and what you can additionally take on your mission) + solid stock maps with great performance and in great amount + (new) custom maps (unfortunately lousy performance since people don't know that mapping is not just about appearance) + suppressing fire usually works fine  Bottom line: Clear recommendation from my end because this game combines all you want to have for an 'adult' player shooter. It also manages to keep you motivated even if your team lost once or twice because it's always possible to adapt your tactics to the enemy team and develop.   9/10

Awesome game. Super realistic, decent graphics. This isn't like those other games where you have an indicator to show how much ammo you have left - you've got to guess. Running for long periods of time causes you to breathe louder and faster - making you more easily spotted by by the enemy. More gear = slower. 1 head shot = dead. 1 - 3 shots (depends on what gun you are using) = dead. You have no kills indicator. Overall, it is a great game however, the AI seems to be lacking and there is pretty much no AI snipers. Two major problems with this game is that the game crashes all the time on Macs for some reason - especially when a new map loads and the resolution is absolutely terrible (although the graphics are pretty good).  TO DEVELOPERS: Please fix the Mac issue, I want to be able to be able to play this game on my laptop whilst on the go.  Graphics - 6 Gameplay - 9 Mac support - 3 Windows support - 7 Realism - 10 Recommend - Yes  EDIT: By lowering graphics settings, I was able to fix the Mac issue.

This is the best First Person shooter i've ever played and probably the most realistic one as well.  Graphics are great and the maps are very complex and fairly large.   Audio is great, your radios will allow you to talk with the rest of your squad, however if you say something when an enemy is close, they can hear you also... The only improvement I would like to see is the ability to change the radio volume separately to the rest of the 'sound effects' volume. Player voice chat is controlled seperately to sound effect volume.  Differences to most shooters: 1. Respawns. Depending on the mode, you will run out of respawns in different ways. Some maps give your team a limited number of respawns that you can replenish by capturing/destroying objectives. Other maps only will respawn your team when you capture or destroy an objective. Other maps you get given a limited number of respawns and can't replenish them.  This makes the game MUCH more team-based, as by yourself you will die quickly 2. Health. You don't regenerate it. You will often die from only one or two bullets, and you often have very little idea where you were shot from. This makes your individual tactical approach, as well as your teams strategy, much more important. If you run in the open, you die quickly.  3. Weapons. You get 'supplies' which are used to purchase weapons and upgrades. You can fit different sights, ammunition, barrels, grips and accessories to weapons, you can purhase different types of armour and grenades. You often need to balance what you want, as you don't have enough supplies to get the best of everything. Capturing objectives can give you more supplies.  The only thing that I really dislike about the game is that there are some 'restricted areas' where the game prevents you from being able to shoot. This is designed to keep you playing near the objectives, but sometimes can be painful as you cannot visually see where they start or finish, so sometimes you will run for cover and find yourself in an area that you can't defend yourself in.  Overall a fun game with a steep learning curve and something I would recommend to any other FPS fan.

I liked this game when it was released.  People played tactically, there were snipers, machine gunners, assault guys...  After a recent sale, when the game was for 2 dollars I decided to play this game again...  Here is a brief gameplay for EVERY match IN EVERY server now:  You spawn, thinking that you should help you teammates and push it to the objective, or defend it, depending on your side. After making few steps you see 2-3 RPG missiles going towards your direction - you die. You spawn again - make few steps - and again RPG kills you. Well, lets try again. Somehow you survived another RPG only to make another few steps and die from grenade. But you are stubborn and decide to try again... After many attampts, surviving RPG and grenades, you make it to the objective. You kill camper in the corner and start capturing. RPG and grenades are constantly hitting the wall you are hiding befind and you think that you are fine... gues what - C4 and you die again.  Basically this game now looks more like a Quake 3 or Unreal Tournament. Guns are usless because you die long before you see anyone. Both teams just spamming RPG, Grenades and C4 and the only sound you hear during the play is the sound of explosions. There are almost no gunshots. So I would call this game 'the world of explosives' or 'The world of RPG'  If you are looking for a realistic shooter - avoid this game and play Red Orchestra.

By all means, I am no pro at first-person shooters. I am no pro at CS:GO, and that goes the same for Insurgency.  This game, from what I understand, is a first-person shooter that has controls and abilities beyond other games for it's 'real' life similarity.  A nice game if you a adept to first-person shooters already, but if you're just starting out, maybe something like Combat Arms, Cross Fire, or CS:GO would be a better fit.  Insurgency, taking account of it's release date, does not have very good mechanics. I mean, it's 2015 (2014 of release). For some reason, whatever reason, a C4 explosion can kill you even if you're behind a wall. Of course, this must be very close, but, logically, that makes no sense. At least a huge health hit would be better, not an instant-kill. For some reason, the graphics, although many parts wonderful, looks as if it's the child of CS:S and CS:GO. Just add in the dust everywhere and you're set to create 'Insurgency'.  Did I mention you die REALLY GOD DAMN QUICK in this game? Seriously. Three shots of anything could basically kill you. Hey, are you lying on the floor trying to cross map an enemy? Huh? You didn't see that guy to the left? Oh! He just shot you and you died. Welps!  Also, team mates and enemies are almost identical in their colors. I actually team killed the first time I went into a bot game. Yes, a bot game. I could hardly see any name tags (didn't see any), so I assumed it was an enemy. Two shots, dead. Later on, a bot rushed in and three shot me, less than a second, and I was dead.  But hey, I guess this relates to real life, right?  I'm not trying to say that this game is bad. It's not. I personally just did not like it, even refunded (so long, Terraria). Like all games, not everyone will enjoy it to the same degree. I find faults with this game that made it a deal breaker. I do not recommend this game to anyone who is already good, or playing, other first-person shooters. You will not enjoy the experience on Insurgency, and it will not help you improve on your other first-person shooter games. I do recommend you try it for yourself, just buy it on Steam, play for a hour or so, and then refund it. Remember that the refund limit is 2 hours.

This game is definitely one of the best shooters I have ever played. I would say that this game is a cross between COD and ARMA. Now I know people ♥♥♥♥ on COD (I do), but in terms of mechanics it has some of the most fluid controls out there, and Insurgency feels even better to me. This game will always keep you on your toes and thinking, as it is 2-3 shot kill at most. It is a harsh yet balanced game.  The various gamemodes force teams to actually play together in order to win. A team of sup-par players can consistently win against players of higher skill if they work together and the other team doesn't. This tactical gameplay is one of the most enjoyable parts of the game. Unlike other FPS where you just mindlessly shoot, die, respawn, Insurgency forces you to treasure every life you are given (as they are few and sometimes far between) and work with people.  This review may make it sound like this game is serious or hardcore, and it is, but if you play with friends it can be a real blast. Also, the devs constantly release new content (guns, maps, gamemodes) for free because they freaking rock.

This game does not give a great first impression. Most will buy Insurgency on a whim, join a server and get completely decimated and have no idea how many of the popular game types work. Like Counter-Strike, it takes effort and patience to learn the mechanics as well as the objective game types. Once you do, you're in for one hell of a game.   Also, I wouldn't suggest this game if you do not have a few friends to play with. Why? Beating the other team relies on communication just as much as it does hitting a fatal shot on your target.   Fire fights in this game are about as intense as it gets. Players are killed with 1-2 bullets so developing a plan to get a jump on your target is essential. You do not need to have your target in plain view to make shooting at them meaningful. There is a suppression mechanic in this game that will make a players screen turn blurry when they are receiving fire behind cover. Communicating to a team mate to move up on a target that is being suppressed is not only strategic but extremely rewarding.   This game will have you on the edge of your seat. Do yourself a favor, gather a few friends and hop on this game, it will consume you.

I've been playing a lot of Arma 3 mods, DayZ, lately. Battlefield 3-4 when each was released but not since. This week I bought CS:GO and Insurgency.   I used to play CS back when it was a mod in 1998! I played the original release. I would come and go over the years, but eventually dropped it completely. WIth the recent Holiday sale I decided to give CS:GO a shot and was disappointed to discover just how little the game has evolved. I suppose that is purposeful given the community, but for me I was bored by the gameplay, and graphics that still to me at least... feel small... like all the people are little action figures running around... compared to other games with more detailed models/scale/weighty physics. But this isn't about CS...  I bought Insurgency Four pack because I've been having fun playing with my friends in various games lately and damn was I ever happy.  I've seen the game kicking around on Steam since it was released roughly two years ago and now I wish I bought it sooner. I always figured it was kind of a CS clone... but it REALLY ISN'T. This game is EXACTLY what I want. Realism! Fun! The weapons feel incredible, the gameplay feels realistic, the sound design was awesome. I really enjoy the level design and game modes. And all of this has only been in 4 hours of game time thus far. It has exceeded my expectations. My first impression was that if felt like a moderized Rainbow Six Rogue Spear but faster and more fun in general. But it really is its own thing and a better game than that ever was. I love that you never actually know for certain if you've killed someone in the distance or behind a wall unless you see the body hit the ground. No kill messages, no gamey interface, it is great. The levels are great medium size for fast but realistic gameplay.   Totally recommend for anyone that likes realistic gameplay that is also reasonably fast paced. I'm surprised by the metacritic rating. It deserves higher, and the USER reviews rating IS higher. Funny since it is usually the opposite with most games, with AAA games getting hyped/paided off high ratings and then the users give the real story. Well with this game the users have given the real story and it is great. No idea how many hours I'll put into this but wow, what a great first impression.

Ok, i quit trying to write text reviews so I'll just make a simple list.  Good stuff: - it's a tactical shooter in the sense that you can't just run around aimlessly shooting people in the face to win, instead having to learn the maps and watch corners, planning your next move, at least on competitive; - the maps are not too big and encourage a more carefull way of playing, throwing off 'run and gun' type of players and giving room to the more skillfull type of players; - the damage model is realistic, which might be a turn on for hardcore FPS players; - team work is also encouraged in competitive mode due to the benefits of providing information and coordenating moves; - balanced weight loadout system with fairly realistic guns and tools, all usefull in some way; - there's a coop gamemode, definitely fun for playing with a friend.  Bad Stuff: - the high damage model makes the tme to kill rather short, which might be frustrating when getting into the game; - the maps, while providing a lot of fun tactical gameplay, together with the damage model also encourage camping, which might also create some frustrating moments; - there´s no singleplayer (the game is totally multiplayer focused and for me thats excelent, but it could be a downside for other players).  It's a fun multiplayer experience with a doubt, with many hours to enjoy alone or with a friend (recommended)

Insurgency the legend of tacticalnesses as i say do i recomend it? for some people and let me explain:  basicly Insurgency is one of those games where if you run out in the open like a ♥♥♥♥ing luni you're gonna get shot up by a sniper down range so tacticalnesses is key you need to be undercover and sneaky flank the unobvious spots and if you do fight out in the middle of the batle stay low and dont rush in instead let the enemy make the first move.  so why did i just explain how to play the game? well if you come from a game life csgo and you're instinct is to rush ♥♥♥♥ then this aint the game for you unless if you're willing to take in some new mechanics and game style then buy it.  anyway enough about why certain people should get the game let me explain why i love this game alot.  so Insurgency in my opinion alows you to jump into smooth servers with good fps and realistic like game style the surrounding within the game looks nice and 'camofladged' so by that i mean it alows you to use the map to you're advantage easier so i absolutely love that in a game. Also i love how the game isn't based on being the 1 guy on your team who ♥♥♥♥s everyone up and carries the game is much more team based so you can use comms to you're advantage which can prove very helpful within a FPS stratigic game. The gun mechanics are very exiting and well put together so you are able to have a chance against a long range sniper or a close range attacker you can change the fire type or whatever you call it so you can go burst fire fully auto or semi auto which well help with long range battles diffrent scopes attachments which will give you a stratigic advantage to help you with diffrent play styles. Finaly i'd like to review the buying system which i find quite interesting basicly per round you get a spending coin thingy which goes towards you're guns,attachments,grenades and armour. personaly i find this a very clever choice for a game like this mostly because it alows new people to the game to have equal firepower against a more expereinced play and also i think that it makes it more fair in firefights because you could have a sniper which is really experienced which has all of the attachments for his sniper and everything else but with the mechanic they have put in it will make it more equal so that wont happen.  So i know i said finnaly earlier but i have somthing quick to adress to people who buy the game from personal experience i have had a glitch where i get no XP or K/D ratio showing up after a game now the only thing you can use that for is braging rights so it isnt that bad but thought i might adress it and also i got told by some friends that if you download it for the first time and put all you video settings to what you normaly have eg. 1680x1080p high (texture settings) etc. then it'll crash you're whole gmae which will cause you to REINSTALL IT so yeah just make sure that you dont do that unless if you want to reinstall it after you just bought it.  Anyway hope that review helped some people who are interested in the game and yeah enjoy the game....

Instantly accessible and very playable tactical shooter that still retains a bit of arcade action. For example you can flash a doorway and jump through while spinning mid air to land and fill your blind opponent full of ammo. This might sound silly however the game does require you to be methodical and approach objectives cooperatively and make sure you get the angles covered. It’s not as fluid as Call of Duty but it’s not as clunky as Arma. Weapons are hitscan but the ranges you engage targets at do not really make this much of an issue. Fans of deep tactical shooters should not be put off by this statement though as hardcore features exist throughout. Such things like elements of the HUD being hidden during combat. There are no crosshairs and the weapons operate in free aim mode meaning when you move your mouse your weapon model moves around the screen a bit and never sit in the same place. Also weapons collide with surfaces, meaning you need to be careful how you position yourself. I highly recommend the game and for the price there is no excuse for this game not to be a part of any true PC FPS gamer's collection.

I love this game. It is entirely based on how well you organize your resources, and thus how well you use said resources, not how good your guns are (if someone has a 'better' gun than you, no biggy. Get it yourself by switching roles!). What is also nice is the Steam workshop support, which holds a vast array of player models and gun skins, as well as maps, which at the moment have custom servers running for the said maps. Another cool thing are the servers hosted for mods such as the Day of Infamy mod, which creates a WW2 environment including maps, guns, and player skins, hosted on dedicated servers. How ever, it is suggested for use on a good computer, but turning down your graphics is no biggy (while what you may see in your scope might be chunkier, it still works well enough to pick off baddies). What I also find helping is shutting off unnecessary apps (mostly anything other than Insurgency and Steam). Definitely a well built game for lets see, 1... 2... 3... 15 US dollars. Well, considering how much fun I have had, that is a decent price (at least it isn't CoD priced ;3).

The inability to add more allied bots sucks too, not because I want to kill all realism of a covert mission but because your fellow bot allies are likely to die quickly. This game has a lot of potential, and if it implemented a stealth machanic to the AI that would be terrific, but atm all they do is give away your position and aim worse than a storm trooper while doing so... always needing to carry the team becomes a drag after a while, and the only use I get from them is if I do die, I can possess their bodies and take over, which is a great idea I've been waiting for someone to actually use in a game.  TL:DR? Great game so far but solo gaming needs some serious improvement.  carrying on with my review, if my bot allies were able to know where my gun is pointing whenever I'm aiming down it so they don't obstruct my view, if they actively sought out objectives or better yet, gave me the ability to give them orders like in Rainbow Six, awesome! and if they actually aimed better than enemy AI, they are meant to be like special forces or something aren't they? So it would make sense if their ability is atleast, slightly better than your foes so you don't feel like the babysitter all the time, AWESOME!... I would recommend you buy this game, IF, you have wired connection for good ol multiplayer against strangers over the net, or if you have friends to game with who have it too... otherwise you might end up eventually breaking your keyboard and using colorful language since I'm pretty sure this isn't call of duty, and so neither is it designed for you to be the one man army, and if you're like me, you like games that feel balanced to some realism at least.

I actually really like this game. The co-op is pretty fun, and is guaranteed to keep you entertained for a while; I'd guess at least 10 hours, probably more, but if you're only interested in co-op then you might want to look for another game because this game is strongest in multiplayer. Now the game isn't perfect, and I do have a few problems with it. First of all, just a few maps tend to be the most dominantly played, so they can sometimes feel a little repetative. Secondly, in the Push game mode, the Security Forces are the attackers probably 3 out of every 4 maps, and push tends to be heavily defender-biased, so Insurgent forces probably win the majority of the time. Third, Sinjar. Yes, just Sinjar. Really though, it can be a pretty fun game. There are several classes to choose from on each team, and each class has access to 3 or 4 different weapons out of a pool of probably 10 or so, plus lots of additional gear like a few different sights, silencers, and different grenades. Not every class has access to the same gear, so everybody can't spam silencers, for example. You can select your gear using Supply Points, which starts at 10 in multiplayer (15 in co-op) and increases by 1 point each round. Guns, armor, gear and different types of ammo all cost supply points, so it's important to choose what's most important to you carefully. Overall, I'd rate this game about 8.5/10.

Such a good game. Gameplay feels meaty and pretty realistic without being clunky like Arma. Shooting guns feels great, I'd even say better than some other AAA games out there. To get the best experience you have to play as a team and stick together to clear out objectives in order to keep the game pace up; that's pretty much all the gameplay in a nutshell.  Graphically the game isn't too shabby. Some maps look almost as good as Battlefield 3, others to me look like incomplete CS Source maps to me. Gun models look great and sound great, which really helps build the ambiance for this game, so even if some maps don't look photo realistic, they feel like an actual firefight area. Particles really bring everything together like no other game out there imo.   Performance isn't too great in this game, or at least not as good as you would expect. While in most other Source games I'm usually staying over 120 fps without many drops below 100 and almost none under 60, Insurgency runs a little wonky, averaging around 80 fps with drops here and there below 60. However, running the game on lowest settings nets performance increases similar to other Source games. You can most likely run this game just fine if you are running an intergrated gpu from an i5 6600.  Community is hit or miss. You just need to find the right server and meet the right people. If someone is spamming their mic, it's very easy to mute them. I've only met a hacker once in my entire time while playing the game, who was eventually banned. A lot of the people who complain about hackers play on the same servers which hackers probably frequent. If you stick to clan servers it's very unlikely for a hacker to join.  Overall the game is a great value. I'd recommend this to anyone that plays a lot of CS, Arma or Red Orchestra because this game is a nice middleground between these 3 games. It's constantly on sale and imo even at 15 bucks it's a steal for how much content it has.

(An updated review)  A Tactical FPS set in a modern middle-eastern setting, it was one of the best games for its price at $15, now its a crime to get this game at its price of $10. Funny enough, I originally got this game along with others during a sale I believe, and really didn't expect to play much of it, that being around one and a half years ago. Now, its practically one of the only games I play often, partly because the multplayer is amazing as well as the mechanics of the game.  Firstly, the mechanics of the game are amazing and feel realistic and authentic while not being a mil sim like ARMA for example (not that it's a bad thing, but this game has similar faster pased FPS mechanics with other games but maintains more realism, despite not being as complex as mil sims). Generally 1-2 shots to the chest or 1 to the head are enough to kill someone, of course depending on the weapon and ammo type. A makorov pistol without any hp or armor piercing ammo will take many shots to kill someone at a longer range for example, but a Mosin or FAL with armor piercing would kill most things in one shot. That said, the damage model is obviously very high, with 1-2 shots at medium ranges being the general number of shots to down an enemy. There is no regenerating health, and if you want tp get health back you have to resupply, as well as getting more ammo for you gun. There are no crosshairs so aiming down sights is the only way to know where your shots are going most of the time, if you control your recoil. Hipfire is free aim making it harder to shoot people with initially, especially for me when I first played it thinking it would shoot in the middle of the screen like most FPS, but if you train your hipfire with a laser sight and adjust your hipfire sensitivities, you'll have a HUGE advantage over other players in PvP, as well as PvE to some extent. If you run out of ammo and don't resupply at your last spawn, you can collect other weapons on the ground with F, but if the gun doesn't share your ammo or gun type, then you won't get the mags the other player was carrying but just whatever was left in the gun, forcing players to more or less stick to their loadouts from their specific classes (which there are plenty anwyways) unless in a pinch, which is a good thing (so that not everyone can have 30 rounds for a sniper rifle they pick up etc.). That said, there's a lot of customization for each class, as they typically have several guns to chose from, as well as atachments such as different types of holoscppes with different magnifiyers, barrel attachments like a heavy barrel or supressor, underbarrel attachments like a bipod or foregrip, extended mags, different ammo types, etc. This also applies to secondary weapons although to a lesser extent, and there is also further customization with nades including frags, smokes, and flashes, chest rigs to carry more ammo and nades, and light and heavy armor to survive more damage. This means that there is always a loadout to suit your class for the situation, so even if you're a sniper, if there is an objective which doesn't faciliate or benefit from sniping, you can adjust your loadout to have a gun with a less magnified scope or a weapon that is better in close quarters. Furthermore, weight should also be kept into consideration, as more nades, heavier weapons, and armor adds to your weight, and depending on your class and playstyle, it might be better to use less supplies for armor or chestrigs etc for more speed; this is especially crucial in gamemodes like push, and light armor is most likely best over heavy armor. Classes are extremely important and even if you're team isn't directly communicating, such as in a pub, performing your role of your class is extrememly effective, such as deploying smoke grenades from your gun as demolitions, or giving supressive fire as support/machinegunner. In terms of the HUD, it's very minimalistic, you have the objective location, number of waves of your team (depending on gamemode), time left, and what objectives there are and what objectives are being capped (depending on gamemodes etc.). There is no mini-map, yet with the 'n' key by default, you can display a map of the current map and friendly locations, as well as a coordinate grid. Being supressed makes your display significantly blurrier, and in rare instances (such as being supressed in close quarters) can give you such limited vision that it can make it difficult to see in front of you sometimes. Generally however, being supressed isn't too annoying yet is quite effective, and can make it harder to aim or focus. Supression is even helpful at determining if you're being shot at, especially from longer distances, along with the sound cracks and sounds of bullets whizzing by your head.  In terms of PvP, it is pretty well balanced most of the time, with several gamemodes for each map, the most common one being push (although I wouldn't say the best in my opinion). Push is one of the most simple of gamemodes, and is most common in pubs and 32 player servers; basically in Push one team must run and capture and objective while the defending team must stop them, with there being 3 objectives and a final cache and each objective capture granting more waves and time for the offensive team. Push can especially be chaotic, but luckily the maps always grant numerous oppurtunities to each objective. That said, many inexperienced players will probably stick to the same route each time using the exact same loadout rushing the same place until dieing each time, which can be the most frustrating thing having bad players on the offensive side. Defenders don't have to change their strategies too much during a game of push if it works, thus more teamwork is required on those pushing, yet the gamemode is still balanced as the maps allow several ways to confront the objectives despite new players going the most obvious route. This also segways into another topic, which is the maps. All maps are well polished and fun, but can be extrememly complex (Tell comes to mind), and as a new player, I would imagine it being extrememly frustrating and aggrivating your first time playing PvP, especially with no kill cams and the like. Knowing the maps is part of the learning curve of Insurgency, as well as its mechanics, but mastering both are satisfying, but consider the warning of an initial learning curve as it may scare newer players, especially those more used to games like CoD or even Battlefield off. Even when dying, the chaos and sounds of the warzone still makes it fun seeing death from your perspective morbidly engaging, as well as seeing your teammates die spectaculary while in front of you or spectating them; either way the immersion will still keep you hooked despite your skill. There are also nighttime versions of the maps which are also fun, adding a new dynamic of using nvg goggles, flashlights, or flare guns and altering your enemies' perception of light to your advantage. Besides 32 player matches, there are also 24 player matches under tactical operations which are often filled with more experienced players and more tactical gamemodes, in which each person is given a single life unless an objective is captured. If you bought Insurgency for its tactical gameplay, servers under Tactical Operations will probably be what you're looking for, as the game is more methodical and slower paced. There is also 5v5 competitive modes which I haven't played too much of and it's a bit more experimental at the moment, but its another option to play PvP (not even mentioning custom servers). PvE is also good and lots of people play it exclusively as well. There is also infinite free skins and maps on the workshop, as well as updates from the devs too, and as my character limit is running out all I can say is that I give this game one of the highest reccomendations if you can get pass the learning curve.  I give it 10 Jihads/Allah.

Pros:   Insurgency has enough realism to make it strategically fun, yet not to where you feel it over controlling.  Kit selection is fun to play with and change your loadouts. Sacraficing points in one area to use them on another.  Sounds seem to be amazing and with new updates things like foot steps are much better and more useable.  Stable, the game is so much more stable then at first early access. I have not had a game crash and the only issue I have now is related to my Mac only. Menu selection sometimes has the mouse disappear and sometimes you can still power through it and other times even when highlighting a menu option I can't still select the option. I don't play a lot on the Mac though, so it doesn't impact me too much.  It feels a lot like America's Army, with some changes like respawns. I normally play with objective based respawns, but there are some wave respawns in certain game mode as well. Which allows for the results to swing at times which is refreshing to me. One guy can take a single objective and that act allows your team to spawn and can turn the tide.  Cons:  Community, like all multiplayer games you still have to deal with the annoyance of not so friendly players. For the most part though it isn't intolerable.  Servers are mostly best of 5, which for me sometimes is a bad thing. On maps I don't care for I really like this, but on competitive matches sometimes it just seems too short.  Lack of teamwork, like stated in the Pros, this game requires teamwork. Which for me is a pro, but when just hoping on for a short time with no buddies playing it can be a con at the same time. If you get on a team that doesn't want to work together, it can be rather frustrating.   Final thoughs:  If you are looking for a combination of America's Army meets Counter Strike then I recommend the game highly. I play CS:GO and Arma 3, two completely dfferent FPS games and this game for me seems like a great middle ground. Not as face paced as CS, but not as slow and sometimes flat out boring as Arma 3.

This game, at its core mechanics and feel is a blend of Counter Strike game-modes and Red Orchestra gun play. It's run on the Source Engine and is spiritual successor to an old mod (which at the time had a huge playerbase). If you're looking for a new tactical shooter thats on a smaller scale than ARMA and has more arcade shooting mechanics than this is the game for you. That being said the pace of the game is about what a match of Red Orchestra would be like, you want to get to the objectives as quick as possible but as cautiously as possible. If you don't plan on communicating with your team or at the very least following orders from a squad leader and supporting your squad then this probably isnt your style of game. The game shines when teams use communication and performs like a well oiled machine.

Even in it's alpha, its bugs (and yes, there are some, and yes, you might crash) this game is worth investing in. The Co-op is a blast with friends (hint: use Voip, not chat) and the multiplayer is fun too.   The game has a ways to go before it can really be considered polished, but I had a blast with people who seemed a lot less pissy than they do in games like Counterstrike and the like. It's got a good atmosphere and brutal realism which strongly encourages working together over going it alone, and I've always really been a fan of Insurgency, even when it was in its early stages as a downloadable mod.  It's very easy to become a leader, simply by using your microphone to inform everybody of the situation and to guide players on where they should go. Players seem pretty inclined to listen and play along, instead of just running off on their own to die.  It makes every kill feel very satisfying, and when you and a 'team' on a co-op server clear a map, it results in congratulations all around.   It has some very unique mechanics that simply make it a game worth buying.  The team is doing a really good job bringing this together, and I really wish them the best.

Insurgency feels like a hybrid of Rainbow Six 3 and Battlefield. Firefights break out from periods of silence when everyone is leaning around corners and crawling prone trying to get to the objectives. The gunplay feels good with smooth firing animations and fantastic sound design.   I can't 100% recommend this game though. I stopped playing it because the overall map design is unfocused. I really don't like how Insurgency is trying to be both close quarters combat and open range sniper fights with its map selection. Some people like that variety but I don't and would much rather have the maps focus on CQC.  The night maps are also redundant and frustrating, more often than not forcing you to waste precious inventory space on night vision goggles. Don't get me wrong, a couple of the maps like Heights and Ministry are great, but they are in the minority.  I have no problem with the skill ceiling of the game and felt like the classes were relatively balanced with strengths and weaknesses. It was the map design that killed it for me, but that might not be a dealbreaker for you like it was for me. Despite all of that Insurgency is still a good game, it just wasn't the one I could truly sink my teeth into.

A really addictive first person tactical shooter, where you either play as Insurgents or the US marines. There are many different game modes that keep it different and affect the dynamic of the game. In Pvp theres ambush(where you have to protect a vip and get him to either of two extraction points), to the most popular game mode of push whereby your team has to capture points a,b,c then blow a weapons cache at d with a limited number of waves the attacking team has the defending team has the advantage. The co op side of the game is more limited as the game has an emphasis on Pvp but its just as good and addictive.  Pros: Gun Sounds are great in this game everything sounds intense. Gun Design is probably the best ive ever come across they put alot of thought into the weapons here. Explosives sound great and seem well proportioned in blast size, relative to what they are. Character movement seems generally fluid and well done. Voice acting is decent and hilarious at times. Alot of custom maps on certain servers. Its just too damn fun!  Cons: Bit buggy in places(grenade launcher rounds dont always go off if shot at something close) Could do with some more weapons(insurgent team is lacking in sub machine guns) Dosnt like being tabbed out then tabbed back in, the rejoining process is jittery with sound going nuts. Various sound and sometimes visual bugs. Hitboxes dont always seem well placed when in spectator mode but when playing seem pretty on point.

This game's multiplayer is quite bad. The game itself is not bad. It's the multiplayer part of it that it's bad. Co-op is a lot of fun, and I guess 16-player servers are also nice. I've primarily played Push, which as I understand is the most popular mode. The game is a camper's wet dream. There is very little tactical element in the game, although it's supposed to be a highly tactical game. Instead matches quickly devolve into camp-fests, where you just run to the best spot to camp the approach of your enemy. The problem is that most maps are too small to accomodate this type of game. It is suprisingly easy to run over from your spawn to your enemy's spawn and just camp their corridors to not let them get out of their spawnpoint. In some maps, like Panj, you can kill spawning enemies without ever leaving your own spawn point. Both teams will rely heavily on explosives, instead of actual gunplay to achieve their objectives. I sincerely hear more explosions than I hear gunfire in a whole match. C4 will kill everyone in a building (not just a room), and grenade launchers carry up to 6 rifle grenades. Killing a rocketeer or a demolitionman will actually cause more harm than good, since they will respawn with their explosives and spam them. Don't buy this game, you will regret it. It's a shame, because it's a good game, but the way people play it makes it into a very bad game. If you want a tactical experience, go play Red Orchestra 2/Rising Storm. It's essentially the same game, but set during WW2, and with a lot better maps and balance.

Definitely, worth to play.  Red Ochestra in a modern military context.  SWAT 4, Ghost Recon and classic Rainbow Six players will have a good time with Insurgency in the Coop mode and PvP too.   It's immersive, yes, but also has many arcade elements without loosing the slow paced and challenging gameplay.  If you played SWAT 4, Ghost Recon and a little bit of Rainbow Six back in the day because of the tactical and slow paced gameplay, you'll have a bit of that in that Coop mode, very challenging AI Bots, up to 8 Coop players with different classes (there is no Medic class, 1 shot can be letal). It's all about team gameplay. No instant respawns, unless an objective is captured or destroyed.  Coop have 3 different modes, and some of them are lengthy to complete with your team, which is fun or challenging.  PvP is great too, up to 32 players, various different modes, no kill feedback (by default, can be turned on), no killcam, no kill streaks or special boosts or advantages. Every weapon is unlocked (if the server allows it), no rank restriction to use any of them. There is only the restriction of weight, which means, each weapon, vest, explosives, etc, have different weight points and is not allowed to equip more than the limitation from the servers weight points, which somehow is a balanced method for both teams because they have the same weight limitation, which can be increased by each round for both teams.   There is Recoil (is noticeable, but not that realistic).  No status feedback and UI in game: No health, regen or status displayed, no map or HUD, reticule. Only for Voice and Text Communication.  Graphics and Audio are Ok. It's a Mod, a good one. Official DLC's are Free, with support of Steamworkshop with custom Maps as well.

(If you don't actually want to read this, just go to the bottom for a tl;dr.)  Make no mistake, this is not CS:GO. This is not CoD. This is not Battlefield 4 (though BF4, out of those 3, resembles this game the most). This game has no health count. This game has no ammo count. This game has no kill cam. This game has no 360 no-scopes. This game has no doritos and mountain dew. This game has camping. This game has realistic mechanics. This game has realistic situations that require teamwork to complete. This game, well, this game is just what it says in the description. Insurgency is 'intense close quarters combat'.   For a first time FPS gamer, this game is not like the rest. If you want to get into FPS gamings, if you want to play tons of FPS games, this game, well, it'll be the one that stands out in the pack, for better or for worse. For me, it's for better. I own CS:GO, and MW3 on the PS3. CS:GO did not appeal to me. MW3 did for a bit, but I got into PC gaming, got more mature, etc., and it lost it's appeal. Since then, I've played games like TF2 and League of Legends. But I felt like I needed a real, non-gimmicky FPS that I could enjoy, come back to, and thoroughly enjoy for hours upon hours.  I've found it.  The gameplay is realistic, fast-paced yet slow enough to build tension, and just overall intense and epic fun. Your K:D ratio will not matter. You'll complete objectives, stop the other team from capping your points. You will die, rage, but continue playing because IT'S JUST THAT FUN.   There are 8 gamemodes in PvP, and 4 co-op, each endless fun, some requiring more skill than others. There are 9 unique and customizable classes for the Security side, and 10 for the Insurgents. Each provide different roles for the team, and each can be used effectively in gameplay.   And the community. Wow. Most FPS games have, well, terrible communities. CoD is full of 10 year olds who have apparently banged your mom. Alrighty then. As does Halo. CS:GO and others like it are full of people who just seem to find other people to hate on always.  This game has it's fairshare of d*ckheads, but it is generally pretty awesome. You'll meet people that give you hope that this community could match up with the likes of the TF2 community, yet smaller and maybe even better. Plus, it takes a sh*tload more skill to be good at this game, so it keeps tons of the 360 no-scope 420 blaze it kids away.  And example of this epic community is found in my friend, his name is 'a cactus'. I refer to him as cactus, because I mean, calling him a cactus is kinda weird. We were defending point B in a Push round, cactus was on the other team. I didn't know him yet. There were about 2 minutes left, and we had leaders in these 2 guys who kind of held our whole team together. Out of nowhere, in the top left corner of the screen, I see, 'Banning [Leader 1]' (forget his real name). I was astonished. He had not been hacking, breaking no rules. He was our best player. Anyway, we continue, and now it's down to about 1 minute where I see, 'Banning [Leader 2]'. Huh? Again, this guy was awesome and was banned by the other team because they wanted an advantage over us. Long story short, our team collapsed without those two and they took B, proceeded to take C, and then destroyed our cache.  After the game, I got a friend invite from cactus. I asked him who he was. He said he was on the other team, and said what they did was pretty sh*tty and, for the record, he voted no to ban those two guys. He said they were trying to ban our best players so they could win. I was annoyed and upset. It was the first time I had seen anything like that in the Insurgency community.  But cactus showed to me how good this community really is, he showed me that this game's community is really top notch. There are tons of guys like cactus around this community.  When you begin, though, you will find the mechanics hard to grasp, the guns hard to aim, etc. Find a class that works for you, keep trying with it, try different scopes, ammo, etc. on the guns, and just keep at it. My first kill was a lucky headshot on Panj, while I was in prone. I couldn't believe it. I died, like, 3 seconds later. I didn't get a kill for another day. Now, I get MVP, learned to play the objectives. I got 330 points in a game today. And I've only played this game for about 25 hours. Jeez.  That about wraps up my review. Please. Do not hesitate to get this game. It is probably the best $15 buy I've ever made on a game. Get it.  tl;dr: get this game. seriously. do it now.

JUST TRY IT!   This game is actually really fun to play and more fair to players that do not spend 3000 hours like smurfs in games like CS:GO.   Almost real damage simulation (at least there is no '4 glock hits - no kill' like in CS:GO). When in close combat, 75% chance you will kill the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with a spray of bullets if well managed.  You get actually suppresed when under heavy fire, and bullets do actually spread out and pull smoke all over the place.  There are very few cheaters (did not found one yet) and it is really hard to 'smurf' or carry a whole team, you will may get a great score, but you will lose if you do not focus on objectives - teamwork.   The maps are just the right size not to be studied corner by corner, but also not to be bored because of large distances. You will be firing, running and mostly crouching all the time. Campers die easily when pushed (real grenade damage - unlike CS:GO).  If you run around trying to get frags like in CoD, you instantly die. Also, the snipers are not so overpowered like in other games. Smokes really work and it is also possible to easily shoot the snipers back with a rifle. Also, there will not be more than 1 sniper every 12 players, you are always forced to choose from a variety of squad fighters with different equipment. You will be fully equiped from the very beginning too - no more eco rounds.  It is also possible to grab anything you find on the floor ;) Furthermore, if you are carrying heavy stuff, you will run slower... ALL THE TIME! (no more knife switching)  The weapons and bullet impacts sound much better than in other games, more realistic recoil, more firingpower feel.  All weapons are actually usefull in the right hands. No bullet counter, no reloading while running, no crossfire (only laser pointer addon - they will spot you really fast)  + Nightfighting :D! actual flashlight/ nightvision simulation :D :D :D   It runs on poor systems like mine (1000$ - 2013 Vaio laptop), which will make this game popular, anyway, it is already full enough of players. You know, gameplay > graphics (which are good enough though).   The different game objectives are also fun to play, and the fraggers will die in hell with very poor scores (10 points/frag, 100 points/objective).   It is not a game intended to overtake CS or BF4 or CoD, but just try it, you will play it regularly.   88/100  Allahu ackbar brothers!

Other than this, the minor in-game glitches are very bearable and usually do not affect performance or gameplay.  My rating: 9 out of 10 With Rice: 12 out of 10

Stubling upon this game during Steam sale, this is well spent 5 bucks. Game is hard, yet simple. One or two bullet - that's all it takes. Plenty of game modes with a lot of servers. Looking for a game? Takes about 2-3 seconds, depending on your network.   When playing coop against computer controlled enemies you never feel safe, always being on edge. The same is with human players. And this is what the game is all about. Think, don't rush, be cautious, shoot only when you are sure you land one.   One big downside is - if you are playing on Mac, be prepared for a lot of crashes. This is very annoying, especially when you find a good players, only to find yourself to get dropped from the game. What a bummer.   Graphics: 6/10  Sound: 9/10 Atmosphere: 10/10  Worth buying? Definitely yes. Whoever created this deserves money for it.  Plus, you will learn russian fast, which is nice bonus.

Insurgency is a very tactical and balanced game, highly depends on teamwork and communication. You will find that taking time scoping the area and checking corners in groups will benefit 100% rather then sprinting ahead and rushing without your team to score some kills as those actions will be very punishing- mostly to your team as in most game modes players have one life only and 2 bullets are enough to kill you.  Insurgency is a different game, it steps away from generic shooters and creates a whole new experience, every victory is very satisfying, and every defeat can teach you how to change your tactics and adapt to your enemy.  Gun customization is also balanced, players will have to choose what attachments they want on their weapons based on their gameplay, many times in order to have your favourite attachment or equipment you will have to sacrifice something else like a secondary weapon or a different expensive attachment like a suppressor.  The game runs smooth, the graphics are beautiful and very fitting, the use of very (and I mean VERY) limited HUD and lack of kill feed (some servers will have those, but by default it's turned off) create an immersive experience. _________  Like every game there will be some bugs and some game's features are kind of unclear such as when you look at the map (with the N button by default) you don't always see your position very clearly. BUT so far Devs have been updating the game and fixing problems.  I'm not going to score the game, but I believe everyone should try Insurgency even for few hours. I'd recommend it to anyone who likes FPS games as its very likely Insurgency will be a new and fresh experience for them them.

Your character is screaming bloody murder as your squad screeches orders at you to go to an enemy cache and destroy it. You have to be so much more tactical and actually have to work with your team. Another military online shooter? Don't groan and roll your eyes just yet. Despite being a stand-alone update on a seven-year-old Half-Life 2 mod, Insurgency's freshness runs deeper than its familiar urban warfare settings and 'good guys vs. the terrorist infidels' trappings might suggest. This first-person multiplayer killfest pushes cooperative team play in interesting directions, using hyperrealism and a unique team role structure to drive its frenetic team-based firefights. Granted, it's not the slickest-looking shooter, but the dated look of these battlefields melts away as the intense tactical encounters heat up.  highly recommended!!! XD
